headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

headline: Economy Hits U.S. PC Sales, but Notebook Growth Remains Strong
abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

headline: Amazon Gains Share of Shrinking Paid Music Market
abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

headline: Yahoo’s Starting Point: A Clearer Strategy
abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

headline: The Network That AT&T’s Growing Profits Will Buy
abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

headline: Clinton’s High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

headline: The iPhone Shortage
abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: A 3-D Viewfinder for a Shoebox of Digital Photos
abstract: A system that can make it easier to put two-dimensional photos into the three-dimensional space of Google Earth is an intriguing alternative to an automated service developed in part by Microsoft.

headline: NebuAd Observes ‘Useful, but Innocuous’ Web Browsing
abstract: NebuAd says it has deals to monitor the Web surfing activity of 10 percent of the people in America. It is building a file that will associate each of those users–identified by the Internet Protocol address–with 1,000 potential interests.

headline: Phorm’s All-Seeing Parasite Cookie
abstract: Phorm, the Internet company that wants to display advertising based on where people surf, has developed a variation on the cookie — code numbers stored by Web browsers — that can help track far more information than cookies have before.

headline: A Loss for Journalism
abstract: Herb Greenberg, one of the best financial reporters I know, announced today that he is leaving Market Watch to start an independent research firm.

headline: ’30 Rock’ Moves to 9:30, Temporarily
abstract: Two weeks after NBC was criticized for showing a racy episode of “30 Rock” during its self-proclaimed family hour, 8 to 9 p.m., it has changed course and moved the show to 9:30 p.m. on Thursdays, although, network officials say, for a different reason, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Ben Affleck’s ‘Nightline’ Assignment
abstract: The actor Ben Affleck traveled to the war-torn eastern Congo to do a report for Thursday’s edition of “Nightline.”

headline: SAG President Urges Supporters To Reject Competing Union’s Deal
abstract: “Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild publicly declared war on a fellow actors’ union at a Monday rally here, increasing the likelihood of new labor strife in an entertainment industry still recovering from a writers’ strike that ended just four months ago,” Michael Cieply reports.

headline: V.C.s Lead Spin-Off of Boston Scientific Unit
abstract: Nearly two years in the making, TriVascular2, a developer of medical devices to treat aneurysms, on Monday said it will be spun off from Boston Scientific, with $65 million from previous and new investors to complete clinical development of its endovascular repair products.

headline: Yahoo to Shareholders: Google Is Better for Us Than Microsoft
abstract: In a letter to stockholders, Yahoo defends its recent decision to sign a search advertising partnership with Google and urges them to vote for the existing board of directors.

headline: Another Big Media Deal for Murdoch
abstract: Rupert Murdoch is seeking to tighten his already-imposing grip on American news media, striking a tentative agreement to buy his third New York-based paper, Newsday, for $580 million. As he nears completion of that deal, Mr. Murdoch appears likely to pose the first significant challenge to the media ownership rule that the Federal Communications Commission recently adopted.

headline: More to Wikis Than Wikipedia
abstract: If Wikipedia is the only wiki you’ve ever used, maybe it’s time for a wiki primer.

headline: Showtime Executive May Lead New TV Channel
abstract: Business Week: “A former top Showtime executive is expected to be named chief executive officer of a new pay TV channel and online service being created by three movie studios, a move seen as another slap in the face to CBS’s premium channel.”

headline: Telemar Dials Up $3.5 Billion Deal for Brasil Telecom
abstract: Telemar Participacoes, owner of Brazil’s largest telephone company, agreed to buy the parent of Brasil Telecom Participacoesor 5.86 billion reais ($3.5 billion), creating a carrier that controls almost two-thirds of the country’s land lines.

headline: Former Monster Executive Is Indicted
abstract: A former chief operating officer at Monster Worldwide, the job recruitment Web site, was indicted Wednesday on charges of securities fraud and conspiracy in connection with what prosecutors said was a scheme to backdate millions of dollars in employee stock option grants.

headline: Looking for a Deal, Microsoft Said to Feel Out Facebook
abstract: In the wake of its failed $47.5 billion takeover bid for Yahoo, Microsoft apparently sent a calling card to Facebook, the social networking site, to see if it might be up for a deal.

headline: CBS Axes ‘Secret Talents’ After One Episode
abstract: “The secret talents of celebrities will remain hidden. CBS is axing its new reality show ‘Secret Talents of the Stars’ after only one episode,” theAssociated Press reports. “The first airing Wednesday had former ‘Star Trek’ actor George Takei singing ‘On the Road Again.’ Only 4.6 million people tuned in — and thousands tuned away as the hour continued.”

headline: Schlumberger and First Energy Reach Deal for Saxon
abstract: Schlumberger, the world’s biggest oilfield contractor, and First Reserve, an energy-industry buyout fund, agreed to acquire Saxon Energy Services of Canada for about $582.1 million to expand in South America.

headline: Previewing the Earnings for CBS Corp.
abstract: Bloomberg: “CBS Corp., dethroned last month after five years as the most-watched U.S. television network, may report a drop in first-quarter sales tomorrow after viewers shunned reruns during a 100-day writers strike.”

headline: Pearlstine Leaves Private Equity for Bloomberg LP
abstract: After less than two years in the buyout business, Norman Pearlstine, the former editor in chief of Time Inc., is moving on.

headline: Rhino Resource to Tap Public Markets
abstract: Rhino Resource Partners, a coal producer, said Tuesday it expects to raise about $92 million from an initial public offering of 5 million common units, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Answers From Iraqi Women, Part IV
abstract: BAGHDAD — Welcome to Part 4 of a week-long Q&A with Iraq women. Today’s post features a question from a reader about women’s rights.

headline: Private Equity Bidders Vie for 3i’s Ambea
abstract: Merrill Lynch‘s private equity unit, French buyout firm PAI Partners and Britain’s Doughty Hanson are competing to buy Nordic health-care company Ambea for as much as 900 million euros ($1.4 billion), Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Wednesday Night Ratings Go to Fox
abstract: Fox’s “So You Think You Can Dance” earned Wednesday’s highest ratings, as an average of 9.3 million viewers tuned in to the show from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Upfronts: CBS Cancels ‘Moonlight,’ Renews ‘The Unit’ and Three Sitcoms
abstract: “Producers of ‘How I Met Your Mother,’ ‘The New Adventures of Old Christine,’ ‘Rules of Engagement’ and ‘The Unit’ can stop biting their nails” — CBS has renewed the four series, Variety reports.

headline: UBS To Announce Job Cuts, Report Says
abstract: Swiss bank UBS, Europe’s biggest casualty of the credit crisis, will announce plans for job cuts on Tuesday when it releases quarterly results, according to Reuters.

headline: Yahoo Makes New Pitch to Shareholders as Stock Drops Further
abstract: Yahoo once again makes the case to shareholders that its existing directors are better equipped to lead the company forward than an alternate slate proposed by Carl Icahn.

headline: Fox Renews ‘Terminator’
abstract: The Hollywood Reporter: “Fox has picked up ‘Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles’ for a second season. The network on Monday handed a 13-episode order to the sci-fi drama.” The series debuted on Fox in January.

headline: NextWave Could Raise Billions in Sale of Spectrum Assets
abstract: NextWave Wireless is looking to sell its vast holdings of licenses for U.S. airwaves, which are worth billions of dollars and could allow a new market entrant to create a nearly nationwide wireless network.

headline: Thousands Gather to Make Their Own Fair
abstract: Last weekend was the third annual Maker Faire, an eclectic gathering spun off from Make magazine, the voice of the DIY movement.

headline: I’m Not Ignoring You
abstract: David Pogue is not ignoring you.

headline: InBev’s Bid for Anheuser Turns Hostile
abstract: InBev, the brewery based in Belgium, has begun a hostile bid to take over the Anheuser-Busch Companies.

headline: Sun Capital’s Jevic Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Sun Capital Partners‘ Jevic Holding is seeking bankruptcy protection, as a nationwide decline in freight volumes has led the trucking company to look for a permanent rest stop.

headline: David E. Kelley Moves Studios
abstract: TV Week: After working at 20th Century Fox Television for 22 years, “Emmy Award-winning writer-producer David E. Kelley signed an exclusive three-year development and production deal with Warner Bros. Television,” the company announced Tuesday. Mr. Kelley most recently developed the new drama “Life on Mars.”

headline: Honeywell to Sell Unit for $1.05 Billion
abstract: Honeywell International said it would sell a unit that distributes aerospace fasteners and hardware to B/E Aerospace for $1.05 billion, at least $800 million of which would be in cash and the rest in B/E stock. The business, called Consumable Solutions, generated revenues of $524 million last year, Honeywell said in a press release.

headline: Limerick Said to Reap $15.2 Million from V.C.s
abstract: Limerick BioPharma, a life sciences start-up in stealth mode, has raised $11 million in venture funding and $4.2 million in debt, according to VentureWire.

headline: ‘CSI’ Star Petersen Returning For Ninth Season
abstract: After lengthy negotiations, “CSI” star William Petersen has signed a deal to return for the crime drama’s ninth season.

headline: Canada’s High Court Showdown
abstract: From Ian Austen, a DealBook colleague in Ottawa:

headline: A Short Seller Makes His Case Against Lehman
abstract: Lehman Brothers is clearly under pressure these days. Its stock is down nearly 50 percent for the year so far, and analysts widely expect it to report a loss for its second quarter. The firm has been forced to deny that its financial health is ailing, battered by too much debt and hampered by too little capital.

headline: Fortis Said to Get $630 Million From Russian Billionaire
abstract: Belgian-Dutch financial services group Fortis received $630 million in capital from Russian billionaire Suleiman Kerimov as part of its recent share issue, The Wall Street Journal said, citing people familiar with the matter.

headline: NBC Bypasses Apple to Stream TV Shows to the iPhone
abstract: NBC is experimenting with offering its TV shows free to iPhone users using streaming technology. This will allow NBC to make money from advertising and avoid selling downloads through Apple’s iTunes Store.

headline: Zuiker’s Strategy For Television and the Web
abstract: The Hollywood Reporter has a recap of Monday’s address by Anthony Zuiker, the creator of “CSI,” at the National Association of Broadcasters’ annual conference. Mr. Zuiker suggested a model for drawing viewers back to television that he called “Cross Blending Storytelling.”

headline: BofA Chief Says He’s Committed to Coutrywide Deal
abstract: The chief executive of Bank of America, Kenneth D. Lewis, said Wednesday he remains committed to buying Countrywide Financial, the giant money-losing mortgage lender.

headline: Brazilian Oil Company Seeks $3.37 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: The Brazilian billionaire Eike Batista is planning a 5.59 billion real ($3.37 billion) initial public offering of OGX Petroleo e Gas Participacoes, betting the country’s recent oil finds will lure investors who snubbed other offerings this year. Mr. Batista founded Rio de Janeiro-based OGX less than a year ago.

headline: Podcast: Security Agreements
abstract: Listen to Alissa J. Rubin and Richard A. Oppel discuss the security agreement debate

headline: JPMorgan Hunts Bear on the Open Market
abstract: JPMorgan Chase said it bought 11.5 million shares of Bear Stearns on the open market, in an effort to gain enough voting power to essentially guarantee its acquisition of the investment bank.

headline: Debating the CBS-CNET Deal
abstract: CBS executives said Thursday in a conference call that the company’s $1.8 billion acquisition of CNET Networks will keep it occupied for a while and would probably put an end to its recent Internet shopping spree.

headline: J. P. Morgan’s Stately Old Logo Returns
2 Accused of Insider Trading in Freescale Deal, Others
abstract: A former partner at Ernst & Young was charged with insider trading on Thursday, accused of tipping off a friend about pending deals involving the firm’s clients, including the $17.6 billion buyout of Freescale Semiconductor led by the Blackstone Group.

headline: SiBeam Adds $40 Million in New Funding
abstract: Wireless chip developer SiBeam stuck with longtime backers for the third time, on Monday, April 7, announcing that it closed a $40 million Series C round of funding to support commercial production of low-cost chips used to power high-bandwidth video transmission.

headline: Ratings: Young Viewers Join Fox In ‘Hell’
abstract: Singing, dancing and cooking topped the ratings on Tuesday as reality series on Fox and ABC garnered the most viewers on the night.

headline: Bush To Appear on ‘Deal or No Deal’
abstract: Reuters reports:

headline: Dinsey’s Steamboat to Raise $200 Million for New Fund, Report Says
abstract: Steamboat Ventures, the venture capital arm of The Walt Disney Company, is planning to raise a third fund, worth $200 million from its owner, PE Week reported.

headline: CBS, CNET and the Perils of Mergers
abstract: Is CBS Chief Executive Leslie Moonves making a big mistake?

headline: Platinum Equity Unloads PNA for About $300 Million
abstract: Platinum Equity has agreed to sell metal processor PNA Group Holding to larger rival Reliance Steel & Aluminum for more than $300 million.

headline: The Vision for Lifetime: ‘Contemporary, Vibrant, Aspirational’
abstract: Broadcasting & Cable and TV Week have full coverage of the cable channel Lifetime’s upfront presentation Monday. The channel acquired “Project Runway” last week, prompting a lawsuit by NBC Universal.

headline: Investors Offer $12.8 Billion to Run Penn. Turnpike
abstract: A consortium led by Citigroup and Spain’s Abertis Infraestructuras won the bidding war to run the Pennsylvania Turnpike with a $12.8 billion offer, Gov. Edward Rendell said on Monday.

headline: ‘Signal Moment’ In Broadcast TV Slump?
abstract: The double-digit declines of the 2007-08 broadcast season “may be no temporary hiccup.”

headline: More Bad News Surfaces on Meriwether Funds
abstract: Reports continue to surface that hedge-fund manager John Meriwether is letting investors exit his global macro fund after the roughly $300 million portfolio lost 14 percent this year.

headline: A Preview of Oxygen’s New Look
abstract: MediaPost: “NBC Universal will unveil a re-branding of the recently acquired Oxygen network at an upfront event” on Wednesday. “While details are still being worked out, the ‘Oh!’ moniker that the network turned to in its early, struggling stages will be history.”

headline: Microsoft Tops Tech’s Lobby Spenders
abstract: Microsoft is leading the tech industry’s charge up Capitol Hill, according to statistics released Monday.

headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

headline: Economy Hits U.S. PC Sales, but Notebook Growth Remains Strong
abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

headline: Amazon Gains Share of Shrinking Paid Music Market
abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

headline: Yahoo’s Starting Point: A Clearer Strategy
abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

headline: The Network That AT&T’s Growing Profits Will Buy
abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

headline: Clinton’s High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

headline: The iPhone Shortage
abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: Charges of Insider Trading for a Wall St. Luminary
abstract: John F. Marshall spent decades teaching at business schools and watching his students parlay his lessons into fortunes on Wall Street. But when he and another professor reached for some of those riches themselves, events took a startling turn, the authorities say.

headline: ‘Jazzing Up’ the Fourth Hour of ‘Today’
abstract: Felicia R. Lee reports:

headline: A Silicon Valley Slowdown
abstract: Housing prices in Silicon Valley remain defiantly high. New BMWs and Saabs cruise Highway 101. But, says The New York Times, for the first time there are signs that the current economic downturn is taking its toll on the country’s cradle of technology and innovation.

headline: Exxon Rejects Proposals Backed by Rockefellers
abstract: Exxon Mobil‘s chairman and chief executive, Rex W. Tillerson, defeated a shareholder effort on Wednesday to take away one of his jobs at an annual meeting punctuated by a debate of the company’s policy toward renewable energy and global warming.

headline: Ex-UBS Banker Pleads Guilty in Tax Evasion
abstract: One after another, the secrets spilled out. The millions stashed in Swiss bank accounts. The precious jewels and artwork whisked into hiding. The diamonds smuggled in a tube of toothpaste.

headline: Indonesia’s Adaro Has Biggest I.P.O. Since 1995
abstract: In Indonesia’s biggest initial share sale in over a decade, PT Adaro Energy has raised 12.25 trillion rupiah ($1.32 billion) to help fund acquisitions and pay debt.

headline: Upfront Wrap-Up: Speaking Profanglish
abstract: Here is a look back at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the upfront week, which ended on Thursday.

headline: Listening to Iraq’s Musicians
abstract: Video

headline: Analyst Predicts a $9 Billion Write-Down for Citi
abstract: Citigroup may incur second-quarter write-downs of $9 billion and raise additional capital, according to a Goldman Sachs analyst, who widened his loss estimate for the bank for the period.

headline: Power to the People
abstract: Iraqis have spoken about electricity during these five years and they got nothing, just each ministry blaming the other ministry for not doing its job.

headline: Replacing The Rabbit Ears As The Digital Broadcasting Deadline Nears
abstract: Here’s another hurdle for the switch to digital broadcasting: “discovered that over-the-air digital signals behave differently from analog signals.” Roy Furchgott reports:

headline: Despite Valley Optimism, a Disease Resists Cure
abstract: In Silicon Valley, an unshakable optimism holds that the right combination of money, brains and computing power can solve any problem.

headline: Airline Says Aloha
abstract: With no buyer and no cash, Aloha Airlines went under Tuesday.

headline: Prosecutors Said to Inquire About Bear Funds’ Bank Dealings
abstract: Prosecutors are looking into whether two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers, who were indicted last week on conspiracy and securities fraud charges for misleading investors, also broke the law in their dealings with banks, BusinessWeek reported.

headline: Hedge Funds Burned on Bradford & Bingley
abstract: London hedge fund giant GLG Partners and Tiger Global Management were among the hedge funds licking their wounds from their short positions in Bradford & Bingley, after details of a bid from financial services group Resolution sent shares in the U.K. mortgage lender up more than 10 percent, Financial News reported.

headline: Merrill Says It Doesn’t Need More Cash
abstract: Merrill Lynch‘s chief executive, John Thain, said the world’s biggest brokerage doesn’t need more funds from outside investors, after speculation that the company needed capital sent the shares down almost 15 percent this year.

headline: Bear Stearns’s New Hires Become Job Seekers
abstract: Thousands of people are losing their jobs on Wall Street – some before their first day of work.

headline: Verizon-Alltel and the March of Oligopoly
abstract: An analyst notes that were Verizon to buy Alltell, it would keep wireless prices high because there is even less competition among cellphone carriers.

headline: ‘Respectable Ratings’ for HBO’s ‘John Adams’
abstract: The miniseries “John Adams” delivered “respectable ratings” for HBO. Sunday’s finale “drew 1.6 million viewers, and ended up with a 2.2 million average for seven Sunday premieres,” USA Today notes.

headline: Lloyds TSB Said to Consider Bid for Deutsche Postbank
abstract: Lloyds TSB, the British bank, is in the early stages of considering a takeover bid for German lender Deutsche Postbank, The Telegraph reported, citing undisclosed sources. The potential offer underscores Lloyds’ “relative immunity to the write-downs that have scarred the balance sheets of its international rivals” and would be a shift from its focus on the domestic market, The Telegraph wrote.

headline: Obama and the Hedge Fund Factor
abstract: As Pennsylvania voters headed to the polls on Tuesday, Andrew Ross Sorkin of The New York Times looked at where hedge funds have been placing their political bets. While Senator John McCain, and perhaps to a lesser extent Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, might seem like the natural favorites for hedge fund managers, Senator Barack Obama has been getting contributions from many of the most highly paid hedge fund bosses — the kind that make a half a billion dollars a year.

headline: Trulli annoyed, or truly disappointed
abstract: It was not one of the main events of the Spanish Grand Prix today, but it is a significant look at how things can go wrong for teams amid the chaos of a race like today’s event outside Barcelona. While Ferrari just made all the right moves, other teams spun out of action or put themselves out action. Take Toyota’s final laps.

headline: Investors Criticize Société Générale Chief for Losses
abstract: They had been saving their anger ever since the trading scandal at the French bank Société Générale broke in January. On Tuesday, shareholders were given their first chance to challenge management on a loss of 4.9 billion euros or $7.1 billion – and there was no more holding back.

headline: Pioneer Southwest Energy Begins I.P.O.
abstract: Pioneer Southwest Energy Partners said Tuesday it began an initial public offering of 8.25 million common units representing limited partner interests.

headline: The Story of a Script and Vanishing Investors
abstract: Last September, when Sanjay Sanghoee set about turning his first novel into a Hollywood movie, the budding filmmaker had his pick of investors.

headline: Japan Bars Investment by British Hedge Fund
abstract: As expected, the Japanese government said Wednesday that it would block a British hedge fund from buying a larger stake in a power company, in a case that is being closely watched as a test of Japan’s openness to foreign capital.

headline: Core Competency Mothers
abstract: A series of blog posts on The Huffington Post documents the arrival of the “core competency” mother, who focuses on what she does best and outsources or ignores the rest.

headline: Did Goldman Overreach With Its Spac?
abstract: Goldman Sachs usually doesn’t have trouble taking its clients public.

headline: Sale or No Sale, Sundance Channel Sells Its Development Schedule
abstract: Although the Sundance Channel still will not comment on whether it is up for sale, its president, Larry Aidem, said at a breakfast with journalists on Wednesday that a sale would not affect the 12-year-old channel’s identity.

headline: Disney Reacquires North American Stores
abstract: The Walt Disney Company signed a deal on Thursday to reacquire its North American chain of stores for for an undisclosed amount from Children’s Place.

headline: Reruns Fuel TV Ratings
abstract: Reruns ruled the ratings once again on Monday as Fox and CBS finished first and second respectivelyfor the night over all.

headline: Moody’s President to Step Down
abstract: The Moody’s Corporation said Wednesday that Brian Clarkson would retire as president and chief operating officer of Moody’s Investors Service.

headline: Societe Generale Replaces Its Chief
abstract: Société Générale, the French bank that was rocked by a rogue trading scandal that cost it 4.9 billion euros or about $7.1 billion, said late Thursday that Daniel Bouton would step aside as chief executive but would remain non-executive chairman as part of a reorganization of its senior management structure.

headline: Stay At Home; Don’t Move
abstract: Today’s Conference Board consumer confidence report shows people climbing into their shells, even though there is a slight increase in the number of people who think business will get better in the next six months.

headline: BlackRock Is Preparing for Bigger Economic Slowdown
abstract: The president of BlackRock, the $1.4 billion asset manager which has emerged as one of the winners from the subprime mortgage and credit crisis, said on Tuesday that the firm is bracing for a “much bigger” global economic slowdown, but also that financial market declines have created some of the best buying opportunities ever for fixed-income money managers.

headline: George Carlin’s Televised Stage
abstract: George Carlin hosted 14 comedy specials on HBO, apparently more than any other comedian in the premium cable channel’s history.

headline: Battle Between TCI and J-Power Heats Up
abstract: The acrimonious battle between J-Power, one of Japan’s biggest energy producers, and The Children’s Investment Fund has escalated after J-Power published an open letter to shareholders.

headline: Upfronts: A Season of Time-Shifting
abstract: In the past television season, there has been a sharp increase in time-shifting, thanks to TiVos and other digital video recorders, streaming video on the Internet, and cable video on demand offerings.

headline: Pickens Donates $100 Million to Oklahoma State University
abstract: In the largest gift to a university from a living donor this year, Oklahoma State University is being given $100 million by the energy tycoon Boone Pickens, the university announced.

headline: K.K.R. and Apax Said to Eye RBS Insurance
abstract: A private-equity consortium is being formed to examine a possible offer for the insurance arm of Royal Bank of Scotland, put up for sale earlier this week, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Paying Money to Killers
abstract: As Andrew Kramer’s story from Mosul demonstrates for some Christian leaders in Iraq the price of keeping their community alive after the invasion was to pay money to killers, who would very likely use it to kill others.

headline: Bleeping The Fun Out Of Commercials
abstract: “Advertisers are winking at the contentious issue of content regulation by using bleeping sounds in commercials and video clips,” Stuart Elliott reports.

headline: Foreign Investors Pull Back on N.Y.C. Real Estate
abstract: The extraordinarily strong office market in Manhattan in recent years owed its vigor in part to the presence of foreign real estate investors. Now, however, many such investors, even those with deep pockets and a strong currency on their side, are waiting on the sidelines.

headline: TiVo Posts A First Quarter Profit
abstract: Associated Press: “Digital video recorder pioneer TiVo reported Wednesday that its first-quarter net income more than quadrupled as operating costs, most notably for marketing and research, declined.”

headline: JPMorgan’s Top Film Banker to Cede Post, Report Says
abstract: JPMorgan Chase veteran David Shaheen has been appointed to succeed film-finance icon John Miller as head of the blue-chip firm’s entertainment banking group, with Mr. Miller to segue into a consulting role in 2009, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

headline: Former Chief Tells Board That A.I.G. Is in a Crisis
abstract: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, says the company is in “crisis” and urged a delay in its annual general meeting, scheduled for Wednesday, in a letter to the board.

headline: For Public Hedge Fund and Private Equity Firms, Where the Upside?
abstract: Shareholders of publicly-traded hedge fund and buyout firms need to re-check their checklists, says Breakingviews. The downturn is highlighting the disadvantages of public scrutiny, with performance fees evaporating and new investment slowing, the publication said. But the supposed pluses – having a public currency to retain talent and grow – aren’t holding up their end of the bargain, either, it argues.

headline: Exchange Pays $625 Million For Creditex
abstract: Securities exchange IntercontinentalExchange has entered into an agreement to buy credit processor Creditex Group in a cash and stock deal valued at $625 million, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Networks Wrap ‘Upfront’ Sales on Upswing
abstract: Reuters reports:

headline: Sonus Phrmaceuticals to Merge With OncoGenex
abstract: Sonus Pharmaceuticals has found good use for its stash of cash – and perhaps a better shot at survival – by merging with British Columbia biotech firm OncoGenex Technologies.

headline: Rebuilding ‘Greensburg’
abstract: On May 4, 2007, an F5 tornado devastated the town of Greensburg, Kansas. Ninety-five percent of the town was wiped off the map and eleven people were killed.

headline: Cerberus to Raise Fund for Distressed Investing
abstract: Private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management is starting a new fund to invest in assets it thinks have been driven down too low by the credit crisis, the firm’s chairman, John Snow, told Reuters.

headline: Search for Missing Bayou Founder Continues
abstract: A manhunt continued on Thursday for Samuel Israel III, a hedge fund manager who disappeared Monday, hours before he was to have reported to prison to serve a 20-year federal sentence for conspiracy and fraud in a scheme to cheat investors out of $450 million.

headline: Upfronts: Some Consistency For ‘Scrubs’
abstract: Even Homer Simpson seems to think the sitcom “Scrubs” was treated poorly by NBC.

headline: Court Approves Review of Countrywide Practices
abstract: A federal judge has authorized an examination of the mortgage processing systems of the lending giant Countrywide Financial by bankruptcy investigators seeking evidence that the company systematically abuses borrowers.

headline: Dynegy, a Dark Horse Again?
abstract: For people outside the power industry, Dynegy may be best remembered as the company that made a daring bid to buy Enron as that energy giant spiraled toward bankruptcy.

headline: Time Warner Spin-Off Puts Spotlight Back on Content
abstract: In another era at Time Warner, before a star-crossed Internet merger, the hard-held belief of Gerald M. Levin, then the chief executive, was that “content is and will remain king, but distribution is the power behind the throne.”

headline: Warner Bros., CW Reach Weekday Deal
abstract: Broadcasting & Cable: “Warner Bros. Domestic Television Distribution will supply programming for The CW’s 3 p.m. to 5 p.m. weekday block, according to a pending deal between the corporate cousins.” The network will show “Judge Jeanine Pirro” (left) from 3 to 4, followed by a comedy block featuring “The Wayans Bros.” and “The Jamie Foxx Show.”

headline: Texas Oil Companies Consolidate
abstract: Smith International has agreed to acquire W-H Energy Services for $3.2 billion, The Daily Deal reported.

headline: Wall Street’s Fading Crush on G.E.
abstract: These days, it’s hard to find much love on the Street for General Electric, once the bluest of blue chips. Shares of the company, which makes everything from light bulbs to jet engines to movies, sank to a five-year low last week after one of the few remaining bulls on the stock finally threw in the towel.

headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

headline: Economy Hits U.S. PC Sales, but Notebook Growth Remains Strong
abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

headline: Amazon Gains Share of Shrinking Paid Music Market
abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

headline: Yahoo’s Starting Point: A Clearer Strategy
abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

headline: The Network That AT&T’s Growing Profits Will Buy
abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

headline: Clinton’s High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

headline: The iPhone Shortage
abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: Virgin Mobile Agrees to Buy Helio
abstract: Virgin Mobile USA said Friday that it has acquired fellow Helio, the U.S. cellphone service provider controlled by South Korea’s SK Telecom, for $39 million, in a widely expected move.

headline: Ratings: ‘CSI’ Returns To Bury ‘Fifth Grader’
abstract: The return of “CSI” to CBS on Thursday lifted the network far ahead of its competitors, as the 9 p.m. crime drama led the night’s ratings with 20.4 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: After 38 Years, ‘Soul Train’ Gets New Owner
abstract: People who think of “Soul Train” as an artifact from 1970s television may be surprised to learn that the 38-year-old song-and-dance show was never canceled. Although no new episodes are produced, it lives on in reruns that showcase the taste-making music, hairstyles and fashions of decades past.

headline: SPAC Window Slamming Shut, Report Says
abstract: Since the credit squeeze has brought the market for initial public offerings to a near standstill, special purpose acquisition companies have been the one bright spot in the landscape for new offerings.

headline: Four Buyouts of the Apocalypse: Clear Channel
abstract: Late Thursday afternoon, the banks financing the disputed buyout of Clear Channel Communications filed a motion for summary judgment in the New York case.

headline: CVC Capital Raises $2.1 Billion for New Asia Fund
abstract: CVC Capital Partners, the British private equity group, has raised $4.1 billion for its new Asia Pacific fund, the biggest sum raised for the region, reflecting rising investor interest in emerging market buyouts.

headline: Notes from a Wednesday in Bahrain
abstract: Got to Bahrain early this morning to find it absolutely pouring down in wind and sand. Can’t imagine how that will be on the cars over the weekend if it continues. (Engines don’t like sand.)

headline: Upfronts: For Oxygen, NBC Assigns Letter Grade to a Generation (Not ‘X’)
abstract: Let there be no doubt who NBC Universal wants watching the newly acquired Oxygen cable channel, the company has given them a name: “Generation O.”

headline: Previews of a Potential Cable Deal
abstract: Now that Time Warner Cable is to be spun off from parent company Time Warner, questions have emerged about what it will do with its newfound freedom. Richard Greenfield, an analyst at Pali Research, said in a report Tuesday that he thinks it may move to swallow a smaller rival.

headline: From the Gulf, Money for Towers in London
abstract: Some of the construction cranes rising over the City of London, the financial hub of Europe, bear the seal of sovereign riches. Not British riches – Middle Eastern ones.

headline: Mixed Signals In UBS Rights Issue
abstract: UBS has wrapped up a 16 billion franc ($15.4 billion) rights issue, the Swiss bank’s second effort to resuscitate finances that have been ravaged by the global markets crisis.

headline: Activist Investor Raises Stake in UBS
abstract: Activist investor Olivant has raised its stake in Swiss bank UBS to 2.5 percent and said on Wednesday it had fully supported the recent rights issue.

headline: Colorado Baggage and Gart Capital Pick Up Bag’n Baggage
abstract: Bag’n Baggage, a Dallas-based luggage retailer operating in bankruptcy, has been acquired for $10.5 million by a Denver-based competitor, Colorado Baggage Company, and private equity firm Gart Capital Partners.

headline: Yahoo’s Post-Microsoft Exodus
abstract: For more than two years, executives and other senior employees have been leaving Yahoo at a steady, persistent trickle.

headline: Buyout Shops Said to Circle Dave & Buster’s
abstract: The auction of Dave & Buster’s, a portfolio company of Wellspring Capital Management, has reached the second round, with roughly six bidders vying for the restaurant chain, The Deal.com reported.

headline: Time Warner Gives Details on Cable Spinoff
abstract: Time Warner and its cable television arm, Time Warner Cable, said Wednesday their boards have approved the companies’ legal separation, with Time Warner Cable expected to pay a hefty $10.9 billion one-time dividend to shareholders.

headline: Promoting Planet Green
abstract: Can the environment make for entertaining TV? Discovery Communications is about to find out.

headline: Canceled After a Single Episode: TV’s One-Show Wonders
abstract: Remember “South of Sunset” or “The Will?” Probably not — they were canceled after only one episode had aired.

headline: QBE Raises Insurance Australia Bid to $8.3 Billion
abstract: QBE Insurance Group raised its hostile bid for Insurance Australia Group for a second time, offering A$8.7 billion ($8.3 billion), Bloomberg News reported. The ongoing deal is Australia’s biggest insurance takeover.

headline: Clear Channel: Sketching a Settlement
abstract: The word is that the parties in the Clear Channel Communications dispute are negotiating a settlement that could involve a reduction of the purchase price from $39.20 to $36 per share. I’m surprised that they are doing so at this point, because of the small reduction in the consideration. It will be interesting to read the background of the settlement in the transactions documents. But in any settlement, here are a few of the issues that the parties need to address:

headline: Why Walter Bender Left One Laptop Per Child
abstract: Walter Bender left One Laptop Per Child in April and speaks out on Microsoft joining the effort. “Microsoft stepping in is the symptom, not the disease,” he said in the interview. The issue, in his view, is whether the tools that bring computing to children are “agnostic on learning” or “take a position on learning.” Mr. Bender said.

headline: China Merchants Bank Wins Auction for Wing Lung
abstract: China Merchants Bank, coming from behind in a three-month auction, has agreed to buy 53 percent of Wing Lung Bank, a family-controlled lender in Hong Kong. It will also offer to buy the rest of Wing Lung’s shares at the same price, valuing the bank at $4.66 billion.

headline: Bear’s Last Day on Earth
abstract: “You need to have a deal by Sunday night.”

headline: Readers Have Their Say in the E-Publishing Debate
abstract: Readers respond to the issue of releasing the books in David Pogue’s Missing Manual series in electronic form.

headline: A Tribute to Jim Gray: Sometimes Nice Guys Do Finish First
abstract: Jim Gray, a legendary computer scientist at Microsoft and I.B.M. who disappeared at sea in January 2007, was remembered by hundreds of friends and colleagues Saturday at a day-long tribute at UC Berkeley. An endowed professorship in computer science is being established in his honor.

headline: ‘Idol’ Viewers Set A Voting Record
abstract: The seventh season of “American Idol” recorded a record number of votes.

headline: Ross Goes East for Bank Purchases Financing
abstract: It’s no secret that Wilbur L. Ross is interested in buying up more financial assets. But Bloomberg News reported Wednesday that the billionaire investor is now seeking about $4 billion from investors — including sovereign wealth funds in the Middle East — to do just that.

headline: AOL’s Blame Game: The Guy We Fired Did It
abstract: The price of ads plummeted for AOL in the first quarter. Time Warner blames the head of its advertising unit who it fired in March. The good news is only 647,000 people canceled their AOL accounts in the quarter, a lower defection rate than it has had in a long time.

headline: Did Wendy’s Get Short-Changed?
abstract: The nearly two-and-a-half-year fight between Wendy’s International and Nelson Peltz appears to be over. Facing shareholder pressure and a possible proxy battle, the Wendy’s board agreed to merge their company with Mr. Peltz’s Triarc Companies, which runs the Arby’s restaurant chain.

headline: Illinois Tool Works to Add Enodis to its Belt
abstract: Illinois Tool Works, the manufacturer of Duo-Fast nail guns and Wilsonart countertops, agreed to buy Enodis for $2.1 billion, trumping a rival offer for the British catering-gear maker from Manitowoc.

headline: Brownstone Buyout Plan Meets Resistance
abstract: More than a century ago, Andrew Carnegie sought to create a massive mansion on Manhattan, staking out a then-undeveloped tract of the island.

headline: Bank of England to Provide Cash to U.K. Banks
abstract: The Bank of England said Monday that it would allow banks to swap mortgage-backed securities valued at about $100 billion for government bonds in an effort to restore calm to the British financial markets.

headline: The Warner Music Ends at Last.FM
abstract: Monday was the last day, so far, for users to listen to Red Hot Chili Peppers, Led Zeppelin and Diddy on CBS’s Last.FM. Warner Music, which publishes those acts and many more, cut off Last.FM because the companies couldn’t reach agreement on the terms for the on-demand listening service.

headline: Cadwalader Adds Two Buyout Lawyers
abstract: Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft seems to be using the lull in leveraged buyouts to bulk up its private equity team. The law firm on Wednesday said it hired two private equity partners, Stewart A. Kagan and Geoffrey W. Levin, both of whom will work out of New York.

headline: A-B’s Independent Directors Forego Their Own Advisers
abstract: As Anheuser-Busch‘s directors prepare for their first in-person board meeting since InBev unveiled its $46.4 billion takeover bid last week, the independent directors have decided against hiring outside advisers, people involved in the deliberations told DealBook.

headline: Patriot Risk Management Files for $115 Million I.P.O.
abstract: Patriot Risk Management, a workers’ compensation risk management firm, filed with U.S. regulators on Tuesday to raise up to $115 million in an initial public offering of common stock.

headline: Deutsche Bank Warns of $4 Billion Write-Down
abstract: Deutsche Bank said Tuesday that it expects first-quarter losses of $4 billion due to ”significantly more challenging” market conditions triggered by the U.S. subprime collapse.

headline: Deutsche Reshuffles Its Top Deal-Makers
abstract: Deutsche Bank‘s global co-head of mergers and acquisitions, Tony Burgess, has retired at the age of 48.

headline: Air One Ready to Fly Again with Alitalia Bid, Report Says
abstract: Air One is ready to renew its efforts to buy rival Alitalia, Bloomberg News said citing an unsourced report in newspaper Il Sole 24 Ore.

headline: Biz360 Raises $10 Million
abstract: Biz360, a market and media intelligence firm specializing in the Web, has raised $10 million Foundation Capital, along with past backers Granite Ventures and Scale Venture Partners.

headline: Romney Son Moves Into Private Equity
abstract: The Romney family may have stumbled recently in politics — but it appears to be betting again on private equity.

headline: ‘High School Musical 3’ Films in April
abstract: “The ‘High School Musical’ gang is returning to Utah this month for their senior year,” the Associated Press reports. “Unlike its predecessors, the third installment in the series will be filmed during the school year at East High School in Salt Lake City.”

headline: Compared to Other Liquids, Gasoline is Cheap
abstract: In five years of writing this blog, I’ve generally resisted passing along some of those great little tidbits that get passed around by e-mail—jokes, quotes, factoids, and stuff like that. Most of the sob stories are bogus, most of the jokes aren’t funny, and so on.

headline: Goldman Said to Cut M&A Bankers
abstract: Goldman Sachs laid off investment bankers last week as it reacts to slowing markets and a slump in merger activity, according to Reuters.

headline: And the Award for Best Deal-Maker Goes to …
abstract: Forget about Microsoft being a “disciplined” investor. Or Yahoo successfully defending itself. The best deal maker in the Microsoft-Yahoo saga is clearly Google.

headline: Reading the Signals at Sprint Nextel
abstract: Sprint Nextel has generated a lot of deal buzz this week. The wireless carrier just signed an agreement with Clearwire and a consortium of other companies to build a high-speed wireless Internet service. The deal came as two rumors were making the rounds: that Sprint might spin off or sell its beleaguered Nextel unit, or be bought by Deutsche Telekom, which operates the rival mobile service T-Mobile USA.

headline: Live from NBC’s ‘Infront': ‘We’re Doing Business Differently’
abstract: 1:46 p.m.: TV Decoder is at 30 Rockefeller Center on Wednesday afternoon, where NBC is holding an “Infront,” announcing its programming schedule more than a month ahead of the traditional “upfront” presentation where networks unveil upcoming shows.

headline: ABC’s Next Hot Show May Well Be…
abstract: Is “Life on Mars” the next hit on ABC?

headline: Lachlan Murdoch Scraps Australian Media Buyout
abstract: Australia’s Consolidated Media Holdings said a proposed A$3.3 billion ($3.1 billion) buyout offer from Rupert Murdoch’s son, Lachlan Murdoch, and Australian gaming tycoon James Packer, would not proceed because they failed to agree on terms.

headline: The Housewives Are Back
abstract: The return of “Desperate Housewives” lifted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday as 16 million viewers tuned in at 9 p.m. for the first new episode of the series since early January, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Despite delivering the series’ lowest ratings to date among adults 18 to 49, “Desperate Housewives” still easily led the night in that demographic.

headline: Take That, Google: No Ads From Apple
abstract: Apple is showing new ways for the iPhone to check news, sports and e-mail. But it appears to be willing to ask users to pay fees to do so rather than subsidizing content and services with advertising.

headline: Microsoft Said to Find Deal for Powerset
abstract: Microsoft has agreed to buy Silicon Valley semantic search engine Powerset, Venture Beat reported. The acquisition price is rumored to be slightly more than $100 million with an announcement expected in July.

headline: Leaving Baghdad
abstract: Ahmad Fadam was the head of the Iraqi staff in the newsroom of The New York Times in Baghdad. He left Baghdad in May to take up a visiting fellowship at the University of North Carolina. He will continue to contribute to the Baghdad Bureau blog from there.

headline: Samsung Chairman to Resign
abstract: Lee Kun Hee, Samsung Group‘s chairman, indicted on tax evasion charges, announced Tuesday that he would step down after 20 years of leadership, during which Samsung soared to become South Korea’s best-known global brand but was dogged by corruption scandals.

headline: Leveraged Planet
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: 2 Hedge Fund Titans Take Biggest Hits of Their Careers
abstract: Hedge-fund titans James H. Simons and Stephen Mandel are showing the biggest losses of their careers in the $1.9 trillion industry’s worst start in more than a decade, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Bronfman Says Warner Is Far from ‘Rocks’
abstract: Warner Music Group struck a minor chord with investors Thursday: The private-equity-backed company reported a wider loss for the second quarter — $37 million compared with $27 million during the same period of 2007 — and suspended its dividend in what it described as an effort to maintain “financial flexibility.”

headline: Sunday Ratings: Ten Million For ‘Oprah’s Big Give’ Finale
abstract: With its eighth and final episode of the season, “Oprah’s Big Give” earned a modest audience of 10 million viewers on Sunday, down from earlier this season but enough to help lift ABC to No. 1 on the night, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The reality charity competition has seen its ratings decline steadily after drawing 15.7 million viewers in its debut on March 2. Still, the finale managed to dominate its 8 p.m. time slot ahead of CBS’s “Big Brother” (6.8 million) and NBC’s “Monk” (5.7 million).

headline: A Fear of Big Demand for Corporate Loans
abstract: When times were sunny, banks promised scores of companies money for a rainy day. Now that day is here – and the banks, hard pressed themselves, are worried they will have to keep their promises.

headline: Bank of England Gains New Oversight Powers
abstract: The Bank of England announced a revamp of its leadership on Thursday as it was granted enhanced powers to manage financial crises in the biggest overhaul of Britain’s financial regulatory system in a decade.

headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

headline: Economy Hits U.S. PC Sales, but Notebook Growth Remains Strong
abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

headline: Amazon Gains Share of Shrinking Paid Music Market
abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

headline: Yahoo’s Starting Point: A Clearer Strategy
abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

headline: The Network That AT&T’s Growing Profits Will Buy
abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

headline: Clinton’s High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

headline: The iPhone Shortage
abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: Spammers Create a Tricky Situation for Stickam
abstract: Stickam, a live webcam chat site with more than two million members, says hackers broke into a message board system and made off with users’ e-mail addresses. Now those addresses are in the hands of spammers.

headline: In St. Louis, Inbev’s Bid Is a Tale of Clydesdales and Bud
abstract: InBev‘s $46 billion bid for Anheuser-Busch is stirring up some pride — and resistance — in the brewer’s home tome of St. Louis.

headline: Finding New Films For Showtime
abstract: With Paramount, MGM and Lionsgate joining forces on a new television network, the premium cable channel Showtime needs new film options.

headline: CSX Urges Shareholders Reject Dissident Slate
abstract: Having lost a court battle, CSX is still hoping to win the proxy war.

headline: Buffett Plans European Shopping Spree
abstract: Warren E. Buffett is about to make a whirlwind tour of Europe looking for large family companies that might want to become part of the $120 billion Berkshire Hathaway empire.

headline: Tom Cruise to Appear Again on ‘Oprah’
abstract: The Associated Press: “Oprah might want to nail down her furniture. Tom Cruise is scheduled to return to ‘The Oprah Winfrey Show,’ nearly three years after a couch-jumping appearance that spawned countless YouTube parodies and late-night jokes.”

headline: The Friends of ‘Gossip Girl’
abstract: In Sunday’s New York Times, Alessandra Stanley writes about the relationships on shows like “Gossip Girl,” a “semisatirical portrait of power and privilege in the private schools and penthouses of New York’s ultra rich.” Its first season finale will be shown on Monday.

headline: Microsoft Renews Pursuit of Yahoo
abstract: Two weeks after walking away from takeover talks with Yahoo, Microsoft made clear on Sunday that it still needed to create an Internet powerhouse that could rival Google – and that its interest in Yahoo had not waned.

headline: Softbank Seesks to Raise Stake in Oak Pacific
abstract: Softbank, the Japanese Internet services and telecommunications company, said Wednesday it hopes to boost its stake to 40 percent in a major Chinese Internet company for a total investment of 40 billion yen ($385 million), eyeing booming demand in the country.

headline: Veoh Raises An Extra $30 Million
abstract: Online video site Veoh has received a further $30 million in financing from such new backers as Intel and Adobe Systems.

headline: Nearly Locked Up, Clear Channel Deal Still Poses Questions
abstract: The revised buyout of Clear Channel Communications by Bain Capital and THL Partnersseems locked up, but questions remain over the stub equity and terms of the material adverse change clause, The Daily Deal reports.

headline: No Kidding
abstract: Moody’s said today that it might reduce the AAA ratings of MBIA and Ambac. The stocks of the insurance companies fell, so I guess somebody thinks this is important news.

headline: Web Start-Up a Joint Israeli-Palestinian Venture
abstract: Workers at G.ho.st, an Internet start-up in Ramallah, hold a weekly staff meeting – with colleagues on the other side of the Israeli-Palestinian divide. They trade ideas through a video hookup that connects the West Bank office with one in Israel in the first joint technology venture of its kind between Israelis and Palestinians.

headline: Is More Junk A Good Sign?
abstract: There seems to be a thawing in the junk bond market, which may be a sign that the credit crunch is easing a little.

headline: Google: We Like Yahoo, and We Like It Independent
abstract: Google executives answer (some) questions about the Yahoo-Microsoft meltdown at a meeting with reporters.

headline: Class-Action Lawyer Gets 5 Years in Bribery Case
abstract: Richard F. Scruggs, whose successful battle against the tobacco industry in the 1990s made him among the country’s best-known plaintiff’s lawyers, was sentenced on Friday to five years in prison for conspiring to bribe a judge over fees with other lawyers in his home state of Mississippi.

headline: Another Texas Buyout Showdown
abstract: Huntsman made the logical counter-attack in its fight with Apollo Management. It sued Leon Black, Joshua J. Harris and over a dozen other Apollo affiliated funds and entities in Texas for more than $3 billion.

headline: DirecTV Profit Up 10 Percent as Subscriptions Grow
abstract: Associated Press: “Satellite television company DirecTV said Wednesday its first-quarter earnings rose 10.4 percent, as it acquired more subscribers in the U.S. and Latin America and customers spent more on high-definition and video recording services.”

headline: Borders Jumps on Barnes & Noble Speculation
abstract: Borders, the bookstore chain put itself up for sale in March, saw its stock jump 9 percent on Wednesday as investors reacted to a report that Barnes & Noble was mulling a bid for its rival.

headline: For French Bank Chief, Questions From Lawmakers
abstract: If experience, as Oscar Wilde once wrote, is simply the name we give our mistakes, then the expertise that Daniel Bouton has gleaned over the last two-and-a-half months ought to place him among the leading authorities on detecting fraud and managing financial risk.

headline: Behind the Scenes of Bear’s Fund Meltdown
abstract: What were the managers of Bear Stearns‘ hedge funds thinking as the mortgage markets began to go haywire and investors started asking for their money back? Thursday’s indictments against those former managers, Ralph R. Cioffi and Matthew Tannin, offer some fascinating clues.

headline: Court Lets Funds Vote CSX Shares
abstract: Two hedge funds engaged in a proxy fight with CSX cannot be prevented from voting their shares in the railroad operator, a federal appeals court ruled on Friday. (Download the document here.)

headline: Carlyle’s Rubenstein Sees Uptick in Buyouts
abstract: Carlyle Group co-founder David Rubenstein suggested that private equity investment activity has hit a “bottom” and said he expects to see more deals close in the $2 billion to $4 billion range.

headline: The A.P. Asserts Tough (and Still Secret) View of Copyright on Blogs
abstract: In a fight with a social news site, The Associated Press has asserted that Internet sites cannot quote the headline and first paragraph of its articles. But so far, the news organization hasn’t articulated its own guidelines for its view of how Web sites can use its content.

headline: Germany’s Bayerische Writes Down $6.7 Billion
abstract: Bayerische Landesbank reported 4.3 billion euros ($6.7 billion) in write-downs from the subprime market collapse, double its previous estimate and the biggest of any German state bank.

headline: Chris Hansen’s Latest Sting Series
abstract: From the producers who brought you “To Catch A Predator”: it’s “To Catch A Shady Insurance Agent.”

headline: Norway’s Fund to Seek Larger Equity Deals
abstract: Norway’s $400 billion oil fund is close to owning more than 1 percent of the entire European stock market as it takes advantage of market turmoil to buy more equities, and has set up a division that will seek larger stakes in companies, similar to a private equity investor.

headline: For Smaller U.S. Banks, Risk Management Might Become Easier
abstract: The majority of U.S. banks would have the option to adopt alternative risk-based capital adequacy rules based on the Basel II accords, under a proposal agreed to by a top U.S. banking regulator, Reuters reported.

headline: UTC Chief Says Diebold Isn’t a ‘Must-Have’
abstract: United Technologies‘ new chief executive sent what appeared to be a show across Diebold‘s bow: Release your financial information, or the conglomerate will walk away from its $2.6 billion unsolicited offer.

headline: S.E.C. Fines Marvell $10 Million
abstract: The Marvell Technology Group, a maker of semiconductors, agreed on Thursday to pay a $10 million civil fine to settle regulators’ accusations of improper backdating of stock options.

headline: Le Mans is off and rolling
abstract: In three hours they will begin the 24 hour race of the year. It is not Formula One, no. But there has been a lot of crossover throughout the history of F1 and Le Mans, in engineers, drivers and even teams. I have put up my Le Mans preview and Le Mans/F1 comparison stories on the IHT special F1 page.

headline: Prudential Eyeing Equitable Fund
abstract: Prudential is among the parties eyeing Equitable Life‘s 7 billion pound with-profit fund, which is up for sale in what is expected to be the final restructuring of the troubled mutual, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Clean Mobile Raises $5.1 Million
abstract: Clean Mobile, a maker of fuel cell-powered drives for small vehicles, has raised a $5.1 million first-round of funding.

headline: Yahoo Rebuffs Microsoft Threat Over Bid
abstract: Responding to Microsoft‘s threat to lower the price of its buyout offer over the weekend, Yahoo said Monday that it continues to believe that Microsoft’s takeover bid is too low, as do many of its shareholders. Yahoo also countered Microsoft’s assertions that its business has deteriorated since Microsoft made its unsolicited bid on January 31.

headline: Yahoo’s New Pitch to Shareholders
abstract: From our colleagues at Bits:

headline: Blu-ray: Do Consumers Care?
abstract: The success of Blu-ray will depend on whether most people can even see the difference between a high definition DVD image and a standard definition one. Meanwhile, Netflix, the online DVD rental company, believes that enough consumers see sufficient incremental value in Blu-ray, that they will be willing to pay more for it.

headline: Behind the Catfight Over ‘Runway’
abstract: How significant is “Project Runway’s” move from Bravo to Lifetime? Add it up:

headline: Grey Wolf Pounces on Basic Energy
abstract: Grey Wolf, a natural-gas drilling services provider, said Monday it would acquire oil and gas well-services company Basic Energy Services in a $1.4 billion deal.

headline: UBS Said to Discourage Private Bankers From U.S. Visits
abstract: UBS has told members of its former private banking team responsible for rich US clients not to travel to America, The Financial Times reported, citing unnamed sources.

headline: Tideway Awash in Fresh Funding
abstract: Applications monitoring software maker Tideway Systems announced Tuesday that it raised $27 million in a Series C round, bringing total investment in the six-year-old company to $37.5 million and setting it on course for a planned public offering within 18 months.

headline: Quickoffice Scores $3 Million
abstract: Quickoffice, a company that makes mobile office document software for smart phones, has raised $3 million to help it expands at a time when users are expected to start using their phones for more tasks.

headline: HBOS May Seek to Raise as Much as $7.9 Billion, Reports Say
abstract: HBOS‘s board will meet on Monday to discuss a possible 4 billion pound ($7.9 billion) rights issue ahead of the British banking group’s annual investor meeting on Tuesday, according to British press reports.

headline: Doubts Greet Treasury Plan Regulation
abstract: As Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. laid out an ambitious plan to overhaul the regulatory apparatus that oversees the nation’s financial system on Monday, lawmakers and lobbyists from an array of industries opposed to the plan predicted that most of it would be dead on arrival.

headline: Sharing an Office, With a Puppy
abstract: A report from Week One of a home office share with a puppy.

headline: Eight Questions for Steve Jobs
abstract: What to watch for at the Apple event today: The iPhone’s new features, of course, but also clues to Apple’s business deals with carriers and longer-term plans.

headline: One Place the Candidates Won’t Be: ESPN
abstract: Via the sib-blog The Caucus: Though Barack Obama has a penchant for pick-up basketball games, the presidential candidate won’t get to talk about his moves on ESPN, the self-proclaimed “worldwide leader in sports” — at least not yet.

headline: For Bob Barker, an Applauding Throng Is a Familiar Comfort
abstract: LAS VEGAS — Hand Bob Barker a microphone, and Bob Barker immediately comes out of retirement.

headline: J.P. Morgan Said to Withdraw Bear Job Offers
abstract: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Iliad Chatting Up Telecom Italia’s Alice
abstract: Iliad, the parent of French internet service provider Free, on Monday confirmed it is in exclusive talks to buy Telecom Italia‘s Alice France ISP unit. The discussions are based on an enterprise value for Alice France of up to $1.25 billion, Iliad said.

headline: O’Reilly to Buy CSK for $1 Billion
abstract: O’Reilly Automotive, the third-biggest U.S. auto-parts chain, agreed to buy CSK Auto for more than $1 billion after a yearlong attempt to take over the Phoenix-based retailer.

headline: Honeywell to Buy Safety-Equipment Maker for $1.2 Billion
abstract: Honeywell International said Friday that it would buy Norcross Safety Products for $1.2 billion to expand its line of personal protective gear.

headline: Ford Says Kerkorian’s Investment Is a Sign of Confidence
abstract: After waging bitter battles with management at Chrysler and General Motors, the financier Kirk Kerkorian is off to a more peaceful start as a major shareholder in the Ford Motor Company.

headline: CNN’s Richard Quest Arraigned for Drug Possession
abstract: Sib-blog City Room reports: “Richard Quest, a reporter and business travel specialist for CNN International, is being arraigned today on a misdemeanor charge of drug possession after the authorities said he was found with methamphetamine in Central Park.” Mr. Quest is a high-profile correspondent for CNN International, known for feature reports and profiles.

headline: Finding Fun In The ‘Hate Mail’ Folder
abstract: “You weak knee liberals never cease to amase me,” the e-mail message from “Armand” read, spelling errors intact. “I’m glad we had a few democrats with some guts when we needed them but that type of democrat has passed on and all we have left is a bunch of cowards.”

headline: The Future of Tender Offer Regulation
abstract: Last month, the Georgetown Law School brought together financial and legal professionals, regulators and academics to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the Williams Act, at an event called “The History and Future of U.S. and Global Takeover Regulation: The Williams Act 40 Years On.”

headline: Despite Gloomy Conditions, Private Equity Firms Book Gains
abstract: A few deals over the past week have thrown a wrench into the theory that, with tumbling valuations and debt financing hard to come by, private equity firms would forced to hold off selling portfolio companies or face booking lowers profits on their investments.

headline: Treasury Secretary Requests Greater Powers for the Federal Reserve
abstract: The Bush administration said Thursday that the Federal Reserve should be given sweeping new powers to protect the integrity of the financial system, contending that this year’s market turmoil had exposed a badly outdated regulatory system.

headline: Apollo Finds Exit From Hughes in Spac Deal
abstract: Apollo Management is selling Hughes Telematics, which makes automotive information systems, to Polaris Acquisition Corporation, a special-purpose acquisition company formed by two financiers who have advised Apollo on prior investments.

headline: ‘Idol’ Finale Matches Last Year’s Ratings
abstract: The Hollywood Reporter has the early Nielsen numbers: “The ‘American Idol’ seventh season finale Wednesday night managed to essentially match last year’s performance, with the coronation of David Cook watched by an estimated 31.7 million viewers. Last year, slightly fewer viewers — 30.8 million — tuned in to watch Jordin Sparks win Fox’s singing competition.”

headline: Citi Raises $500 Million to Dig Into India
abstract: Citigroup has raised $500 million to invest in India’s roads, ports and utilities for a $5 billion infrastructure fund with the Blackstone Group, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

headline: Economy Hits U.S. PC Sales, but Notebook Growth Remains Strong
abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

headline: Amazon Gains Share of Shrinking Paid Music Market
abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

headline: Yahoo’s Starting Point: A Clearer Strategy
abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

headline: The Network That AT&T’s Growing Profits Will Buy
abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

headline: Clinton’s High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

headline: The iPhone Shortage
abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: Goldman’s Growing Question Mark
abstract: What’s a mortgage worth? Increasingly, the answer to that question is “who knows?” — even for Goldman Sachs, an investment bank that has stood out for its smart moves in the recent subprime mess.

headline: Laura Bush to Guest Host on ‘Today’
abstract: “First lady Laura Bush will be ‘guest host’ for an hour of NBC’s ‘Today’ show next week,” the Associated Press reports. She will help host the 9 a.m. hour on April 22. “Mrs. Bush will participate in several segments and interviews, NBC said Tuesday. She will be joined earlier in the broadcast by her daughter Jenna to talk about their new children’s book, ‘Read All About It!'”

headline: Time Warner Cable to Offer Web to TV Link
abstract: Reuters reports:

headline: The Stalking of Sourcefire
abstract: Sourcefire, a network security company, has had a rough go of it on the Nasdaq since going public in March. Now, private-equity-backed Barracuda wants to end its run.

headline: Country Music Awards Rate Well for CMT
abstract: The Associated Press reports: “More than 9.1 million viewers tuned in for the premiere and repeat telecasts of this week’s Country Music Television awards. The show hosted by “Hannah Montana” star Miley Cyrus and her father Billy Ray Cyrus scored a 1.27 rating among viewers 18-to-49 for the live broadcast. That’s up 35 percent from last year.”

headline: National City Considers Deal With KeyCorp, Report Says
abstract: National City, which has been battered by the housing downturn, is considering a plan to sell itself to rival KeyCorp, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Newsday: The Sale That Isn’t a Sale
abstract: Is the Tribune Company dodging the tax man? Not quite, but the newspaper company seems to be doing its best to avoid paying Uncle Sam a piece of the proceeds from the potential sale — or non-sale, if you happen to be a representative from the Internal Revenue Service — of Newsday.

headline: Memorable U.S. Open, Memorable Ratings
abstract: Thank you, Tiger Woods and Rocco Mediate.

headline: Hedge Funds Results Take a Beating in 2007
abstract: Hedge funds around the world became more cautious, reducing the amount of debt they took on to buy assets by the end of last year as returns took a beating from turmoil in global credit markets, according to a study released on Monday by Greenwich Associates.

headline: ‘Idol Gives Back,’ But Gives Up Viewers
abstract: The second annual “Idol Gives Back” telethon lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Wednesday, but far fewer viewers tuned in this year than last year to the celebrity-studded charity drive. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the prime time portion of the “American Idol” special, which began its broadcast at 7:30 p.m., attracted 17.6 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m.

headline: I’m In Like With You Pulls in $1.5 Million Round
