abstract: Social-network-turned-gaming-site I’m In Like With You has raised $1.5 million of venture funding led by Spark Capital, CNet News reported.

headline: Government Seeks to Buy Student Loans
abstract: The Bush administration is proposing that Congress authorize it to buy billions of dollars in federal student loans to make sure the nation’s credit crunch does not block borrowing for higher education.

headline: Exxon’s Texas-Size War Chest
abstract: The oil industry is known to be very conservative. And Exxon Mobil, the world’s largest publicly traded oil company, may be the most conservative of the bunch. It refuses to invest in projects that would lower its industry-leading return on capital employed, which is now around 35 percent. Rather than use its phenomenal cash flow for huge, dilutive acquisitions, it prefers to spend billions of dollars to buy back its own stock.

headline: Bear Stearns Merchant Banking to Be Spun Off
abstract: Bear Stearns‘ private-equity arm Bear Stearns Merchant Banking is expected to announce today that it will spin off into an independent company with JPMorgan Chase as its largest investor, The Wall Street Journal said.

headline: MySpace Will Host ‘America’s Got Talent’ Auditions
abstract: MySpace has long been known as a home for musicians and other performers, who use the site as a way to reach fans. Now they’re going to reach a different audience: the judges of “America’s Got Talent.”

headline: J. C. Flowers Bids for Stake in Germany’s Hypo
abstract: J. C. Flowers, the private equity firm, on Friday unveiled a 1.1 billion euros ($1.7 billion) offer for a stake in German subprime-hit investment bank Hypo Real Estate.

headline: Japan’s Daiichi Coughs Up $4.6 Billion for Ranbaxy
abstract: Japanese drug maker Daiichi Sankyo moved to take majority control of India’s biggest drug maker Ranbaxy Laboratories in a friendly deal worth up to $4.6 billion.

headline: Pa. Primary: Networks Look Ahead Two Weeks, ‘Same Place, Same Station’
abstract: A graphic on MSNBC, appearing for the first time on Tuesday, foreshadowed the results of the Pennsylvania primary.

headline: Canadian Court Hears Bell Canada Appeal
abstract: The Supreme Court of Canada reserved judgment Tuesday on whether to approve the $51.8 billion leveraged buyout of Bell Canada, the country’s largest telecommunications company.

headline: Shackleton Buys 3i Stakes
abstract: Shackleton Ventures, a firm that buys investments from other private equity groups, will this week announce it has bought 13 stakes in small companies from 3i in the first investment by its second fund, according to The Financial Times.

headline: TPG Invests in Troubled British Lender
abstract: TPG has agreed to take a 23 percent stake in Bradford & Bingley, the troubled British mortgage lender, for 179 million pounds ($353 million). Bradford & Bingley also said Monday that it slashed the price of a proposed rights offerings; its stock plunged as much as 32 percent.

headline: Coming Soon To Your PC: More Commercial Breaks
abstract: One of the most appealing attributes of online television viewing is the advertisements — actually, the lack of them. On the Web, commercial breaks usually last for 30 seconds, compared to two minutes or more on TV.

headline: Anheuser’s Staggering Defense
abstract: InBev on Thursday filed suit in Delaware Chancery Court against its resisting target, Anheuser-Busch. The Brazilian-Belgian brewer is seeking a judicial declaration that the five Anheuser directors elected when Anheuser’s board was staggered are eligible for removal without cause.

headline: Blackstone Taps Merrill’s Tosi as C.F.O.
abstract: The Blackstone Group has hired Merrill Lynch‘s former chief operating officer to be its chief financial officer. After 14 years with the buyout shop, Michael Puglisi will step down to make way for Laurence Tosi, who spent nine years at Merrill.

headline: Upfronts: Live-blogging the ABC Upfront
abstract: 5:10: ABC concluded with a preview of the “Lost” season finale. Mr. McPherson jokingly thanked the CW for sponsoring the after-party. (The CW will hold its upfront nearby starting very soon.)

headline: Blockbuster Said to Seek Stake in Viacom-MGM Venture
abstract: Blockbuster is in talks about taking a stake in the new premium TV channel to be launched by Viacom with Lions Gate Entertainment and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Want to Buy an iPhone? Wait a Few Weeks
abstract: If you’re in the market for a new iPhone, hold off a few weeks. All the signs suggest that significant upgrades are coming in June.

headline: Financials Hit New Low
abstract: Financial stocks bounced off their lows in March, after the Fed bailed out the creditors of Bear Stearns. That was taken as a sign that the Fed would prevent disaster.

headline: Zalaznick Adds iVillage to Portfolio
abstract: TV Week: “Lauren Zalaznick has been named president of NBC Universal Women and Lifestyle Networks, adding iVillage.com to a portfolio that already including Bravo Media and Oxygen Media.” Also: “Ms. Zalaznick said she is launching Women@NBCU, a content and marketing initiative that will allow advertisers to reach young, upscale women through a collection of NBC Universal brands.”

headline: Morgan Stanley Directors Expected to Win Re-Election
abstract: Despite shareholder fury over Morgan Stanley‘s fourth-quarter loss, John J. Mack and 10 other directors are set to win re-election to the firm’s board, Bloomberg News reported Tuesday citing an unnamed source.

headline: Staples Wins Corporate Express for $2.65 Billion
abstract: Staples, the office goods supplier, won approval from Corporate Express on Wednesday to take over the Dutch firm with a sweetened 1.7 billion euro ($2.65 billion) bid.

headline: Spitzer 2.0: A Vulture Investor?
abstract: Eliot L. Spitzer appears to have gone from attack dog to vulture.

headline: A Lawyer With 2 Clients at Large
abstract: From our colleagues at City Room:

headline: Sergey Brin’s $5 Million Space Adventure
abstract: Google co-founder Sergey Brin has invested $5 million in Space Adventures, a Virginia outfit that books flights for the well-heeled on Russian Soyuz rockets.

headline: K.K.R. to Get a Little Greener
abstract: Is private equity going green?

headline: Venture Capitalists Look Into the Light
abstract: Venture capitalists have taken a shine to Silicon Valley makers of LEDs and other bright lights, a report from the Cleantech Group has found.

headline: Australia Dismisses Report of Block on Chinese Buying Spree
abstract: Australia said on Sunday no Chinese companies have been told to withdraw applications to buy into Australian resource firms, despite media reports Canberra was pressuring China to back away from such investment.

headline: Comcast to Buy Plaxo to Boost Video Sharing
abstract: From our colleague Vindu Goel at Bits:

headline: Screen Actors Guild Says Contract Talks May Extend Into July
abstract: Associated Press: “The Screen Actors Guild said Thursday that talks with Hollywood studios could extend past the end of the current contract on June 30, but was willing to keep actors working without a deal.”

headline: A Way for Businesses to Respond to Fans — and Critics
abstract: Yelp.com, an established Web site on which real people review businesses, is now letting businesses talk back.

headline: For New York Developer, a Shift at the Top
abstract: Less than three weeks after Macklowe Properties was forced to sell its trophy General Motors Building and three other Midtown Manhattan office towers to pay off its creditors, William S. Macklowe has replaced his father, Harry, as chairman and chief executive of the vastly diminished real estate portfolio, the company announced Thursday.

headline: A Big Win for Citigroup in Parmalat Suit
abstract: Citigroup has won the dismissal of much of a multibillion-dollar New Jersey lawsuit over its alleged role in the 2003 collapse of Parmalat , the Italian food company.

headline: Lifetime Announces Acquisition of ‘Project Runway;’ NBC Files Suit
abstract: “NBC Universal, the parent company of Bravo network, has gone to court to try to keep ‘Project Runway,’ one of the biggest hits in cable television, from moving to Lifetime this fall,” Bill Carter reports.

headline: Go karting in Spain
abstract: As happens every year, Formula One journalists get together Friday evening at the Spanish Grand Prix to race go karts against each other at the Bridgestone karting race to see just how far off their abilities are from the pros they write about. Although the event is open only to journalists, a number of Formula One drivers have become part time journalists after their F1 career is over. That means that drivers such as Marc Surer and Bas Leinders take part in the event. Surprise, surprise, this year the teams of those two drivers came in first and second place in the race. Oh yes, and Autosport came in third. My team came in a poor ninth.

headline: BNP Paribas in Talks for BofA’s Prime Brokerage Unit, Report Says
abstract: BNP Paribas is in advanced talks to buy the equities prime brokerage unit of Bank of America in a move that would boost the French group’s presence in the U.S. and enable its U.S. rival to scale down its investment banking business, The Financial Times.

headline: France Telecom Bids $42 Billion for TeliaSonera
abstract: France Telecom on Thursday offered $42 billion in cash and stock for TeliaSonera, the Swedish-Finnish phone company with holdings across the former Soviet Union and Turkey, in the latest bid by a European wireless operator for a bigger foothold in emerging markets.

headline: Tribune Sells Conn. Real Estate for $30 Million
abstract: The Tribune Company has sold real estate it owned in Stamford and Greenwich, Conn., for $30 million, it was disclosed Wednesday.

headline: Ron Kuby To Join Air America Radio
abstract: Ron Kuby, the liberal-leaning, sometime television analyst who lost his job as co-host of a talk show on WABC radio in New York City at least partly to make room for Don Imus, will return to radio on Monday, on the Air America network.

headline: Banks Seek to Dismiss Clear Channel’s Texas Suit
abstract: The six banks led by Citigroup that are being sued by Clear Channel Communications and its buyers argued in a court filing Wednesday that a lawsuit against them should be dismissed and a temporary restraining order lifted. (Read the filings as a PDF here.)

headline: Moody’s Drops Merrill Deal
abstract: My column today deals with an amazingly bad mortgage securitization underwritten by Merrill Lynch a year ago.

headline: CBS to Pay $1.8 Billion for CNET Networks
abstract: CBS said Thursday it would buy CNET Networks for $1.8 billion in cash, marking its biggest online acquisition since hiring Quincy Smith, a former media and technology investment banker, to lead its interactive unit in late 2006. The deal came as CNET, whose assets include a popular technology-news Web site, was trying to fend off a group of activist investors seeking to take control of its board of directors.

headline: With Bold Steps, Fed Chief Quiets Some Criticism
abstract: Over a frantic weekend in mid-March, Ben S. Bernanke rewrote the rule book as chairman of the Federal Reserve. Like a military commander applying overwhelming force, he took steps then and over the next two months that some at the central bank are now calling the Bernanke Doctrine.

headline: What’s It Worth: Using the Web to Appraise the Price of Everything
abstract: A startup, Ztail, has devised a way to appraise everything – even the junk in your basement

headline: Shipping Costs Soar, Again
abstract: The most interesting economic argument now going on is not the one over whether there is or is not a recession. (I think it started sometime around November or December.) Instead, it is the debate over inflation and the threat it poses.

headline: Advent International Raises $10.4 Billion
abstract: Advent International raised $10.4 billion for its sixth and biggest private equity fund amid a dearth of leveraged buyouts.

headline: Apollo May Put Linens ‘n Things into Bankruptcy, Report Says
abstract: Leon Black’s buyout firm, Apollo Management, is considering the idea of a “pre-packaged” bankruptcy plan for ailing home furnishings retailer Linens ‘n Things, The New York Post reported.

headline: CBS And Yahoo In Web Video Sharing Deal
abstract: “CBS Corp. said on Wednesday it reached a deal to allow its Web videos to be carried by Yahoo Inc., part of a broader plan by the media company to add new outlets for its television shows.”

headline: Scenes from a Burial
abstract: To paraphrase T.S. Eliot, this is the way the firm ends: Not with a bang, but a vote.

headline: ExxonMobil Resumes Its PBS Sponsorship
abstract: After a four year absence, ExxonMobil will resume sponsorships of PBS programs this month, the public broadcaster announced Tuesday.

headline: Canada’s Viterra Seeks $400 Million in Share Sale
abstract: Viterra said Monday it has signed a deal to raise 400 million Canadian dollars ($397 million) in an offering of common shares to help fund growth.

headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

headline: Economy Hits U.S. PC Sales, but Notebook Growth Remains Strong
abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

headline: Amazon Gains Share of Shrinking Paid Music Market
abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

headline: Yahoo’s Starting Point: A Clearer Strategy
abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

headline: The Network That AT&T’s Growing Profits Will Buy
abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

headline: Clinton’s High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

headline: The iPhone Shortage
abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: Goldman Chief Says ‘Say on Pay’ Would Be Damaging
abstract: Goldman Sachs‘s chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, who received about $70 million of compensation last year by some counts, said on Thursday that shareholder votes on executive pay would constrain the board and hurt the investment bank’s ability to attract the best employees.

headline: Ex-Amaranth Trader Makes Good, Possibly
abstract: Has Brian Hunter gotten his spark back? Or did he just stumble onto a gusher?

headline: Diller, Malone Said to Restart Talks on IAC Breakup
abstract: Barry Diller and John C. Malone appear to be on speaking terms again.

headline: DreamWorks Said to Seek Deal for Independence
abstract: Steven Spielberg’s DreamWorks SKG film studio may soon get a lift from Bollywood.

headline: Lehman Shares Climb Back to Neutral
abstract: It may be difficult to tell from this stock chart, but Lehman Brothers‘ stock has actually improved from earlier this morning.

headline: Reliance Said to Consider Buyout Partners in MTN Bid
abstract: Anil Ambani, the billionaire Indian industrialist, is considering linking up with private equity groups on his bid to gain a powerful foothold in South African mobile operator MTN, The Financial Times reported citing unnamed sources close to the matter.

headline: A Security Concern Over ID Card Deal
abstract: L-1 Identity Solutions, which is battling for control of Digimarc, is raising questions about whether rival bidder Safran would be prevented from buying Digimarc by United States authorities because the French government owns a 30 percent interest in the company.

headline: After Deal Dies, What Now for Yahoo?
abstract: Yahoo‘s chief executive, Jerry Yang, and his team, were reportedly exchanging high-fives when they learned of Microsoft‘s decision to withdraw its offer to buy Yahoo for $33 a share, or approximately $47.5 billion.

headline: Pregnant Man Boosts Ratings for Oprah
abstract: Broadcasting & Cable reports: Oprah Winfrey’s April 3 interview with Thomas Beatie, the so-called pregnant man, helped “The Oprah Winfrey Show” gain “45 percent from the prior week to hit a 7.1 live-plus-same-day national household rating, according to Nielsen Media Research. Comparatively, the rest of Oprah’s four shows averaged a 5.5″ last week.

headline: Icahn’s Proxy Fights: A Scorecard
abstract: “I’m the guy in school that the other guys go to and say ‘Beat that guy up.'” — Carl Icahn

headline: Echo Logistics Files for $100 Million I.P.O.
abstract: Echo Global Logistics filed Wednesday to raise as much as $100 million in an initial public offering.

headline: Market Gloom Hangs Over Tulane Confab
abstract: As he finished up his opening presentation at Tulane’s Corporate Law Institute conference on Thursday, Mark Shafir, Lehman Brothers‘ head of mergers and acquisitions, called out a fellow banking bigwig, Robert Kindler. “I want to kill him,” he declared.

headline: ‘Entertainment Tonight’ In HD Soon
abstract: Broadcasting & Cable: “CBS’ Entertainment Tonight and The Insider will make the leap to HD come September, making them the first two entertainment newsmagazines to announce such a move.”

headline: Frank Rich to Be Consultant for HBO
abstract: “Frank Rich, an Op-Ed columnist for The New York Times, has signed on with HBO as a creative consultant to help develop new programming, while still writing his weekly column,” Richard Perez-Pena reports.

headline: Now You Tell Us: Improving Disclosure
abstract: The sudden subprime blow-ups, which came years after Regulation FD was put in place, show that fair disclosure isn’t the same as full disclosure, Louis M. Thompson Jr. wrote in a column for Compliance Week. “Investors lacked much-needed information about the risks involved in investing in collateralized debt obligations (CDOs) that constituted packaged sub-prime mortgages,” he wrote.

headline: Upfronts: Your Vote on the CBS Schedule
abstract: Of the five series that will join the CBS schedule in the fall, which one sounds the most promising?

headline: HSBC Says 1Q Profit Up Despite $3.2 Billion Write-Down
abstract: HSBC Holdings said Monday that its first-quarter profit was ahead of the equivalent period a year ago as higher profits in Asia, the Middle East and Latin America helped offset rising bad-debt charges in the U.S. and a write-down at its investment banking arm.

headline: Corel Hires Advisers to Examine Vector Bid
abstract: Corel, which makes graphics and publishing software, said Monday that it has hired a financial adviser, Genuity Capital Markets, to review last month’s unsolicited buyout bid its majority shareholder, private equity firm Vector Capital.

headline: The Ever-Rising Cost of Cable
abstract: Cable prices keep rising, and customers keep paying, Matt Richtel reported in Saturday’s New York Times.

headline: CNBC Video: A Rough Quarter for Hedge Funds
abstract: So far, 2008 has played havoc with nearly every sector of the economy, from housing to retail to banks. But what about the so-called “smart money” — that is, hedge funds? Such investors are supposed to make better decisions in times of turmoil, justifying their sometimes eye-popping income statements.

headline: Landry’s Agrees to Buyout by Founder
abstract: The founder and chief executive of the Landry’s Restaurants chain, Tilman Fertitta, has reached an agreement with his board to take the company private for about $415 million, pending shareholder approval.

headline: Russia’s Severstal Makes a Play for Esmark
abstract: Russian metals and mining company Severstal offered Tuesday to buy Esmark for $17 per share in cash, claiming it has the critical support of the United Steelworkers union.

headline: Posting Loss, Marsh to Sell Kroll Units
abstract: Marsh & McLennan, which runs one of the world’s largest insurance brokerage companies, posted a first-quarter loss on Wednesday after it wrote down the value of its Kroll corporate security unit by $425 million.

headline: Bezos Backs Kongregate With $3 Million
abstract: Billionaire investor Jeff Bezos is putting $3 million behind San Francisco-based Kongregate, an online casual games site that draws its content from independent developers, the Red Herring reported.

headline: Smucker Shines to Folgers’ Crystals
abstract: J.M. Smucker Company said Wednesday it would buy the Folgers coffee business from Procter & Gamble in a stock deal it valued at about $3.3 billion, including the assumption of about $350 million of Folgers debt.

headline: Another Night, Another Fox/CBS Ratings Slugfest
abstract: A two-hour edition of “So You Think You Can Dance” lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Wednesday, with 8.8 million viewers tuning in from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Motorola Ponies Up for VirtualLogix
abstract: Motorola is among the latest venture investors in VirtualLogix, a software company whose technology aims to make cell phones smarter and more powerful.

headline: Does Money Follow Passion? Top Bloggers Weigh In
abstract: A bevy of bloggers weigh in on the age-old career quandary — is choosing work you love a recipe for financial success?

headline: ’48 Hours’ Gets Religion
abstract: “48 Hours,” the CBS newsmagazine usually known for investigating murder mysteries, is about to tackle a very different subject: teenagers who are training to be Christian missionaries.

headline: Big Tax Breaks for Business in Housing Bill
abstract: The Senate proclaimed a fierce bipartisan resolve two weeks ago to help American homeowners in danger of foreclosure. But while a bill that senators approved last week would take modest steps toward that goal, The New York Times says it would also provide billions of dollars in tax breaks — for automakers, airlines, alternative energy producers and other struggling industries, as well as home builders.

headline: Powerset Debuts With Search of Wikipedia
abstract: Powerset launches its natural language search engine on Wikipedia. It’s promise to best Google remains a long ways off.

headline: A Strong ‘Upfront,’ But With Caveats
abstract: Stuart Elliott’s verdict on the upfront market of TV advertising sales: “It appears, from discussions with network executives and industry analysts, that the broadcasters may have matched the $9.1 billion to $9.2 billion they took in last spring before the start of the 2007-8 season.”

headline: Former AOL Executives Sued in Ad-Revenue Case
abstract: In a reminder that the wreckage of the disastrous merger between America Online and Time Warner is still being sifted, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday filed fraud charges against eight former AOL executives, saying they had inflated online advertising revenue by more than $1 billion.

headline: In Pact With Jay-Z Deal, Live Nation to Finance Ventures
abstract: In a move that reflects the anarchy sweeping the music business, the superstar rapper Jay-Z, who released his latest album to lukewarm sales five months ago, is on the verge of closing a deal with a concert promoter that rivals the biggest music contracts ever awarded.

headline: Bain Signs Deal for Japan’s D&M
abstract: Bain Capital agreed to buy D&M Holdings, the Japanese audio-equipment maker, for about 47.6 billion yen ($441 million) from rival buyout firm Ripplewood Holdings and the other shareholders.

headline: Banks Argue for Dissmissal of Clear Channel Suit
abstract: In the latest installment of the Clear Channel Communications buyout saga, Citigroup and five other banks Thursday asked a New York judge to throw out a lawsuit by the company’s private equity buyers accusing them of illegally refusing to fund the $19.5 billion acquisition.

headline: Psychics, Crime-Fighters and Lonely Singles: Welcome to CBS This Fall
abstract: CBS will introduce its fall schedule over a three-week period in September and October, beginning with “Survivor: Gabon” on Sept. 18, the network announced Thursday.

headline: Hedge Fund Guidelines Draw Criticism
abstract: Critics blasted the Treasury Department’s call for the hedge fund industry to police itself better, saying its voluntary guidelines did little to protect investors and regulate the pools of capital.

headline: Nike May Run Off With an Asian Rival
abstract: Nike could buy a Chinese or Japanese rival to strengthen its presence in Asia, the brand president of the world’s largest maker of athletic footwear and apparel told a German newspaper.

headline: Intrepid Potash Pops in I.P.O.
abstract: Intrepid Potash, the largest U.S.-based company that mines an essential fertilizer ingredient called potash, braved a mean market for I.P.O.’s and was rewarded with a big pop.

headline: Austin Ventures Leads Bid for Entrepreneur, Report Says
abstract: Entrepreneur Media, the Irvine, Calif.-based media company which focuses on small-business owners, is being bought in a deal led by Austin Ventures, paidContent.org reported.

headline: Chongqing Machinery Seeks $200 Million in I.P.O.
abstract: China’s Chongqing Machinery and Electric has launched pre-marketing for a Hong Kong listing that is expected to raise about $200 million.

headline: Where Securitization Lawyers Are Still Wanted
abstract: Common wisdom says that if you’re a corporate lawyer today specializing in structured finance — the practice of bundling together mortgages, bonds or loans into complex instruments — your job is probably on the chopping block. You have only to look to firms like Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft and McKee Nelson, which are dumping asset-bundling specialists amid the subprime mortgage meltdown.

headline: Sprott Asset Management Confirms I.P.O. Plans
abstract: Sprott Asset Management, the Canadian hedge fund led by Eric Sprott, has confirmed that it plans to sell shares in an initial public offering.

headline: Google Tests Using Your Search Data to Tailor Ads to You
abstract: Google is starting to look at the history of what its users search for in deciding which ads to show them. It’s a small step, but significant since Google until now has said it doesn’t use its vast store of information on the behavior of its users to target ads.

headline: Devoting Their Lives to Google
abstract: At this page, you can find two astonishing sights.

headline: ‘Brothers & Sisters, ‘ ‘Ugly Betty’ Win GLAAD Awards Again
abstract: The Associated Press: “Two ABC series were in repeats — as winners — at the annual awards honoring good work in media presentations of gays and lesbians. ‘Brothers & Sisters’ and ‘Ugly Betty’ received awards for outstanding drama and comedy series during the 19th annual Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation Media Awards at the Kodak Theatre on Saturday night.”

headline: Multigig Ticks Off $12.5 Million
abstract: Multigig, a maker of a new generation of clocks for silicon chips, has received $12.5 million in second-round financing.

headline: Citi’s New Slogan Is Said to Be Second Choice
abstract: Perhaps the next Citigroup tagline should be “Let’s Get It Right.”

headline: Bankrupt Airline Sues FedEx
abstract: ATA Airlines is suing the FedEx Corporation over its decision to drop the airline from its military charter team, a move ATA says forced it into bankruptcy protection and left it financially destroyed.

headline: JPMorgan Adds Bear Executives to Investment Bank
abstract: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Dubai Investment Firm Takes Stake in U.S. Asset Manager
abstract: Istithmar World Capital, the private equity and alternative investment arm of the Dubai government-owned investment company Istithmar World, has agreed to purchase a majority stake in U.S.-based corporate credit investor Gulf Stream Asset Management for an undisclosed amount, as the Dubai company seeks to expand beyond alternative investments and into credit markets.

headline: Digital Domain I.P.O. May Have Trouble Getting Off the Ground
abstract: Digital Domain, the Hollywood special-effects studio that had planned its initial public stock offering for this week, looks like it’s having trouble closing the deal — at least at the price it wants, The Los Angeles Times said.

headline: Three stories behind qualifying in Turkey
abstract: The top three finishers in today’s qualifying session each had equally interesting stories, although they are not all equally as straightforward.

headline: And the Winner of the Game Console Wars Is….
abstract: While there’s no denying that Xbox 360 is the first to sell the 10 million consoles, it isn’t going to hold the bragging rights for much longer.

headline: The $199 iPhone? Something’s Missing From the Picture
abstract: A report says AT&T will subsidize the new iPhone model to sell it for $199. What it doesn’t say is whether monthly data fees will rise at the same time.

headline: Temasek Confirms $600 Million Purchase of Merrill Shares
abstract: Temasek exercised an option to buy an additional $600 million worth of Merrill Lynch shares in February, raising its investment in the U.S. bank to $5 billion, the sovereign wealth fund said on Tuesday.

headline: Cerberus Won’t Pursue Blackwater Deal
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm, was in talks to invest $200 million for a stake in Blackwater USA, the controversial private security group, but those talks have now ceased, news reports said.

headline: Post-Strike, Some Show Ratings Are Down
abstract: Variety reports: “The May sweep starts Thursday, but the networks aren’t exactly in a mad dash to reach the starting line. Ratings are down for the hit shows that recently returned to action for the first time since the writers strike, and they’re also off” for some reality shows, incluing “American Idol.”

headline: Hedge Fund Heavyweights of 2007
abstract: For all its 85-year history, Bear Stearns is fetching about $1.2 billion in its sale to JPMorgan Chase. Last year alone, at least five hedge-fund managers made more than that.

headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

headline: Economy Hits U.S. PC Sales, but Notebook Growth Remains Strong
abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

headline: Amazon Gains Share of Shrinking Paid Music Market
abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

headline: Yahoo’s Starting Point: A Clearer Strategy
abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

headline: The Network That AT&T’s Growing Profits Will Buy
abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

headline: Clinton’s High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

headline: The iPhone Shortage
abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: Countrywide Says It Lost $893 Million in Quarter
abstract: Countrywide Financial said Tuesday that it lost $893 million in the first quarter as rising loan defaults forced it to increase its provision for loan losses and to book other credit-related charges.

headline: Hedge Funds: A ‘Lemon’ Market?
abstract: A new twist has emerged in the long-running debate over whether the $2 trillion hedge fund industry uses its power for good or for evil.

headline: Toward Friendlier Skies
abstract: David Pogue reports on the Federal Aviation Administration’s new technology that aims to relieve the nightmarish congestion our air-traffic system faces right now.

headline: Huawei Said to Consider Stake Sale
abstract: China’s Huawei Technologies, a telecom equipment maker, is considering the sale of a multibillion dollar stake in its mobile devices unit to a foreign investor, The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday, citing unnamed sources.

headline: Getting Rich — If Your Successor Does Well
abstract: Wachovia has filed an 8-k with the S.E.C. giving details on what Ken Thompson gets as he leaves. (See prior post here.)

headline: What?
abstract: Six tips for improving your listening skills.

headline: M&A Slowdown Hits the Middle Market
abstract: Everyone knows that the pace of mergers has slowed down dramatically since the onset of the credit squeeze. With a few notable exceptions here and there, mega-deals in particular seem to have disappeared.

headline: Canadian Retailer May Go On Block After Owner Dies
abstract: Hudson’s Bay Company, the Canadian retailer, may find itself on the block again after U.S. billionaire Jerry Zucker died over the weekend, leaving his wife, Anita, at the reins.

headline: InBev’s Offer for Anheuser-Busch: The Letter
abstract: Below is the letter send by Carlos Brito, InBev‘s chief executive, to August A. Busch IV, his counterpart at Anheuser-Busch, proposing a $44.6 billion union of their two companies. Mr. Brito also makes his case in a video here.

headline: Google Gets Closer to a Mobile Future
abstract: Google invests in wireless consortium to ensure open access

headline: In Yahoo Fight, It’s Goldman Against Icahn Again
abstract: Goldman Sachs and Carl C. Icahn, it seems, will square off once more.

headline: How Much Longer Will Katie Couric Anchor The ‘CBS Evening News?’
abstract: “A wide-ranging discussion in February about Katie Couric’s future as the anchor of the ‘CBS Evening News’ threatened on Thursday to turn her into a virtual lame duck in the job,” Bill Carter and Jacques Steinberg report.

headline: Two Candidates, Two Top Ten Lists
abstract: So who had the better Top 10 list — Barack Obama or Hillary Rodham Clinton?

headline: Answers From Iraqi Women, Part V
abstract: Video

headline: Networks Sue an Internet Video Start-Up
abstract: From DealBook’s colleague Brian Stelter at TV Decoder:

headline: Wave of Lawsuits Over Losses Could Hit a Wall
abstract: Finding someone to sue over losses in the mortgage market and the credit crisis is easy. Winning in court, lawyers say, will be hard.

headline: In Merger Lull, Analyst Sees Warning on Stocks
abstract: A year ago, mergers and buyouts were booming. And Tobias Levkovich, the top United States market strategist at Citigroup, saw that boom as a potentially bullish sign for stocks in 2008. The reason? He found there is a strong historical connection between deal activity and how the stock market performs 12 months later.

headline: Investors Betting Against BHP’s Rio Bid, Report Says
abstract: The market is assigning long odds BHP Billiton will succeed in its bid to acquire Rio Tinto amid growing fear regulators will block the tie up between the world’s first and third-largest miners, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: The e-Book Test: Do Electronic Versions Deter Piracy?
abstract: David Pogue has agreed to try an experiment involving his book “Windows Vista: The Missing Manual”: to offer it as part of that buy-the-electronic-versions program.

headline: Gore’s Latest V.C. Fund Raises $683 Million
abstract: The Climate Solutions Fund, a venture capital pool headed by Al Gore, has closed on a $683 million fund to invest in early-stage environmental companies, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Basic Instinct: Sprint Battles AT&T and iPhone With New Samsung Device
abstract: Sprint is aggressively positioning its upcoming Samsung Instinct smart phone as an alternative to Apple’s upgraded iPhone.

headline: Are KeyCorp’s Woes a Harbinger of More To Come?
abstract: Nobody was expecting an easy year for U.S. banks, but, says BusinessWeek, many observers thought the bulk of the industry’s credit troubles would come in the first quarter.

headline: Ratings: Finales Boost CBS; NBC, Not So Much
abstract: Finales of “CSI” and “Without a Trace” lifted CBS into first place as the most watched network on Thursday, but ABC remained the night’s leader among adults 18 to 49.

headline: Citigroup Raises $6 Billion in Capital Markets
abstract: Citigroup on Monday sold $6 billion of preferred shares to shore up its balance sheet after the largest United States bank recorded over $16 billion in write-downs and credit losses in the first quarter.

headline: Finally, Some Good News for Katie
abstract: After writing the same headline two weeks in a row — “A Record Low For ‘CBS Evening News'” — it is worth noting that Katie Couric’s nightly newscast posted some gains last week.

headline: Ratings: ‘Grey’ Leads, ‘Dance’ Follows
abstract: The two-hour season finale of “Grey’s Anatomy” vaulted ABC to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday, attracting 17.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although the number of viewers for the show’s fourth season conclusion declined nearly 5 million compared to a year ago (22.6 million), it still led the night by a wide margin over its nearest competitor, NBC’s “Deal or No Deal,” which garnered 10.3 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m.

headline: Rockefellers Seek Change at ExxonMobil
abstract: The Rockefeller family built one of the great American fortunes by supplying the nation with oil. Now history has come full circle: some family members say it is time to start moving beyond the oil age.

headline: Capital Group Raises $2.25 Billion Buyout Fund
abstract: The private equity division of Capital International is expected to announce that it has raised a $2.25 billion fund to invest in emerging markets, according to a report in The Financial Times. It would be among the largest global emerging markets funds to close so far this year.

headline: Dimon Confirms More Than Half of Bear Staff to Be Cut
abstract: JPMorgan Chase‘s chief executive confirmed Tuesday that the bank will be keeping nearly half of the employees at Bear Stearns, the struggling investment bank that JPMorgan agreed to buy in March.

headline: Bernanke to Face Bear Stearns Queries
abstract: Long before taking office as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke wrote an article with some other academics calling for the Fed to demystify its actions and pronouncements.

headline: China’s Everbright Bank Files for I.P.O.
abstract: Everbright Bank of China said Monday it had applied to China’s securities regulator for a long-planned initial public offering. The move comes as “investment sentiment in the country’s main exchange is facing poor conditions after recent heavy losses,” Reuters wrote.

headline: Cox Enterprises to Acquire Adify, an Ad Tech Firm
abstract: Cox Enterprises, a media company with broad holdings in newspapers, radio and television, said Tuesday that it would pay $300 million in cash for the advertising technology company Adify. The move would put Cox in competition with companies like Google that have built up big online advertising franchises.

headline: Cable Networks Boost Viacom Profit
abstract: “Viacom Inc said on Friday quarterly net profit rose 33 percent, beating Wall Street forecasts, on strong sales of the ‘Rock Band’ video game and higher advertising revenue at MTV Networks,” Reuters reports.

headline: Keep Reporting? Or Stop?
abstract: Khalid al-Ansary has worked for The New York Times.

headline: Gomez Aims for Nasdaq Listing
abstract: Gomez, an Internet performance monitoring company, has filed to go public. But is the market ready for this small, unprofitable but fast-growing company?

headline: Jana and CNet Battle It Out on Paper
abstract: The war of the words escalated Tuesday between CNet Networks and a group of activist investors led by Jana Partners that are seeking control of the company.

headline: NYSE Euronext to Announce Tech Partnership, Report Says
abstract: NYSE Euronext, the transatlantic exchange group, will on Tuesday step up its efforts to become a one-stop shop for U.S. equity trading in the face of mounting competition by announcing a partnership with Progress Software, a company specializing in advanced trading technology, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Ex-Manager Tells of Bribery at Siemens
abstract: A former manager of Siemens, the European engineering company, testified Monday about an intricate system of slush funds and bribery at the company as the first trial on allegations of corporate corruption in Germany began.

headline: A Fear That the Market’s Watchdog Is Losing Its Bite
abstract: Not long ago the market police at the Securities and Exchange Commission gave JPMorgan Chase the Wall Street equivalent of a traffic ticket. The penalty: $25 million.

headline: Thomson Reuters Said to Team With S&P for Hedge Fund Research
abstract: A half-dozen members of the Thomson Reuters  research department are moving to Standard & Poor’s to form a new department to produce market research for hedge funds and other Wall Street players, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Altor Networks Ropes in $6 Million
abstract: Altor Networks, a network security start-up, said Wednesday it raised $6 million in a second funding round led by Accel Partners and Foundation Capital.

headline: Circuit City Said to Have Several Interested Bidders
abstract: Blockbuster, it seems, may have some competition for its bid to acquire Circuit City.

headline: Why US Airways May Fly Solo
abstract: US Airways on Thursday joined the other large, United States-based network carriers in reporting a major quarterly loss: It said it was $236 million in the red. But while it has been invited to the money-losing party, it seems to be the only major American airline not invited to the merger jamboree.

headline: Kerkorian’s Ford Stake: A Deeper Shade of Red
abstract: Kirk Kerkorian is a savvy — and wealthy — investor, but lately he has shown an uncanny habit of buying Ford Motor shares just before they take a dive. The stock fell sharply in the weeks after his investment vehicle, Tracinda, made a tender offer for the shares in May. And on Friday, one day after he revealed increasing his stake even more, the stock took another tumble.

headline: Taking Stock of Apollo’s Timing
abstract: Apollo Management, the buyout firm run by Leon Black, took the market by surprise Tuesday, filing to sell some privately traded shares on the public markets despite the current lack of appetite on Wall Street for floating investment companies.

headline: Lehman’s Expensive History
abstract: From Louise Story, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Catterton Closes $300 Million Consumer Growth Fund
abstract: Catterton Partners, a Greenwich, Conn.-based private equity shop, has closed a $300 million growth fund to invest in the consumer sector.

headline: Citigroup to Shut Down Pandit’s Old Lane
abstract: In a press release early Thursday, Citigroup said it would “restructure” Old Lane, buying the assets of its multi-strategy hedge fund at fair value and integrating some of its other strategies — convertible equities, credit fixed income and structured credits — elsewhere at the bank.

headline: Tightening the Locks on Bear
abstract: James Dimon, JPMorgan Chase‘s chief executive, must have been really angry about the problems in the terms of the first version of his deal to buy Bear Stearns — because he isn’t taking any chances this time around.

headline: George Carlin and the Inaugural ‘SNL’
abstract: It speaks volumes about George Carlin’s prominence as a comedian that the NBC executives turned to him to host the inaugural episode of “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: Upfronts: Univision Unveils A New Bigger Sábado
abstract: One of the best-known, most-watched programs on Hispanic television will be getting a makeover.

headline: Macquarie, a Target for Short Sellers?
abstract: Macquarie has more of its shares on loan than any other Australian-listed company in a sign that short sellers have taken a big gamble that the investment bank’s share price will tumble, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Alimna Jumps 80 Percent in First Day of Trading
abstract: Alinma Bank, which in April raised $2.8 billion in Saudi Arabia’s biggest initial share sale for five years, jumped as much as 80 percent as it began trading in Riyadh Tuesday.

headline: Bank of America Vows More Help for Countrywide Mortgage Debtors
abstract: Bank of America will expand efforts to help Countrywide Financial borrowers avoid foreclosure on troubled mortgages, a top bank executive said Monday.

headline: British Pub Chain Confirms Buyout Talks
abstract: Mitchells & Butlers, the owner of British pub chains All Bar One and Harvester, confirmed Monday that several private equity firms had expressed interest in company and that it had received an approach from rival Punch Taverns about buying its 1.1 billion pound ($2.2 billion) Spirit managed pubs division.

headline: Microsoft Talks Tough, But Earnings Show Weakness
abstract: Microsoft continued to talk tough about its takeover feud with Yahoo, even as it reported fourth-quarter results that showed its online business, which trails far behind Google‘s, remains a problem area. Although the software giant’s overall results slightly surpassed Wall Street’s expectations, Microsoft’s shares fell 5 percent in after-hours trading.

headline: Upfronts: The CW’s Lineup
abstract: The CW will start its fall season on September 1, weeks before other broadcast networks, in an effort to jump-start its junior year schedule.

headline: Contract Talks: SAG Extends, AFTRA Delays
abstract: “Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers said on Friday that they would extend their current round of contract talks through Tuesday,” The New York Times reports.

headline: Bazaarvoice Speaks to V.C.’s
abstract: Bazaarvoice, which provides technology for brands to utilize consumer-generated content, has raised $7.1 million in a fundraising round.

headline: Upfronts: The Return of ’24’
abstract: After an 18-month hiatus, the Fox counter-terrorism drama “24” will return to the network’s schedule with a two-hour prequel.

headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

headline: Economy Hits U.S. PC Sales, but Notebook Growth Remains Strong
abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

headline: Amazon Gains Share of Shrinking Paid Music Market
abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

headline: Yahoo’s Starting Point: A Clearer Strategy
abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

headline: The Network That AT&T’s Growing Profits Will Buy
abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

headline: Clinton’s High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

headline: The iPhone Shortage
abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: An Opaque Argument for Market Transparency
abstract: Since Friday, one of the most-discussed items on Wall Street has been an op-ed in The Wall Street Journal, penned by Citigroup‘s chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit.

headline: Advertising With The ‘Family Guy’
abstract: The characters on “Family Guy” suddenly seem to be the darlings of Madison Avenue.

headline: Goldman Said to Name Co-Heads of Asia Investment Banking Group
abstract: Goldman Sachs on Monday announced two new co-heads to its investment banking group for Asia excluding Japan, highlighting a shifting of talent by Western banks to Asia.

headline: ‘Emeril’ Moves To Fine Living Network
abstract: “Emeril Lagasse is leaving the Food Network’s prime-time schedule for the Fine Living Network,” The Associated Press reports, “a move the chef hopes will mean a second course of ‘Emeril Live!'”

headline: Pier One Offers to Buy Cost Plus
abstract: Pier One Imports, the home-furnishings chain, said Monday it offered to buy Cost Plus in a stock swap valued at about $88 million.

headline: Charter Suspends Plan to Sell Customer Data to Advertisers
abstract: Charter Communications has suspended its plan to sell information about its customers’ Web surfing to an advertising company.

headline: Britain’s Inchcape to Drive Off With Musa Stake
abstract: Inchcape, the global car dealership, is buying a 75.1 percent stake in Russia’s Musa Motors Group for up to $450 million in anticipation of what the British company believes will be Europe’s biggest retail automotive market within two years.

headline: Fox Ramps Up Marketing For ‘Fringe’
abstract: The out-of-the-box marketing campaign for the Fox drama “Fringe” continues.

headline: Yahoo Chairman Fires Back at Icahn
abstract: Yahoo‘s chairman, Roy Bostock, rejected late Thursday accusations from the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn that the company’s board had acted irrationally in turning down a $47.5 billion takeover offer from Microsoft and repeated that Yahoo remained open to a deal at the right price.

headline: Prada Says No I.P.O. Before the Summer
abstract: Prada, the Italian fashion label making its fourth attempt to go public, isn’t planning to sell shares in an initial offering before the summer, despite having penciled in a June date for its I.P.O.

headline: BHP Won’t Rule Out Adding Cash to Rio Bid, Chief Says
abstract: BHP Billiton was not ruling out adding cash to its all-share hostile offer for rival Rio Tinto, BHP’s chief executive, Marius Kloppers, told CNBC.

headline: Iraq Briefing
abstract: A selection of articles from many sources on Iraq. For more, see the Baghdad Bureau blog’s Google Reader Shared Items.

headline: Watching Over the Bond Insurers
abstract: Eric Dinallo, New York State’s insurance superintendent, has had a hectic first year on the job. In its latest issue, Investment Dealers’ Digest interviewed him about the situation at various bond insurers and his thoughts on the credit crisis.

headline: Kleiner Said Dole Out iFund Cash to Pelago
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is reportedly leading a $15 million round for Pelago, the first company to tap iFund, the $100 million cash pool Apple launched in partnership with the V.C. firm to fund iPhone applications.

headline: Concerns Over Merrill Spark Speculation on Bloomberg Sale
abstract: Expected further write-downs by Merrill Lynch and worry that it may have limited options for raising capital have renewed speculation that it may sell its stake in financial information provider Bloomberg LP, MarketWatch reported.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Hires E.A.’s Creative Chief
abstract: William B. Gordon, a dean of video games who was one of Electronic Arts‘ first employees, in 1982, is leaving E.A. for the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield and Byers, the firm said Monday.

headline: Alliance Data Ends Deal With Blackstone
abstract: Alliance Data Systems, the credit card processor, sued the Blackstone Group in New York State court late Friday, accusing the private equity firm of breaching its agreement to buy the company for $6.4 billion, The New York Times reported.

headline: Sundance Is Sold to Cablevision for $496 Million
abstract: Rainbow Media, the cable programming subsidiary of Cablevision, said Wednesday that it was purchasing the Sundance Channel, which shows independent films and other programming, for $496 million in stock and cash.

headline: Hedge Fund Nominees Join Times Board
abstract: Two hedge fund who were part of a group of investors that threatened a proxy battle against The New York Times Company were elected as directors at the company’s annual meeting on Tuesday.

headline: Talking About Talks With Take-Two
abstract: Take-Two Interactive Software, maker of the wildly popular shoot-em-up Grand Theft Auto video games, appears to be very popular itself. Or so its chief executive, Ben Feder, keeps hinting.

headline: ‘The Wire,’ ‘Mad Men’ Top Critics’ Picks
abstract: Zap2It: “The closing chapters of ‘The Wire’ and the stylish first season of ‘Mad Men’ lead the nominees for the 2008 Television Critics Association Awards. Each show earned four nominations, the most of any program, and both are up for the top honor of program of the year.”

headline: HBOS Unveils $7.9 Billion Rights Issue
abstract: HBOS, the British bank, announced a 4 billion pound ($7.9 billion) rights issue alongside plans to cut its dividend to shore up its balance sheet after additional write-downs on troubled assets.

headline: Bell Canada Sale Can Proceed
abstract: From Ian Austen, DealBook’s colleague in Canada:

headline: Australia’s GrainCorp Offers to Buy Ridley
abstract: GrainCorp has offered to buy livestock feed maker Ridley for $390.5 million. The deal would allow eastern Australia’s largest grain handler to gain 23 domestic grain mills and sales in North America.

headline: Lonely Girl Pair Get $5 Million from V.C.’s
abstract: Miles Beckett and Greg Goodfried, the duo behind the 2006 online video phenomenon Lonelygirl15, have received $5 million from venture capitalists including Netscape co-founder Marc Andreessen and Spark Capital, to create an independent online studio, BusinessWeek reported.

headline: Vodafone Confirms Verizon Talks to Buy Alltel
abstract: Verizon Communications is near a deal to buy Alltel for about $27 billion, including the assumption of debt. Vodafone, Verizon’s partner in its wireless business, confirmed the talks in a short statement Thursday, which said Verizon Wireless was in “advanced discussions regarding the potential acquisition of Alltel.”

headline: Microsoft’s Deadline for Yahoo Bid Passes
abstract: So far, there’s been only radio silence on the Microsoft–Yahoo front.

headline: Lehman To Spend $1 Billion on Hedge Funds, Report Says
abstract: Lehman Brothers is planning to invest up to $1 billion in a fund it will use to buy stakes in hedge fund managers, Reuters reported.

headline: Google to Introduce New Ad-Planning Tool
abstract: Google is expected to unveil a new ad planning tool Tuesday designed to help media buyers identify a Web site’s demographic audience with more precision.

headline: For Many on Wall Street, H-P Deal Doesn’t Add Up
abstract: Hewlett-Packard‘s chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, faced a barrage of contentious questions Tuesday from analysts who seemed to be puzzled by the company’s decision to spend $13.2 billion to buy technology service provider Electronic Data Systems.

headline: Weather Channel Bids Due Today
abstract: Wall Street Journal: “Time Warner Inc. and a partnership between General Electric Co.’s NBC Universal and Blackstone Group LP have emerged as leading contenders to win an auction for the Weather Channel, ahead of Friday’s deadline for a second round of bids.” Bids are due Friday.

headline: Linens ‘n Things Shops for a Buyer
abstract: Linens ‘n Things has hired Financo, an investment bank specializing in retail companies, to find a buyer for the troubled housewares and bedding chain while it tries to avoid filing for bankruptcy.

headline: Will WPP’s Sorrell Take TNS Bid Hostile?
abstract: British advertising impresario Martin Sorrell may soon go hostile in his latest takeover tussle, according to The Deal.com.

headline: How Lionel Found Light at Tunnel’s End
abstract: Lionel LLC, the toy train maker, recently pulled out of a three-and-a-half-year stop in bankruptcy protection. The company’s chief executive tells Investment Dealers’ Digest that, given a few more years and the right conditions, an initial public offering might be in the cards.

headline: EU Gives Staples Thumbs Up for Corporate Express Deal
abstract: Office goods supplier Staples has won approval from the European Commission for its 1.7 billion euro ($2.64 billion) takeover bid for Dutch peer Corporate Express.

headline: Narrow Escapes for CNN Reporter in Myanmar
abstract: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Kathie Lee Doesn’t Add Viewers to ‘Today’
abstract: TV Week reports: “Kathie Lee Gifford’s first week as a ‘Today’ co-host alongside Hoda Kotb in the fourth hour of the show attracted slightly more young viewers but did not grow the overall audience for the time slot.”

headline: Taking Yang to Task
abstract: In an open letter to Jerry Yang published Saturday, The New York Times’ Joe Nocera lacerates the Yahoo chief to task for his muddled handling of Microsoft’s bid to buy the search giant, as well as his decision to throw his company into Google’s arms.

headline: The Real Fight Over Fake News
abstract: Next month, Comedy Central will start Webcasting full episodes of “The Daily Show.” Some cable systems are starting to complain that too many of the programs they pay for are being given away on the Web for free.

headline: Miller Undecided on Yahoo-Icahn Battle
abstract: Bill Miller, the star portfolio manager at Legg Mason Capital Management, said he has not yet decided whether to support a dissident board slate at Yahoo backed by billionaire investor Carl Icahn.

headline: Showtime Orders Season Three of ‘The Tudors’
abstract: Associated Press: “Showtime’s The Tudors and star Jonathan Rhys Meyers will return for a third season, with production set to begin in June in Ireland.” The show is midway through its second year. The next season will air in 2009.

headline: Remembering Spring 2003, From the Iraqi Side of Battle
abstract: This post is by an Iraqi employee of The New York Times based in Diyala whose name is being withheld for his safety. It was written in Arabic and translated by his colleagues in the Baghdad Bureau.

headline: Linens ‘n Things May Shutter More Stores, Report Says
abstract: Apollo Management‘s bankrupt retailer Linens ‘n Things may close additional stores beyond the 20 percent of its chain that it has already pledged to shutter, The New York Post reported.

headline: A Few Things to Think About
abstract: I must admit that I am still a bit too sun-dried after Memorial Day weekend to focus on events in the market.

headline: Buyout Firms Double Down on Their Own Debt
abstract: Private equity moguls are doubling down – on their own takeovers.

headline: ‘Smarter,’ ‘Swingtown,’ ‘CSI’ Top Thursday
abstract: On a low-rated Thursday of summer television, Fox came away as the most watched network thanks to its game show “Are You Smarter Than a Fifth Grader?” followed by a results edition of “So You Think You Can Dance.”

headline: Alcoa Names Chief Executive
abstract: Alcoa named its president, Klaus Kleinfeld, as its new chief executive on Thursday.

headline: ABC Game Show Contestants Will Wallow in Goo
abstract: If you’ve turned on ABC any time in the past month, you’ve no doubt seen the commercials for “Wipeout.”

headline: Société Générale Names Chief Financial Officer
abstract: Société Générale, the French bank hit by a rogue trading scandal, said Didier Valet would become its new chief financial officer.

headline: Judge Rejects Hedge Funds’ Attempts to Block Candover-Expro Deal
abstract: Britain’s High Court has rejected a last-gasp effort mounted by a group of hedge funds to block Candover‘s 1.8 billion pound bid for oil services group Expro, The Telegraph reported.

headline: BSNL Considers I.P.O.
abstract: Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited  is considering offering shares to government employees along with a considerable reservation for BSNL staff. Should the proposal go through, it would be the first such I.P.O., RTT News reported.

headline: Lehman: Upbeat Words, but a Grim Reality
abstract: Despite what it tells Wall Street, Lehman Brothers can’t seem to stay away from the capital-raising trough.

headline: Deadline Passes in Alliance Data Deal
abstract: The Blackstone Group‘s deadline to buy credit-card processor Alliance Data Systems passed with nary a word from either side on what will happen to the stalled $6.6 billion transaction.

headline: An ‘Average’ Cable Channel Embarks on a Radical Makeover
abstract: WGN, a Chicago-based channel owned by the Tribune Company, has a new name, “WGN America,” that indicates impending changes.

headline: Hexion’s Damages Claim
abstract: I’ve been mulling over the argument that Hexion Specialty Chemicals made in this week’s complaint that its damages are limited under the merger agreement to only $325 million. Upon reflection, I think this argument, though not compelling, is stronger than I initially suspected.

headline: HSBC Tops Underwriting Ranking for the First Time
abstract: HSBC has been named as the top underwriting bank in global initial public offering rankings for the first time, bolstered by strong deal-flow from Asia and the Middle East.

headline: Yahoo Chief Says Microsoft Was the Stubborn One
abstract: People involved in relationships that end abruptly often have grossly conflicting accounts of what went wrong. On Monday, Jerry Yang gave his version.

headline: Jobs Show Recession Is Here
abstract: The jobs report today has depressed the stock market, for obvious reasons. The popular theory that we would avert a recession and the economy would pick up in the second half now looks very dubious.

headline: Mike Wallace Will Return to the Vineyard, But Maybe Not To CBS
abstract: Mike Wallace, the veteran correspondent for “60 Minutes,” has appeared on the show sporadically since he retired two years ago. But health problems have gotten in the way, and he probably will not be returning to the air anytime soon.

headline: When Buyout Kings Try ‘Public Equity’
abstract: With the credit squeeze having all but shuttered the private equity industry, buyout moguls anxious to spend the money they raised are investing in publicly-traded companies. The latest example is David Bonderman’s TPG, which is expected to invest $5 billion to help keep Washington Mutual afloat.

headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

headline: Economy Hits U.S. PC Sales, but Notebook Growth Remains Strong
abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

headline: Amazon Gains Share of Shrinking Paid Music Market
abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

headline: Yahoo’s Starting Point: A Clearer Strategy
abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

headline: The Network That AT&T’s Growing Profits Will Buy
abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

headline: Clinton’s High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

headline: The iPhone Shortage
abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: Read The CNN Headline, Then Wear It
abstract: As if it’s not hard enough to summarize a story in six or seven words, CNN.com has a new test for editors: is the headline witty enough to be worn on a T-shirt?

headline: N.J. Agency Refuses to Give Tropicana Back to Owner
abstract: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission on Thursday refused to transfer assets of the Tropicana Resort & Casino back to its disqualified owner as a way to prevent the company’s being pushed into bankruptcy.

headline: Nuance Cuts $400 Million Deal for eScription
abstract: Nuance Communications said Tuesday it would purchase medical transcription software maker eScription for $400 million in what is the largest ever deal for the acquisitive voice technology company.

headline: News Networks Firm Up Convention Plans
abstract: In the days since Barack Obama solidified his standing as the presumptive Democratic nominee, “television news executives have begun to set their plans for covering the four-day Democratic convention, which begins on Aug. 25, and its Republican counterpart, which opens in St. Paul on Sept. 1, Labor Day,” Jacques Steinberg reports.

headline: As Markets Plunge, Deal-Making Plummets
abstract: Gloom has descended over Wall Street once again. While the price of oil is rising, the health of the financial sector is flagging, taking yet another heavy toll on the markets.

headline: S.E.C. Seeks to Reduce Reliance on Credit Ratings
abstract: Securities regulators proposed weaning investors and Wall Street institutions from over-reliance on credit ratings, part of changes to the rating industry prompted by the subprime mortgage crisis.

headline: ABC Cancels ‘Men in Trees’
abstract: ABC has canceled the two-year-old dramedy “Men in Trees,” TV Guide reports. The final episodes will begin airing May 28.

headline: Colony Capital and Eurazeo Look to Lift Stakes in Accor
abstract: Colony Capital and Eurazeo said they plan to increase their stake in Accor, Europe’s biggest hotel owner, to 30 percent.

headline: To Praise (or Pillory) a Short-Seller
abstract: David Einhorn’s apparent victory last week over Lehman Brothers has propelled him to near-rock-star status on Wall Street. Now Mr. Einhorn has gone mainstream with a spread in this week’s New York magazine.

headline: Nascar Wins Ratings
abstract: Ratings were low all around for prime-time television over the Memorial Day holiday as repeats on CBS ranked first on Monday and Nascar coverage lifted Fox to No.1 on Sunday.

headline: Arnault Ready to Set Sail With Princess Yachts
abstract: French billionaire Bernard Arnault is poised to buy Princess Yachts for an estimated 200 million pounds ($393.6 million).

headline: Fear and Loathing Among Consumers
abstract: Notes on the dreadful Reuters-University of Michigan April consumer sentiment survey:

headline: Anheuser Investors Say They Like $65-a-Share Offer
abstract: A bid by Belgium’s InBev for Anheuser-Busch at $65 a share would be reasonable, and a takeover would boost the Budweiser beer maker’s sluggish growth, Anheuser shareholders told Reuters.

headline: Icahn vs. Yahoo: The Latest Exchange
abstract: Carl Icahn said that Yahoo should offer to sell itself to Microsoft for nearly $49.5 billion and laid out his plan for the company, where he to succeed in taking control of it. Interestingly, Yahoo didn’t say the price was too low.

headline: Cuomo to Argue for Charges in Grasso Suit
abstract: New York Attorney General Andrew Cuomo will get his last chance Tuesday to have four key charges reinstated to the blockbuster lawsuit against former New York Stock Exchange chieftain Richard Grasso.

headline: Lehman’s Chief Folds on His 2008 Bonus
abstract: From Louise Story, a DealBook colleague:

headline: 2 Bear Bankers to Hang Their Own Shingle
abstract: Two top Bear Stearns investment bankers are opening an advisory boutique and plan to split with JPMorgan Chase the fee they expect to earn on a $5.2 billion buyout deal, according to TheStreet.com.

headline: Big Names Hook Up for Wireless Venture
abstract: A who’s who of technology and telecommunications companies announced Wednesday that it intends to build the first of a new generation of nationwide wireless data networks.

headline: Four Buyouts of the Apocalypse: Bell Canada
abstract: Sometimes the expected actually happens.

headline: United and Continental Said to Firm Up Deal of Their Own
abstract: As Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines reportedly near a merger agreement, United Airlines and Continental Airlines are poised to announce a deal of their own, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: For Lehman’s Fuld, A Reversal of Fortune
abstract: Richard S. Fuld tried for months to persuade Wall Street that Lehman Brothers, the investment bank he runs, could weather the storm in the financial markets. But by last Wednesday his time had run out: Confidence in Lehman seemed to be slipping away.

headline: Bollywood Goes to Hollywood, With Some Tinsel of Its Own
abstract: Hollywood loves to show outside investors just how the movie business really works. But some of the people behind Bollywood in India believe they have something to teach Hollywood about making movies.

headline: Texas Court Dismisses Banks’ Request for Delay in Clear Channel Suit
abstract: Clear Channel Communications said a Texas court on Monday dismissed a request by a group of banks to delay a trial over the funding of the $20 billion buyout of the radio station operator.

headline: Colbert Takes His ‘Report’ on the Road
abstract: “Stephen Colbert’s bid for the presidency may have fallen short, but he’s still determined to influence the race,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Working While Chronically Ill
abstract: After bouts with debilitating illnesses, one women turns her experience into a way to help others, and to earn a living.

headline: Chrysler Seeks to Unload to Axle Plants
abstract: Chrysler is seeking buyers for two Michigan axle plants as it tries to back away from producing auto parts in-house, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Advances in Merrill’s Deal for Ground Zero Headquarters
abstract: Merrill Lynch is negotiating a deal to build a 70-story headquarters at ground zero, a plan that would make it the first financial firm to return to the 16-acre former World Trade Center site since the terrorist attack destroyed the complex in 2001.

headline: Bidders Said to Line Up for BankThai Stake
abstract: HSBC, Standard Chartered and CIMB Group are among potential bidders for a 42 percent stake in unprofitable BankThai, which is partially owned by TPG, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Offer Says, ‘This Bud’s for InBev’
abstract: InBev, the world’s biggest brewer, started to build an argument Sunday for its $65-a-share offer to acquire Anheuser-Busch, saying it was based on the Budweiser maker’s current assets and business.

headline: Ballmer Says He’s Unmoved by Yahoo Earnings
abstract: Yahoo‘s earnings may have beaten expectations (if slightly), but they haven’t silenced tough talk from the Internet company’s chief tormentor, Microsoft‘s Steven Ballmer.

headline: Adelphia Founder And Son to Be Re-Sentenced
abstract: A federal district court judge on Thursday will re-evaluate the prison sentences of Adelphia founder John Rigas and his son Timothy after an appeals court overturned one part of their convictions last year.

headline: Jim McKay, Longtime ABC Sportscaster, Is Dead
abstract: Jim McKay, the longtime ABC sportscaster who hosted “Wide World of Sports” for more than thirty years, has died. He was 86.

headline: Credit Agricole to Sell Assets to Restructure Investment Arm
abstract: Credit Agricole said on Thursday it would sell assets and restructure its Calyon investment banking arm as it confirmed a $9.1 billion rights issue, Reuters reported.

headline: Langone to Face Trial Over Grasso Pay
abstract: A divided appeals court ruled Thursday that Kenneth G. Langone, the former chair of the New York Stock Exchange’s compensation committee, must face trial to determine if he breached his fiduciary duty to the exchange by misleading board members about deferred compensation for then-Chairman and Chief Executive Richard A. Grasso, in connection with his hotly disputed $187.5 million compensation package.

headline: France’s EDF May Raise Its Bid for British Energy, Report Says
abstract: Electricite de France could raise its bid for British Energy above 700 pence ($13.74) a share in exchange for the nuclear power company’s support for a deal, Reuters reported, citing a source close to the matter.

headline: ‘Grey’s Anatomy’ Star Doesn’t Want To Be Considered For Emmy
abstract: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Silver Miner Plans $900 Million London I.P.O.
abstract: Fresnillo, the world’s largest primary silver miner, said it planned to list in London next month in an initial pubic offering that could value it at around 4 billion pounds ($7.9 billion) and propel it into the FTSE 100.

headline: Capital Corp. Weighs Asset Sales
abstract: Capital Corporation of the West, the Merced, Calif., holding company of County Bank, is weighing an asset divestiture as part of a strategic review headed by Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.

headline: Thursday Ratings: ‘CSI’ Beats ‘Idol’
abstract: “CSI” overtook “American Idol” as the most-watched show on Thursday, lifting CBS to a ratings victory for the night.

headline: Stars’ Talents Will Remain Secret
abstract: As noted earlier, CBS canceled the reality show “Secret Talents of the Stars” on Thursday after telecasting only one — low-rated — episode.

headline: China’s Shagang Mulls Bid for Brazilian Iron Ore Unit
abstract: Jiangsu Shagang Group, China’s biggest privately owned steelmaker, is seeking to buy a stake in Brazil’s Cia. Siderurgica Nacional ‘s iron ore unit as prices for the raw material soar to a record.

headline: A Tale of Two Public Offerings
abstract: With the credit market still in lockdown and the equity market on a downswing, taking a company public might seem a bit loopy. Two companies that actually took the plunge this week, American Waterworks and Intrepid Potash, exemplify how bipolar this market has become.

headline: ArcLight Sells Magnum Coal to Patriot
