abstract: Patriot Coal said Wednesday it would acquire ArcLight Capital Partners‘ portfolio company Magnum Coal for nearly $709 million to bolster its presence in the Central Appalachian region.

headline: The Webbys in Five Words: Cynical, Campy, Goofy, Hot, Long
abstract: The Webby Awards. What can you say?

headline: NBC’s Future: ‘Content Centers’
abstract: Bill Carter reports:

headline: Tumbling Home Prices
abstract: The existing home sales numbers — on a seasonally adjusted basis — seem to be staying about the same these days. But the prices keep falling.

headline: Skepticism Clouds H-P’s Talks with Electronic Data
abstract: Nearly seven years after its controversial $25 billion merger with rival personal computer maker Compaq, Hewlett-Packard seems to have caught the merger bug once again. The company, known widely for its printers, has confirmed that it is close to sealing a deal to buy technology service provider, Electronic Data Systems, for $12 billion to $13 billion.

headline: Rich Americans Under Scrutiny in UBS Case
abstract: One afternoon in April, six dozen wealthy Americans were honored at a luncheon party in Midtown Manhattan, along with a special guest from Paris: Henri Loyrette, the director of the Louvre.

headline: Surprise! Microsoft Proposes New Deal to Yahoo
abstract: Microsoft has proposed a complex new deal with Yahoo that would involve collaboration between their online advertising businesses but would not involve a full takeover, Microsoft said on Sunday.

headline: National City Said to Face S.E.C. Scrutiny
abstract: National City, the large Midwestern bank that sold a stake to an investor group earlier this year, has entered into a memorandum of understanding with federal regulators, effectively putting the bank on probation, The Wall Street Journal reported on Friday.

headline: United Rentals Goes Where Cerberus Wouldn’t
abstract: Seven months after the $6.6 billion leveraged buyout of United Rentals by Cerberus Capital Management was scuttled, the tool rental company is planning what amounts to its own leveraged buyout.

headline: Brokaw To Host ‘Meet the Press’ Through Election
abstract: Tom Brokaw will moderate “Meet the Press” in Tim Russert’s place through the 2008 presidential election in November, NBC announced Sunday morning.

headline: Countrywide Shareholders to Vote on Bank of America Deal
abstract: Countrywide Financial shareholders vote on Wednesday to approve the largest U.S. mortgage lender’s purchase by Bank of America, marking the demise of the company perhaps most closely associated with the nation’s housing bubble and subsequent collapse.

headline: A Home Improvement Web Site Begets a TV Series
abstract: HGTV will introduce a television spin-off of the Web site “Rate My Space” on Thursday, marking another partnership between Internet properties and TV.

headline: Officials Seek to Keep JPMorgan in Boston
abstract: Boston officials on Tuesday unveiled a $4 million tax-incentive package to convince JPMorgan Chase to remain in Boston.

headline: The Stars Can Dance All They Want, But More People Watch Simon Cowell
abstract: ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” marked its 100th episode on Tuesday, drawing solid ratings but not enough to overcome Fox’s advantage with “American Idol.”

headline: The Cost of Lehman’s Loss
abstract: Shares in Lehman Brothers plummeted more than 10 percent in early-morning trading Monday, after pre-announcing a $2.8 billion loss for its second quarter and disclosing that it will seek $6 billion in additional capital.

headline: Treasury to Release New Foreign Takeover Rules
abstract: The Treasury Department said Tuesday it will release rules by the end of this month clarifying how the government will vet acquisitions involving foreign buyers for national security risks.

headline: Tuesday Ratings: Fox’s ‘Idol,’ NBC’s ‘Loser’ Are Winners
abstract: “The Biggest Loser” proved to be a big asset for NBC on Tuesday, as the reality weight loss competition lifted the network to a second place finish — behind Fox — for the night among adults 18 to 49.

headline: Ustream Pulls in $11.1 Million from V.C.’s
abstract: There are seemingly more “livestreaming” services out there than people actually using them, but that hasn’t stopped Ustream.tv from raising $11.1 million in Series A funding.

headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

headline: Yahoo’s Starting Point: A Clearer Strategy
abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

headline: The Network That AT&T’s Growing Profits Will Buy
abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

headline: Clinton’s High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

headline: The iPhone Shortage
abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: Online Ad Start-Up Raises $10.7 Million
abstract: Jivox, which provides an online video advertising platform for businesses, said it closed a $10.7 million financing round led by venture capital firm Opus Capital. Helion Venture Partners, a new investor, also took part in the round, Jivox said.

headline: Two Friends Are Buried and a Family Grieves
abstract: Video

headline: A David-Versus-David Showdown on ‘Idol’
abstract: The David Cook/David Archuleta showdown on “American Idol” wasn’t a surprise, the Associated Press surmises.

headline: BlackRock’s Chief Gets a 27% Pay Lift
abstract: BlackRock Chairman and Chief Executive Laurence Fink received $41.87 million in compensation in 2007, a 27 percent increase from the prior year, according to a regulatory filing on Monday.

headline: Clear Channel Settlement Gives Hope to BCE Shareholders
abstract: News that Clear Channel Communications buyout is a go following a settlement with the six banks financing the deal may also be sweet music to shareholders of BCE, the Canadian telecom giant that agreed last year to sell itself to a private equity consortium in a 52 billion Canadian dollar ($51.3 billion) deal.

headline: Treasury Officials to Meet With Wall Street Execs, Report Says
abstract: Treasury Department officials plan private meetings with Wall Street executives and bankers, in an apparent attempt to counter Congressional Democrats seeking stronger steps to handle the housing crisis, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Charming Shoppes Averts Proxy Fight
abstract: A dramatic proxy showdown at apparel company Charming Shoppes ended Thursday with an 11th-hour truce that will expand the company’s board to 11 from 10.

headline: Is Freescale an ‘Ugly Baby’?
abstract: For months, Wall Street has been wondering what will become of Freescale Semiconductor, the chip maker taken private with a big slug of debt near the height of the leveraged buyout boom. More specifically, there has been widespread speculation about how its buyers, a consortium led by Blackstone Group, would make out in the $17.6 billion deal.

headline: A Government Risk-Management Panel?
abstract: Harvey Pitt, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, suggested in a column in Compliance Week that the President’s Working Group on Financial Markets should consider forming a Risk Management Committee.

headline: Nymex Members Said to Try Stopping CME Deal
abstract: Members of the New York Mercantile Exchange will try to thwart the $9 billion takeover by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange unless the rival futures trading giant significantly boosts its offer, The New York Post reported Tuesday.

headline: NYSE Euronext Reports Higher Profit
abstract: NYSE Euronext on Tuesday reported a surge in first-quarter profit, as the stock-exchange operator benefited from its acquisition of the European bourse owner Euronext by both growing revenue and chopping costs.

headline: A New Wave of Vilifying Short Sellers
abstract: In the days when square-rigged galleons plied the spice route to the East, the Dutch outlawed a band of rebels that they feared might plunder their new-found riches.

headline: Wall Street Journal Editor Expected to Resign
abstract: Just four months after Rupert Murdoch took control of Dow Jones, the parent company of The Wall Street Journal, the newspaper’s top editor, Marcus W. Brauchli, is expected to step down, according to reports.

headline: Grand Theft Auto IV Didn’t Bolster Console Sales
abstract: Grand Theft Auto IV sold extremely well, but sales figures show it didn’t induce people to buy new game consoles to play it on, says NPD, a market research firm.

headline: The Latest Japanese Imports: Game Shows
abstract: ABC is preparing an unscripted series called “I Survived A Japanese Game Show.” Which understandably leads us to wonder: what exactly is a “Japanese game show” and why is it so perilous?

headline: R.B.S. Investors Said to Approach Sainsbury Chairman
abstract: Institutional investors in the Royal Bank of Scotland have approached Philip Hampton, chairman of supermarket group J. Sainsbury, about becoming chairman of the bank, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Delayed Singapore Sale Contributes to Indiabulls Fall
abstract: Indiabulls Real Estate fell to the lowest in almost a year in Mumbai trading after it delayed a share sale by its real estate investment trust in Singapore by a day, Bloomberg reported.

headline: National City to Raise $7 Billion in New Capital
abstract: The National City Corporation, the nation’s tenth-largest bank, said on Monday that it plans to raise $7 billion from a group of investors as it seeks to shore up its balance sheet against continued trouble in the mortgage market. But the plan also involves slashing the bank’s dividend and a big dilution of current shareholders.

headline: What’s On Your DVR?
abstract: “Grey’s Anatomy,” “House,” “Lost,” and “American Idol” were the most-played-back shows of the 2007-08 television season.

headline: Buyout-Fee Withdrawal, By the Numbers
abstract: The big investment banks are getting hit from both sides these days. Not only do they have to write down billions of dollars in toxic assets, they are also bringing in less money.

headline: Jim McKay, The ‘Most Reliable and Dignified Voice’ of ABC Sports
abstract: The memorial service for the ABC sportscaster Jim McKay “became a morning of storytelling” in Baltimore on Tuesday, Richard Sandomir reports.

headline: BA Confirms Talks With American, Continental
abstract: British Airways said on Wednesday it was in discussions with two of its largest U.S. rivals, American Airlines and Continental Airlines, which a source briefed on the matter told Reuters was about a potential alliance.

headline: Good Times Left Lehman Unprepared for the Bad
abstract: Sometimes, when you really mess up, it is good to admit you erred.

headline: Lehman Battles an Insurgent Investor
abstract: David Einhorn thinks another big Wall Street bank is headed for trouble – and he is not being quiet about it.

headline: Greentech Media Connects With V.C.’s
abstract: Venture capitalists, it seems, just can’t get enough of anything green. From alternative energy start-ups to organic beverages, V.C.’s are opening their wallets for environmentally-friendly business.

headline: Diller Pours Cold Water on Expedia Buyout Chatter
abstract: Expedia‘s chairman, Barry Diller, on Wednesday dismissed newly resurfaced rumors that the online travel site would be taken private and blamed speculators for trying to make a quick buck.

headline: Citi Moves Top Banker to Middle East
abstract: Citigroup announced late Wednesday that it was moving one of its most senior investment bankers to the Middle East, hoping to establish a stronger foothold in the oil-rich region.

headline: United’s Pilots Union Pans Potential US Air Deal
abstract: A “toxic stew” of problems with pilots and other issues at US Airways would imperil any merger between that carrier and United Airlines, the leader of the United pilots’ union said on Tuesday.

headline: A Letter to Facebook’s Founder
abstract: Memo

headline: NBC Stakes Out a Family-Friendly Position
abstract: It is rare for broadcast networks to discuss overarching themes or approaches to their schedules. After all, it is called broadcasting, meaning that the shows are meant to appeal to a broad range of audiences.

headline: Icahn’s Big Yahoo Wager
abstract: Carl C. Icahn prides himself on his poker-playing skills. But he may have just made one of the biggest gambles of his career as he tries to shake up Yahoo.

headline: Park the Car
abstract: Americans are driving less. It is not clear how much of that change is due to recession, and how much to higher prices, but the trend seems clear.

headline: Should Anti-Spyware Programs Fight Snooping I.S.P.s?
abstract: An industry group is going to help figure out whether anti-spyware software should try to block Internet Service Providers from monitoring where their customers surf in order to show them ads.

headline: NYSE Jumps on the Spac Bandwagon
abstract: NYSE Euronext, challenging the American Stock Exchange‘s historic dominance in listings of special-purpose acquisition companies, plans to list its first Spac later this month. The Spac is Heckmann Corporation, which made its debut on the American Stock Exchange in November but will jump from there to the NYSE Euronext on May 23.

headline: Mechanical Zoo Said to Grab Angel Funding
abstract: Nathan Stoll, a former Google News executive, has been quietly working on a new social search service he started with the help of two other Google refugees, CNET News.com reported.

headline: Putting a Price Tag on Apollo
abstract: Leon Black generally avoids the public eye — so why did his buyout firm, Apollo Management, just file to go public? And why now, when private equity deals are in a credit-crunch-induced coma? Well, it had to: As part of its debut last August on Goldman Sachs‘s private market, GSTrUE, Apollo agreed to register for a public offering in 240 days. The deadline was just about now. Like it or not, it’s showtime.

headline: Jefferies Sees Brighter Forecast for Clean-Tech I.P.O.’s
abstract: Bankers at Jefferies Group on Wednesday forecast an improved deal pipeline for initial public offerings for companies in the business of reducing the world’s carbon emissions and fossil-fuel consumption, following a dry spell in the first quarter.

headline: SmartSynch Puts $20 Million on the Meter
abstract: SmartSynch, which sells smart metering technology to the utility industry, has raised $20 million in new funding led by new investors Credit Suisse and Southern Farm Bureau Life Insurance.

headline: The High Costs of Milberg Weiss’ Plaintiff Payments
abstract: From Jonathan D. Glater, a DealBook colleague:

headline: E.U. to Investigate Italian Aid to Alitalia
abstract: European Union regulators said Wednesday that they would investigate whether Italy’s rescue loan to ailing national airline Alitalia is illegal, The Associated Press reported.

headline: S.E.C. Proposes Tighter Credit-Rating Rules
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed new rules on Wednesday intended to stem conflicts of interest, expand disclosure for Wall Street’s credit rating industry and flag the ratings of more complex securities.

headline: Big Pain From a Student Loan Company’s Bankruptcy
abstract: Does the plight of a nonprofit student loan guarantor reflect what would happen if a bond insurer melted down?

headline: Ringing Up Gains on Alltel
abstract: It’s not a home run. But it’s not bad for a few months’ work either.

headline: Tesla Chairman Expects I.P.O. This Year
abstract: Most people probably won’t be able to afford one of the sexy electric sports cars from Tesla Motors. The Roadster sells for about $100,000 and only recently began shipping in limited quantities. But fans of Tesla may be able to buy something else later this year: Shares of Tesla’s stock.

headline: Senators to Question Chiefs of Bear and JPMorgan
abstract: Bear Stearns chief executive Alan Schwartz and JPMorgan Chase chief executive James Dimon are among the witnesses expected to appear on Capitol Hill on Thursday for what Chris Dodd, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said he hopes will be a “full, thorough airing of the relevant facts and information” about the Fed-backed fire sale of Bear to JPMorgan.

headline: Viewers Reject Repeats, Watch Reality
abstract: How low are the ratings for network reruns this summer? Here’s how low..

headline: Air France-KLM Grounds Bid for Alitalia
abstract: Air France-KLM said Monday that its offer to buy the struggling Italian airline Alitalia for 139 million euros ($220 million) was “no longer valid.”

headline: Michelle Obama To Be A Guest Host On ‘The View’
abstract: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Ex-CNN Anchor Aaron Brown Returns to TV on PBS’ ‘Wide Angle’
abstract: Aaron Brown, the former CNN anchor who found cable TV an awkward fit, is joining PBS’ ”Wide Angle” series and ending his on-air absence of more than two years.

headline: Signs of Life for Megadeals?
abstract: Five months into a tough year for deal-making, a few statistics confirm what practitioners in the trenches already knew. The volume of announced mergers around the world is down from last year’s heady levels: It declined about 35 percent through May 29 compared with the equivalent period in 2007, according to Dealogic’s numbers. And the value of leveraged buyout deals has positively plunged, down 76 percent from a year ago.

headline: Saturday Night on CBS: A Mixed Martial Arts Debut
abstract: This Saturday, CBS will become the first legacy network to show full mixed martial arts matches in prime time, the Associated Press reports.

headline: Viacom Joint Venture Hires Ex-Showtime Executive As CEO
abstract: “An entertainment joint venture formed by Viacom Inc, its Paramount Pictures unit, and film studios Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studios Inc and Lions Gate Entertainment Corp said on Monday that it hired former Showtime cable executive Mark Greenberg as its chief executive,” Reuters reports.

headline: Wall Street Chiefs Grilled on Bear Deal
abstract: “Buying a house is not the same as buying a house on fire.”

headline: Citi Expands Its Innovation Efforts
abstract: Citigroup must be ready to innovate. The latest sign: It now has not one, but two innovation chiefs.

headline: Lieberman Seeks Limits to Reduce Commodities Speculation
abstract: A prominent Washington lawmaker said Wednesday that he would propose next week to ban large institutional investors, including index funds, from the nation’s booming commodity markets.

headline: Chinese Reversal
abstract: The most interesting thing in the trade figures today may be the fact that China’s trade balance with the United States is shrinking fast. In March, it came to $16.1 billion, the lowest figure for any month in two years and nearly $10 billion below the peak monthly figure of $25.9 billion, reached in October.

headline: Ponzi Squared
abstract: Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y.

headline: Upfronts: ‘Lost,’ ‘Goode Family’ At Midseason For ABC
abstract: ABC’s midseason plans include “Lost” and “The Goode Family.”

headline: Third Suit Filed Against San Jose Investor
abstract: The third time may not be the charm for San Jose investor William “Boots” Del Biaggio III. A new lawsuit accuses Mr. Del Biaggio of scamming Modern Bank of New York out of a $10 million loan so he could buy an interest in the Nashville Predators hockey team.

headline: In Tougher Times, Carlyle Looks Abroad
abstract: It’s been a rough few months for David M. Rubenstein, co-founder and managing director of the Carlyle Group, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

headline: Economy Hits U.S. PC Sales, but Notebook Growth Remains Strong
abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

headline: Amazon Gains Share of Shrinking Paid Music Market
abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

headline: Yahoo’s Starting Point: A Clearer Strategy
abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

headline: The Network That AT&T’s Growing Profits Will Buy
abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

headline: Clinton’s High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

headline: The iPhone Shortage
abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: Fox News Worker Sues Over Bedbugs
abstract: Reuters reports:

headline: Biotech’s Banner Year
abstract: Biotechnology firms in the United States drew a record $5.5 billion in venture-capital funding in 2007, according to Ernst & Young’s annual report card on the industry. But the sector may not be immune from broader economic ills.

headline: Big Write-Down May Force Barclays to Raise Capital
abstract: British bank Barclays said profits fell in the first quarter and refused to rule out a rights issue as it took a 1 billion pound ($2 billion) hit for the impact of the credit crunch.

headline: New Board Member Reflects Global Influence on Goldman
abstract: The steel magnate Lakshmi N. Mittal joined the board of Goldman Sachs as an independent director, a move that underscores the growing importance of the developing world for Wall Street’s behemoths.

headline: Finisar to Buy Optimum
abstract: Finisar said Friday it would buy Optium, a supplier of telecommunication equipment, in an all-stock deal worth about $211.7 million.

headline: Japan Rejects TCI’s Bid to Raise Stake in J-Power
abstract: Japan is rejecting a bid by The Children’s Investment Fund to increase its stake in J-Power, government officials told The Associated Press Wednesday.

headline: WhiteHat Scores $7 Million
abstract: WhiteHat Security, a provider of Web site security services, has raised a fourth round of funding.

headline: And The Winner Is…
abstract: “It was a winner by a knockout Wednesday in the finale of the seventh season of ‘American Idol,’ but the victor was not the contestant who appeared to have delivered the decisive blow during the final night of competition one night earlier,” Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Bear Stearns and Deloitte Sued Over Hedge Fund Collapse
abstract: The liquidators of two Bear Stearns mortgage hedge funds that collapsed last year, filed suit on Monday against the company and its auditor, Deloitte & Touche, seeking to recover over $1 billion in losses.

headline: TomTom Reiterates Committment to Tele Atlas Deal
abstract: TomTom said Friday it is committed to its 2.9 billion euros ($4.6 billion) buyout of digital map maker Tele Atlas and looking for a “positive outcome” from talks with European antitrust regulators.

headline: Ning Picks Up $60 Million from V.C.’s
abstract: Ning, the make-your-own social network, has raised a $60 million fourth round from unspecified institutional investors, valuing the company at $500 million, pre-investment.

headline: Friday’s Links: Personality Types of Presidential Types
abstract: What can be learned from looking at the personality types of presidential contenders and sitting presidents?

headline: Sundance Is Sold to Cablevision for $496 Million
abstract: From DealBook’s colleague Brian Stelter on TV Decoder:

headline: Carlyle to Buy Booz Allen’s Government Unit
abstract: The consulting firm Booz Allen Hamilton said early Friday that it would sell a majority stake of its government practice to the private equity firm Carlyle Group for $2.54 billion. The announcement came four months after DealBook reported that a potential deal with Carlyle, run by David Rubenstein, was in the works.

headline: Your Questions for Iraqi Women
abstract: BAGHDAD – When we asked readers to suggest a topic for a future Q&A, many people asked to hear from Iraqi women. Elyse Giaimo wrote that “women should be asked how their daily lives and aspirations have changed since the fall of the former regime.”

headline: This Year’s Finales Are Drawing Fewer Viewers Than Last Year
abstract: ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” attracted Monday’s largest audience, with 18.8 million viewers tuning in for the show’s final performances of the season, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Like most network television shows this spring, ratings for the final episode were down compared with last year: the same episode of “Dancing” drew 20.2 million viewers in 2007.

headline: There He Goes Again: More Racial Comments from Imus
abstract: Don Imus, who was fired last year for referring to the Rutgers women’s basketball team as “nappy-headed hos,’’ waded into racially treacherous waters again on his new radio program Monday morning.

headline: The New Celebrities on Syndicated Shows: Barack, Hillary and John
abstract: A symbiotic relationship has developed between the presidential campaigns and the entertainment press, Julie Bosman reports in Thursday’s New York Times.

headline: Is China Planning to Snap Up a $20 Billion Stake in BHP?
abstract: China may be moving closer to attempting something many have considered unthinkable: taking a substantial stake in the world’s largest miner, BHP Billiton.

headline: The Cost of the $199 iPhone: $10 More a Month for Data
abstract: Apple cut the price of its iPhone by $200 to $199, but AT&T is raising price of the data service you need to use the phone to $30 a month — a $10 increase. In other words, consumers will wind up paying $40 more over the course of two years than they would have under the previous iPhone deal.

headline: Looking Back At TV’s Dead List
abstract: Lisa de Moraes of The Washington Post asks: “Where Are The Shows Of Yesteryear?”

headline: Stunts Today for Firefox. Sophisticated Programs Tomorrow
abstract: The latest edition of the Firefox browser is being released today with a call to set a world record for software downloads. Beyond the hype and a few new features, the new version is the beginning of an evolution in the standards behind Web pages that will enable much more sophisticated applications.

headline: Tesla Signs Deal With Daimler
abstract: Tesla Motors, a maker of electric sports car that has won admirers among the celebrity set, has signed a “small” deal to work with Germany’s Daimler, Tesla Chairman Elon Musk said in a Fox Business News interview last week.

headline: Deutsche Bahn Plans Global Push
abstract: Deutsche Bahn will use funds from the proposed initial public offering of its DB Mobility Logistics unit to expand globally, German newspaper Boersen-Zeitung reported, citing an interview with Deutsche Bahn’s chief executive, Hartmut Mehdorn.

headline: Can Facebook Build a Better Passport?
abstract: Facebook is matching new features from MySpace that will let users bring information from their profiles onto other sites. It is also reviving another idea: the possibility of a universal logon, an idea tried unsuccessfully years ago by Microsoft.

headline: SpikeSource Gets $10 Million Patch from Intel
abstract: SpikeSource, which on Friday is introducing a version of its automated support and testing service tuned for the needs of IT industry platform providers, announced that Intel has invested $10 million in the start-up.

headline: Fifth Third to Cut Dividend and Raise Capital
abstract: Fifth Third Bancorp, a Cincinnati-based bank, said Wednesday it would cut its dividend by more than half and raise about $2 billion by selling convertible preferred stock and certain “noncore businesses.” It said it is taking the steps “to strengthen its capital position in light of continued deterioration in credit trends.”

headline: GLG’s Profits Rise Despite Market Turmoil
abstract: GLG Partners, the publicly traded British hedge fund, said on Wednesday that it earned $33.8 million for the first quarter, a 142 percent jump over last year even as the firm’s industry continues to struggle with the choppy markets.

headline: Staples Raises Corporate Express Bid to $2.6 Billion
abstract: Staples has raised its offer for Corporate Express to 1.67 billion euros ($2.6 billion) after the Dutch company rejected two takeover attempts and agreed to buy a French rival.

headline: Predicting The ‘Idol’ Winner
abstract: Ian Ayres of sis-blog Freakonomics asks: What’s the Best Way to Predict American Idol?

headline: Despite Downturn, Financing Still Exists
abstract: With all the grim earnings news from corporations and banks lately, not to mention the continuing credit squeeze and widespread talk of recession, it would seem that most small companies, too, would be having a hard time finding financing.

headline: TPG Leads $7 Billion WaMu Investment
abstract: Washington Mutual, the nation’s largest savings and loan, on Tuesday received a$7 billion lifeline from the buyout firm TPG and other investors in an effort to stabilize its finances.

headline: Lessons of G.E.
abstract: Pondering the G.E. earnings miss yesterday leaves me with a handful of observations:

headline: $50 Billion Bharti-MTN Deal Falls Apart
abstract: The world’s largest corporate deal in an emerging market, a tie-up worth nearly $50 billion between two telecommunication companies, Bharti Airtel in India and MTN Group in South Africa, came to a screeching halt Saturday.

headline: G.E. Looks to Sell Its Appliances Unit
abstract: General Electric is planning to sell its appliances division, one of the longest-running businesses in the conglomerate’s 120-year history, a person briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

headline: On ‘Idol, ‘Good Singers Make For A Dull Season
abstract: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Jack Welch on G.E.’s ‘Credibility Crash’
abstract: John F. Welch Jr., the legendary former chief executive of General Electric, was throwing rapid-fire bouquets and brickbats Wednesday morning during his turn as guest host of CNBC’s Squawk Box. Perhaps most notably, he said Jeff Immelt, his successor at G.E., had suffered a “credibility crash” after the giant conglomerate severely missed earnings expectations last week.

headline: Brazil’s OGX Raises $3.58 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: OGX Petroleo e Gas, the Brazilian oil company controlled by billionaire Eike Batista, raised 5.87 billion reais ($3.58 billion) in what could be the country’s biggest initial public offering.

headline: With Housewives and Makeovers, Sunday Night Belongs to ABC
abstract: ABC proved unbeatable in the ratings on Sunday, as new installments of “Desperate Housewives,” “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” and “Brothers & Sisters” led all four hours of prime time.

headline: On TV, The Housing Market Is Still Booming
abstract: Comparing the 2005 and 2008 episodes of housing shows offers a shorthand version of the downturn of the housing market.

headline: CNBC Video: National City’s Costly Fundraising
abstract: National City became only the latest bank to seek additional funds in the wake of the housing market slump, unveiling a plan on Monday to raise $7 billion from a group of investors. The bank, the tenth-largest in the United States, is now following in the footsteps of a score of peers — from Citigroup to Washington Mutual — to rely on a big infusion by outsiders.

headline: Blue Coat Tries Packeteer on for Size
abstract: Blue Coat Systems said Monday it will acquire Packeteer for about $268 million in cash, a deal uniting two suppliers of software used to improve the performance of large corporate networks.

headline: ABC and ESPN Adds Videos To Veoh
abstract: ABC and ESPN videos will be accessible through the independent video site Veoh.com.

headline: GE to Buy Most of Citi’s Commercial Lending Unit
abstract: General Electric‘s GE Capital unit said Thursday that it will buy a majority stake of Citigroup‘s commercial lending and leasing business for an undisclosed amount of cash, as both companies seek to cope with market troubles and internal problems.

headline: KSL Partners Said to Be Among Esporta Bidders
abstract: KSL Capital Partners, a U.S. buyout firm that counts golf-course operator Clubcorp among its investments, is one of half a dozen suitors to have submitted initial offers for British fitness club chain Esporta last week, The Times of London reported.

headline: Ambac Asks Fitch to Remove Ratings
abstract: Ambac Financial, the big bond insurer struggling with the effects of the mortgage debacle, said Wednesday that it has asked Fitch Ratings to withdraw its ratings “effective immediately.”

headline: Collective Intellect Scores $6.6 Million
abstract: Collective Intellect, whose software helps corporations monitor the online buzz, said Wednesday it closed a $6.6 million funding round.

headline: Laud Collier Leads Tread Buyout
abstract: Private equity firm Laud Collier & Company said Wednesday that it had led a buyout of mining equipment manufacturer Tread. The consortium also included Gladstone Investment and Argosy Investment Partners.

headline: TV, but With Connections
abstract: LAS VEGAS — “IPTV,” the shorthand for “Internet Protocol TV,” doesn’t sound all that appealing. But “connected TV” has a nice ring to it.

headline: Here Comes China’s Pension Fund
abstract: China’s $74 billion national pension fund said it has received approval to invest up to 10 percent of its assets in private equity funds, Bloomberg reported.

headline: Intrepid Postash Boosts I.P.O. Price
abstract: Fertilizer maker Intrepid Potash has boosted the size and expected price range of its proposed initial public offering, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

headline: Grasso’s Grit May Win After All
abstract: Call it the curse of Dick Grasso.

headline: Despite Break-Up, Diller Continues Shopping Spree
abstract: Barry Diller, it seems, just can’t help himself.

headline: Shareholders Advised to Back Restoration Buyout
abstract: Restoration Hardware said earlier this week that two proxy advisories had recommended shareholders vote in favor of a proposed buyout by a Catterton Partners-led group valued at $4.50 per share.

headline: Circuit City Opens Its Books to Blockbuster
abstract: Circuit City, the electronics chain, said Friday that it would allow the video rental company Blockbuster to examine its books, marking a shift from its initial, highly skeptical stance toward Blockbuster’s unsolicited takeover bid.

headline: Moody’s May Align Municipal Debt Ratings With Corporate
abstract: Criticized by states and cities for how it rates their bonds, Moody’s Investors Service said on Thursday that it was considering rating municipal debt on the same scale it uses for corporate debt.

headline: JPMorgan Campaigns for Former Bear Staff
abstract: JPMorgan Chase has launched a campaign to find jobs for more than 5,000 people who are being let go after its takeover of Bear Stearns, The Financial Times reported.

abstract: Linens ‘n Things has become one the biggest companies taken private in the recent buyout boom to land in bankruptcy court.

headline: Park the Car, Part 2
abstract: Late in the afternoon on Memorial Day, I drove from Putnam County, north of New York, to Manhattan, a trip I often take on Sunday afternoons. The weather was glorious. But I cannot recall a day when there was less traffic.

headline: BofA May Re-Cut Countrywide Deal, Analyst Says
abstract: Bank of America is likely to renegotiate its deal to buy Countrywide Financial down to the $0 to $2 level or completely walk away from it, said Friedman, Billings, Ramsey, which downgraded Countrywide to “underperform” from “market perform,” according to Reuters.

headline: A Long, Cold, Cashless Siege
abstract: For individual and institutional investors alike, auction rate securities lately have brought only pain.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Appear on ‘Colbert Report’
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton will make her first appearance on Comedy Central’s “The Colbert Report” on Thursday, the Associated Press reports. Barack Obama “has thus far declined Colbert’s invitation. Obama’s wife, Michelle, will appear on the show Tuesday.”

headline: Carlyle and TPG May Bid for Cavalli in Second Round, Report Says
abstract: The Carlyle Group, TPG and Candover are likely to bid in the second round of the auction of Italian fashion house Roberto Cavalli set for mid-July, Reuters reported.

headline: How to Brew Up a Tax-Free Sale
abstract: Years ago, there was a commercial in heavy rotation in which diners who thought they were drinking fresh-brewed coffee at the Tavern on the Green restaurant were actually quaffing Folgers instant coffee.

headline: Tennis Match Is Up For USA
abstract: Wall Street Journal: “USA Network, the longtime home of weeknight coverage of the U.S. Open Tennis Championships, will no longer televise the tournament after this year.” ESPN may pick up the rights.

headline: Bear’s Mayer Turns Down JPMorgan Offer
abstract: Jeffrey Mayer, co-head of fixed income at Bear Stearns, has reportedly turned down an offer of $27 million from JPMorgan Chase to join the bank on completion of their merger, Financial News reported.

headline: The Charitable Side of Hedge Funds
abstract: Hedge fund managers are better known for making money — scads of it — than for giving it away.

headline: And the Winner Is…Google
abstract: Microsoft and Yahoo were pushed to the brink of a multibillion-dollar marriage and then to a sudden breakup this weekend by the same player.

headline: EADS Executives Face Insider Trading Sanctions
abstract: The French financial market regulator filed a formal complaint Tuesday against European Aeronautic, Defense & Space, the parent company of Airbus, and more than a dozen current and former executives in connection with an inquiry into allegations of insider trading and other market abuses.

headline: G.M. on the Hook Again as Hedge Fund Balks at Delphi Deal
abstract: Appaloosa Management‘s decision Friday to terminate its $2.55 billion deal to invest in Delphi agreement is not only setback for Delphi but is also a blow to General Motors, which spun off the bankrupt auto-parts maker nearly a decade ago and has been paying for it since.

headline: A Deal For Yahoo May Be Nigh, Report Says
abstract: Yahoo finally looks ready to do a deal, according to BusinessWeek, which cited people familiar with the situation. Pressure from large shareholders, including Carl C. Icahn and hedge fund Paulson & Company, has persuaded Yahoo to work out a transaction with Microsoft, or alternatively, with Google, according to the magazine.

headline: China South Locomotive May Roll With I.P.O.
abstract: China South Locomotive & Rolling Stock may sell a 30 percent stake in a Shanghai initial public offering to help fund nearly 9 billion yuan ($1.3 billion) of projects, Bloomberg reported citing a company filing.

headline: Judicial Activism in Mutual Funds
abstract: My column today discusses a surprising decision by the chief judge of the Seventh U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, Frank Easterbrook, that essentially negates a section of the Investment Company Act allowing mutual fund shareholders to sue over management fees they deem to be too high.

headline: IPhone 2.0: What Might Have Been
abstract: Some Apple watchers are focused not on the new model’s innovations but on what it lacks — and the complaints can be a bit strange.

headline: News Corp. May Join Yahoo Bid With Microsoft
abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation is in talks with Microsoft about joining in its contested bid for Yahoo, according to The New York Times. The combination, which would join Yahoo, Microsoft’s MSN and News Corporation’s MySpace, would create a behemoth that would upend the Internet landscape, The Times said.

headline: Ex-Chief Executive at AT&T to Be Motorola’s Chairman
abstract: David W. Dorman, former chief executive of AT&T, will become chairman of Motorola next month as the struggling company tries to fix its slumping fortunes by splitting in two.

headline: Networks to Show Joint Cancer Research Telethon in September
abstract: “ABC, CBS and NBC have agreed to set aside the same hour of prime-time television on the first Friday night in September for a live, joint telethon benefiting cancer research,” Jacques Steinberg reports.

headline: Youth Exposure to Alcohol Marketing Still Too High, Study Says
abstract: What is planned to be the final report from a watchdog group that monitors alcohol advertising concludes that progress still lags in curbing the access of young viewers to television commercials selling liquor, beer and wine.

headline: Federated Media Said to Score Funding
abstract: Federated Media Publishing, the online blog ad network founded by John Battelle, has raised between $40 million in $50 million in Series C funding at a $200 million pre-money valuation, according to peHUB.

headline: Austria’s Bawag May Go Public Sooner Than Anticipated
abstract: Austrian bank Bawag, which is owned by a consortium headed by the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, said it is likely to be in shape for an initial public offering before its target of 2012.

headline: CBOE Settlement Clears Path to Go Public
abstract: One billion dollars later, the question of who owns the Chicago Board Options Exchange has been resolved.

headline: Fannie Mae to Raise $6 Billion After Loss
abstract: Fannie Mae, the largest provider of U.S. home financing, Tuesday reported its third straight quarterly loss as the U.S. housing crisis took another turn for the worse during the first quarter of 2008.

headline: Hormones Linked to Big Trading Profits, Study Finds
abstract: Making a profit in trading certainly requires skill, smarts and guts. Apparently, it’s also helped by hormones.

headline: Walking Toward the Dead
abstract: Mudhafer al-Husaini is an Iraqi employee of The New York Times. One hour after writing this blog he volunteered to travel to Baquba, 30 miles north of Baghdad, to report on the explosion there on Tuesday, which killed dozens of people and wounded his Iraqi colleague, who has worked for The New York Times in Diyala. The injuries were not serious.

headline: Confirmed: Sue Naegle Becomes Entertainment President at HBO
abstract: Jacques Steinberg reports: HBO said Wednesday afternoon that it had selected Sue Naegle, a Hollywood talent agent, as the president of its entertainment division, and charged her with helping the cable channel finds its next “Sopranos” and “Sex and the City.” Read more…

headline: Executive Compensation: A Brighter Spotlight, Yet the Pay Rises
abstract: Wasn’t 2008 supposed to be the year of shareholder victory on the executive compensation front?

headline: Imagining a Public Law Firm’s Earnings Report
abstract: Nearly a year after an Australian law firm went public, many in the legal profession are still tittering over whether any American players would follow suit.

headline: Monday Ratings: Weak ‘Gladiators’
abstract: “American Gladiators,” NBC’s surprise hit during the writers’ strike, made a disappointing return to network television on Monday after a three-month hiatus, drawing just 4.9 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Early Into the Summer Season, ‘Notable Ratings Dips’ For Broadcasters
abstract: The broadcast networks are experiencing a sluggish start to the summer season.

headline: I.P.O. Planned for Magapolitan
abstract: Indonesia property company PT Megapolitan Developments has said it will launch an initial public offering this year to sell 30 percent of its shares worth about $44 million.

headline: Analyst Sees More Pain Ahead for Banks
abstract: James Dimon, the head of the banking giant JPMorgan Chase, recently estimated that the credit crunch was about 75 percent over. But Meredith Whitney, the head of equity research at Oppenheimer, believes that it will extend well into 2009 and perhaps beyond that.

headline: ‘Grand Theft Auto’ Sales May Be Nasty Surprise for EA
abstract: Electronic Arts‘ $26 a share hostile bid for rival video game maker Take-Two Interactive could get a whole lot pricier if a report last week predicting blockbuster sales for Take-Two’s upcoming release of “Grand Theft Auto IV” proves correct.

headline: Meriwether Lets Clients Withdraw Funds Early
abstract: John Meriwether, founder of the hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management that imploded at the end of the ’90s, has run into trouble with his latest business.

headline: Kinetic Concepts to Offer $51 a Share for Lifecell
abstract: Kinetic Concepts, a medical technology company, said Monday that it has agreed to buy Lifecell, a maker of tissue repair products, for $1.7 billion in cash via a tender offer. At $51 a share, the deal represents an 18 percent premium over Lifestyle’s closing stock price on Friday and a 26 percent premium over its 90-day volume-weighted average trading price.

headline: Citigroup Director Expected to Quit Key Committee
abstract: The chairman of Citigroup‘s audit and risk committee, C. Michael Armstrong, who has overseen more than $22 billion in write-offs, is poised to resign from that post under pressure from shareholders, The New York Times reported.

headline: A Tentative Pact for Pilots of Merging Airlines
abstract: Negotiators for pilots at Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines said Tuesday that they had a tentative agreement with Delta management on a joint contract to cover both pilot groups when the companies combine later this year.

headline: Jeffrey Epstein’s Other Headache
abstract: Jeffrey Epstein, an intensely private money manager with billionaire clients, has been caught up in a highly public scandal involving massages with teenage girls.

headline: An Architect of the CVS Deal Will Start a Turnaround Firm
abstract: The former chief of Caremark Rx who orchestrated its $26.5 billion sale last year to the drugstore chain CVS is getting into the deal business full time.

headline: Energy Recovery Files for $175 Million I.P.O.
abstract: Energy Recovery, a maker of energy recovery devices for the water desalinization industry, filed for an initial public offering for as much as $175 million.

headline: Illinois State Agency Makes Another Bid for Wrigley Field
abstract: Although an Illinois state agency will step up with a revised proposal to buy Wrigley Field, home of The Chicago Cubs, from the Tribune Company, the chances of such a deal succeeding appear to be waning, according to The Chicago Tribune.

headline: CNN Schedules Values Forum With Candidates
abstract: Reuters reports (via THR):

headline: The Next Buyout Lawsuit
abstract: We’ve entered into a postmodern stage in private equity buyouts.

headline: The Mosley poll
abstract: No sooner did I write down my rambling thoughts yesterday than Mosley has told the Sunday Telegraph today that he would like to resign as president of the International Automobile Federation next year after completing his term.

headline: Should Google Buy Salesforce.com?
abstract: If Google is serious about selling business applications, it may need to make a major acquisition to catalyze that effort. Two analysts at The 451 Group present their point of view on why Salesforce.com would be one of the better targets — though an expensive one.

headline: One Bear Stearns Hedge Fund Seems to be Getting It Right
abstract: Investment bank Bear Stearns may have hit rough times but at least one of its hedge funds, the $1.2 billion Emerging Markets Macro Fund, is bouncing back from earlier losses this year.

headline: Merrill May Throw Out Election System
abstract: In an effort to win points with disgruntled shareholders, Merrill Lynch‘s board may adopt a measure that would make the directors more vulnerable to future efforts to oust them, The New York Post reported.

headline: Reed Calls Citigroup Deal a ‘Mistake’
abstract: Ten years after the fateful marriage of Citicorp and Travelers, the financial behemoth that emerged, Citigroup, looks like a “sad story.”

headline: Some Questions About Those Commitment Letters
abstract: The report today is that Anheuser Busch is going to reject the InBev offer. InBev will now have to decide whether it will launch a consent solicitation to remove all of the Anheuser directors. This can be done at any time. Alternatively, at the request of 25% of Anheuser’s shareholders a special meeting of Anheuser shareholders can be held. So, InBev can also go this route and remove the Anheuser directors at the special meeting if they can get enough shareholder support for it to be called. I suspect that if InBev does attempt to remove and replace the Anheuser directors, InBev will arrange a consent solicitation rather than attempting to call a special meeting: it is quicker.

headline: New on ABC: To Catch an Illegal Alien
abstract: First there were “Cops” on Fox. Soon there may be border patrol agents on ABC.

headline: Yahoo Stock Falls 20% in Early Trading
abstract: Some of Jerry Yang’s top lieutenants at Yahoo reportedly cheered on Saturday when Microsoft pulled its unsolicited bid for the company. But Mr. Yang’s net worth is taking a hit as a result: The market value of his 3.9 percent Yahoo stake plunged by more than $300 million Monday morning, as much of the premium in Yahoo’s stock evaporated.

headline: Banks Said to Prepare Sale of Alliance Boots Debt
abstract: Investment banks are poised to agree a plan to sell much of the 9 billion pounds ($17 billion) debt in Alliance Boots, the private equity-owned pharmacy chain, providing a crucial test of improving conditions in loan markets, The Financial Times reported.

headline: UBS Faces More Trouble With Mortgage Securities
abstract: Lehman Brothers may have drawn the lion’s share of concern on Monday, but UBS remains a big worry for financial investors as well, The Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday.

headline: Why There Aren’t More Flips
abstract: Software and hardware makers often feel they have to pile on the features — much to the chagrin of the users.

headline: Deutsche Telekom Suffers 2 Legal Setbacks
abstract: Deutsche Telekom came under fire Thursday in Germany on two fronts, losing a legal bid to block competitors from gaining low-cost access to its network, and becoming the target of a separate antitrust investigation.

headline: First Day Success for Indian Companies May Signal Revived Investor Interest
abstract: Anu’s Laboratories and Gokul Refoils & Solvent gained on their first day of trading in Mumbai, following the slowest month for initial share sales in two years, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Another CEO Gone
abstract: Give Wachovia’s board credit for honesty. The board fired Ken Thompson, who had been chief executive since 2001, and did not mince words in explaining why he was leaving.

headline: Former Hedge Fund Manager Settles S.E.C. Charges
abstract: A hedge fund and its former manager have agreed to pay more than $1 million for trading on inside information surrounding Citizens Bank‘s $10.5 billion purchase of Charter One.

headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

headline: Economy Hits U.S. PC Sales, but Notebook Growth Remains Strong
abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

headline: Amazon Gains Share of Shrinking Paid Music Market
abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

headline: Yahoo’s Starting Point: A Clearer Strategy
abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

headline: The Network That AT&T’s Growing Profits Will Buy
abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

headline: Clinton’s High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

headline: The iPhone Shortage
abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: Google-Yahoo Test Gets Justice Dept. Questions
abstract: Google and Yahoo said Wednesday that they notified the Justice Department before the start of a joint search advertising test that could lead to a broader partnership between the two companies. The two Internet giants also said they have answered questions from Justice Department officials about their arrangement.

headline: Those Intense iPhone Users
abstract: IPhone users are not like the rest of cellphone users. A study says 37 percent of iPhone users watch video (ten times more than the average cellphone user), 20 percent play online games (nine time more than average) and 33 percent send instant messages (three times more than average).

headline: New Fare from CBS: Password, Dogs, Advertising Jingles
abstract: “Big Brother,” hosted by Julie Chen (above), will return to CBS in July.

headline: Sprint and T-Mobile? Hold the Phone
abstract: Sprint Nextel‘s stock rose more than 6 percent Monday morning following reports that Deutsche Telekom was considering buying it — but investors might want to be wary.

headline: MTV Adapts to Ratings System for Commercials
abstract: Once a skeptic, MTV Networks has become a convert to commercial ratings.

headline: ‘Survivor': Exhausted?
abstract: “Survivor: Micronesia,” the sixteenth edition of the CBS franchise, ended on Sunday, drawing the lowest ratings ever for a season finale of the 8-year-old series. The episode drew an average of 12.9 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates, coming up just short of the previous lowest rated finale in the franchise, last year’s conclusion of “Survivor: Fiji” in May (13.6 million).

headline: UBS Said to Hire Lazard; Is a Sale in Its Future?
abstract: Investors seem to think UBS has something up its sleeve — and it may be a sale of some kind.

headline: United and US Airways Said to Be Closer to a Deal
abstract: United Airlines is closing in on a merger with US Airways, after being spurned by Continental Airlines and Delta Air Lines, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: Steaz Gets $11 Million for Organic Drinks
abstract: The Healthy Beverage Company, which operates under the trade name Steaz, has raised $11 million for fairly traded, organic teas, VentureBeat reported. The funding was provided by Inventages Venture Capital and Whitefish Group, the publication said.

headline: Justin Timberlake to Produce MTV Reality Show
abstract: “Youth-oriented cable television network MTV said on Friday it will air a new reality game show called ‘The Phone’ to be executive-produced by pop star Justin Timberlake,” Reuters reports.

headline: Talk May Be Cheap, But It May Be More Effective Offline
abstract: For the second time in a week, a study has been released that concludes that the word-of-mouth conversations generated offline may be deemed more credible and positive by consumers than those conversations held online.

headline: Dubai World Offers $5.34 Billion for OGK-1
abstract: Looking to profit from the breakup of Russia’s national power monopoly and the demise of regulated electricity prices, Dubai World and Roskommunenergo have offered to buy Russian utility OGK-1 for 125 billion rubles ($5.34 billion).

headline: Shipping Chief to Open New Green Fund
abstract: Amid spiking interest in green technology, the head of three shipping and energy companies plans to announce on Tuesday a new investment fund focusing on environmentally friendly developments in the maritime and clean energy sectors.

headline: Is Clinton Biting Wall Street’s Hand?
abstract: As the Democratic presidential primary drags on, Hillary Rodham Clinton has fired warning shots across Wall Street’s bow.

headline: Abu Dhabi Fund Still Sees U.S. as ‘Attractive’
abstract: Executives from the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, the Mideast sovereign wealth fund that invested $7.5 billion in Citigroup last year, talked to BusinessWeek about the fund’s strategy and investment outlook.

headline: Analyzing CBS’s Ratings Slump
abstract: For CBS, the bad news doesn’t end with the “Evening News,” The New York Times reports. The network, like other broadcasters, have suffered serious losses this year:

headline: Icahn Wants New Chief for Yahoo
abstract: The investor Carl C. Icahn stepped up the pressure on Yahoo on Tuesday, vowing to remove Jerry Yang, its chief executive, if he succeeds in replacing the company’s board with his own slate of directors.

headline: EA Extends Deadline for Take-Two Offer
abstract: Video game publisher Electronic Arts on Friday extended by nearly a month its tender offer for Take-Two Interactive Software, but also lowered the price it will pay for each share of the ”Grand Theft Auto” maker.

headline: CBS To Buy CNET Networks
abstract: “CBS said Thursday it would buy CNET Networks for $1.8 billion in cash, marking its biggest online acquisition since hiring Quincy Smith, a former media and technology investment banker, to lead its interactive unit in late 2006,” Dealbook reports.

headline: Will a Hedge Fund Take Control of TVT Records?
abstract: D.B. Zwirn & Company is a leading contender to win the upcoming bankruptcy auction of TVT Records, the record label known for its stable of rap and hip-hop artists.

headline: Greenhill to Start Fund Placement Group
abstract: As the vestiges of the last private equity boom appear to be wrapped up, Greenhill & Company seems to be betting on a resurgence of the buyout industry.

headline: BlackRock to the Rescue
abstract: One Saturday morning in March, Laurence D. Fink got some urgent news: Wall Street needed his help.

headline: BHP Asks Australian Regulator for Rio Tinto Approval
abstract: Pursuing its $167 billion takeover of Rio Tinto Group, BHP Billiton has made a submission to the Australian competition regulator seeking approval for the hostile bid, Bloomberg reported.

headline: Wendy’s Rejects Peltz Bids
abstract: Nelson Peltz’s Trian Partners said in a regulatory filing Friday that Wendy’s International had rejected two offers to be purchased, prompting it to seek a special shareholder meeting.

headline: Traditional Media Not Dead Yet for Marketing, Study Says
abstract: A study to be released on Wednesday finds that advertisements appearing in traditional media like television are still “much more likely” to have made a positive impression with consumers than ads running in digital media.

headline: Macau Casino Giant Said to Seek I.P.O.
abstract: SJM Holdings, Macau’s largest casino operator, may raise as much as 5.1 billion Hong Kong dollars ($653 million) from a share sale repeatedly delayed by a dispute between billionaire Stanley Ho and his sister Winnie, according to press reports.

headline: When a Founder Becomes a Footnote
abstract: He put the ‘Gomez’ in Gomez Inc., but now an Internet entrepreneur finds himself relegated to the fine print.

headline: Icahn Said to Prepare Fight at Yahoo
abstract: Carl C. Icahn may have set his sights on his latest target: Yahoo.

headline: Citigroup Fund Flies With Airport Investment
abstract: Citigroup‘s infrastructure fund has purchased a 50 percent stake in Canda’s YVR Airport Services, as part of its push to invest in airports worldwide, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: HD Enthusiasts Crying Foul Over Cable TV’s Crunched Signals
abstract: As cable TV companies pack ever more HD channels into limited bandwidth, some owners of pricey plasma, projector and LCD TVs are complaining that they’re not getting the high-def quality they paid for, the Associated Press reports. They blame the increased signal compression being used to squeeze three digital HD signals into the bandwidth of one analog station.

headline: Goldman Funds Said to Make Comeback
abstract: Two large hedge funds run by Goldman Sachs have rebounded so far this year after big losses in 2007, according to MarketWatch.

headline: The Man at the Helm of China’s Sovereign Fund
abstract: Should sovereign wealth funds be feared? Analysts, lawmakers and reporters have mined that topic for nearly six months now, as these government-owned investment firms propped up ailing Western banks during the brunt of the subprime mortgage crisis.

headline: A Quiet Call for BofA’s Chief
abstract: Bank of America‘s chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, appeared humbled by the bank’s third consecutive drop in quarterly earnings, telling investors on a conference call that “the current environment is the most challenging I have dealt with.”

headline: Compliance Week Magazine Is Sold
abstract: Haymarket Media has agreed to buy Compliance Week magazine from Financial Media Holdings Group for an undisclosed price. Haymarket’s parent company, a privately held group based in the United Kingdom, owns about 100 magazines, including PR Week and Management Today.

headline: Citi Reshuffles Communications Office
abstract: Citigroup on Thursday announced a reshuffling of its marketing and communications office under Lisa Caputo, its chief marketing officer. The bank also said that it has appointed a new head of corporate communications, replacing Leah Johnson, who resigned last month.

headline: Ex-Big Board Chairman Wins Round in Pay Fight
abstract: On Wall Street, there are stars that fade and stars that fight. Richard A. Grasso is one of the latter.

headline: Proxy Advisory Support Helps Countrywide, a Little
abstract: Countrywide Financial hasn’t had much good news in months, and this week was mostly no exception. (For starters, a connection to Countrywide founder Angelo R. Mozilo helped lead to the ouster of James A. Johnson from Barack Obama’s campaign.) And its stock has fallen more than 7.5 percent this week.

headline: Wachovia Hires Goldman to Advise on Loan Portfolio
abstract: Wachovia, it appears, really values Goldman Sachs. The bank has hired the Wall Street investment firm for advice on its loan portfolio.

headline: Mergers Accelerate as Telecoms Seek Growth
abstract: A multibillion-dollar telecommunications merger was announced Thursday, reflecting a trend for mobile phone operators to consolidate in their own crowded backyards while they scout for growth in emerging economies.

headline: Pandit Calls for Debate on Financial Regulations
abstract: Citigroup‘s chief executive, Vikram Pandit, on Tuesday called for a “vigorous” debate on regulatory oversight as the crisis in the financial services industry continues, Dow Jones Newswires reported.

headline: Nielsen to Buy Audience Research Firm IAG
abstract: Reuters reports: “Nielsen Co, a provider of market research and media services, said it agreed to acquire IAG Research Inc, a television and Internet audience research firm, for $225 million to strengthen its media business.”

headline: Andy Grove Offers an Energy Solution
abstract: There are parallels between the challenge faced by the automotive industry and lessons Andy Grove learned in the PC industry: “As with PCs, the work of advocates and hobbyists shows the way out of this dilemma.”

headline: The Rights Issue
abstract: Rights issues are all the rage. The Royal Bank of Scotland just announced a nearly $24 billion rights offering to shore up its capital base. And last week, Blockbuster made a $1.35 billion all-cash offer to buy Circuit City, part of which would be financed by a rights offering.

headline: You Probably Weren’t Watching, But…
abstract: For reasons that aren’t entirely clear, Sunday night’s ratings were the lowest for the five broadcast television networks since Christmas Eve 2006.

headline: Lichtenstein’s Steel Partners Ousts Board of Japan’s Aderans
abstract: Steel Partners, the hedge fund run by activist investor Warren G. Lichtenstein, helped oust most of the board of Japanese wig maker Aderans Holdings on Thursday, the first time management of a Japanese firm has been ejected under pressure from an activist fund.

headline: Side-by-Side: When the President Meets Reality
abstract: 2006: In the film “American Dreamz,” Dennis Quaid plays President Staton, a commander in chief nearing the end of his term who turns to a popular television program, a reality show called “American Dreamz,” to “pump his sagging ratings.”

headline: Aquiline to Introduce New Commercial Finance Firm
abstract: Aquiline Capital Partners, the private equity firm run by former Marsh & McLennan chief Jeffrey Greenberg, will announce Tuesday that it has formed a new commercial finance firm with more than $1.75 billion in equity commitments.

headline: Merrill Said to Raise $6 Billion Buyout Fund
abstract: Merrill Lynch is raising a $6 billion private equity fund, according TheStreet.com, which cited a pitch to an investor earlier this year.

headline: Fed Approves JPMorgan’s Bear Deal
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board on Tuesday formally gave its approval to JPMorgan Chase to purchase a banking unit of Bear Stearns.

headline: Monday Night Was a Dead Heat for Viewers
abstract: In a low-rated Monday night of network television filled with mostly summer repeats and reality fare, CBS, ABC, and Fox finished in a virtual dead heat for first place in the ratings during prime time.

headline: Iraq Briefing
abstract: A selection of articles from many sources on Iraq. For more, see the Baghdad Bureau blog’s Google Reader Shared Items.

headline: Thompson Is Ousted as Wachovia Chief Executive
abstract: G. Kennedy Thompson, the head of Wachovia, on Monday became the latest banking executive to be shown the door during the credit squeeze, as Wachovia‘s board requested that he step down amid a stock slide and a series of losses.

headline: Jury Acquits Stockbroker in Gym Assault Case
abstract: From our colleagues at City Room:

headline: Looking Up, but From a Deep Hole
abstract: A massive round of capital raising from sovereign wealth funds and other investors has kept big banks afloat. And although some of Wall Street chieftains are now predicting the worst is over, The New York Times’ Floyd Norris wonders if the optimism isn’t overdone.

headline: Lotte Takes Cosmo Stake
abstract: The Lotte Group has agreed to buy more than 50 percent of Cosmo Investment Management, South Korea’s largest investment consulting firm, from Japan’s Sparx Group.

headline: The Sundance Subplot: Taxes
abstract: Cablevision has announced a couple of purchases lately that made many analysts scratch their heads and ask, “Why?” The cable company’s $650 million purchase of Newsday, the Long Island, N.Y., daily newspaper, was one. The other was its $496 million deal to buy the Sundance Channel, known for airing independent films, from a group including General Electric‘s NBC Universal unit.

headline: Delta and Northwest in $3 Billion Deal
abstract: Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines agreed to merge late Monday, in a $3.1 billion deal that would create the world’s biggest airline and could prompt other airlines to pursue mergers of their own.

headline: Virgin Green Fund Raises $199 Million
abstract: Virgin Group‘s first green investment fund has attracted the interest of such maiden investors Wolverhampton City Council and Calpers, The Financial Times reported.

headline: A Clear Channel Surprise
abstract: There has been a surprising development in the dispute over the buyout of Clear Channel Communications: In a letter to the would-be private equity buyers, lawyers for the lending group have proposed using binding arbitration to set the final terms for funding the $19.5 billion transaction. If that occurred, it would mark a resolution of the matter in which Clear Channel, the largest radio broadcaster in the United States, is taken private at the originally agreed-upon price.

headline: On Paper, Wall Street Gets Its Way
abstract: More than a year ago, when the markets were flying high, a chorus of alarm went up on Wall Street. Talk spread that the United States risked losing its edge in the financial world.

headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

headline: Economy Hits U.S. PC Sales, but Notebook Growth Remains Strong
abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

headline: Yahoo’s Starting Point: A Clearer Strategy
abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

headline: The Network That AT&T’s Growing Profits Will Buy
abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

headline: Clinton’s High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: Microsoft Hires Firm to Lobby for Yahoo Deal
abstract: Microsoft has yet to persuade Yahoo to agree to a friendly takeover, but the software company is already hiring lobbyists to help it persuade regulators to let the deal go through, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Pressure on Times Co. May Rise After Poor Results
abstract: After The New York Times Company posted a $335,000 loss in the first quarter – one of the worst periods the company and the newspaper industry have seen – industry observers are betting that two activist hedge funds may ratchet up the pressure on the newspaper publisher.

headline: We Like ‘Filthy’ and ‘Rich,’ But…
abstract: The CW has been developing a series based on the book “How to Teach Filthy Rich Girls” for months. But this week, the name of the show was abruptly changed.

headline: Big Changes Coming to Profile Pages on Facebook
abstract: Facebook prepares significant changes to the heart of its service: user profile pages.

headline: Deal Volume Falls, but Corporate Buyers Keep Rising
abstract: Already, one report has noted doom and gloom in the deal-making world. Now Dealogic is adding its own take on the slump that has overtaken the world of mergers and acquisitions.

headline: Trouble in Financials Drags Down Shares
abstract: Wall Street sank Wednesday for the second consecutive day in part on renewed concerns about the financial sector.

headline: Take-Two’s Managers Get a Raise and E.A. Cries Foul
abstract: Shareholders of Take-Two Interactive gave the company’s management a hefty raise Thursday as part of a compensation package that would grow considerably should the video game company be acquired by Electronic Arts.

headline: Enron’s Skilling Asks Court to Overturn His Conviction
abstract: Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron who was convicted for his role in the company’s collapse, took risks when he ran the company but they were always for its benefit, his lawyer told an appeals court Wednesday.

headline: Verso Shares Fall in Market Debut
abstract: Shares of Verso Paper, a company backed by private equity firm Apollo Management, fell 17 percent in their market debut Thursday. The company had already cut the number and expected price of shares to be sold.

headline: Who Needs a Mortgage Anyway?
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: Yahoo Shareholder Proposes Compromise on Icahn Slate
abstract: Dissident Yahoo investor Eric Jackson urged fellow shareholders on Monday to vote for a board comprising five existing directors and four nominees from billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn’s slate.

headline: Goldman Sachs Said to Take Stake In Claren Road
abstract: A private equity fund of Goldman Sachs has added another hedge fund investment to its portfolio, Dow Jones reported, marking the third stakebuilding in a hedge fund firm this week by a bank or asset manager.

headline: Delta and Northwest Win Approval for Transatlantic Cooperation
abstract: Northwest Airlines and Delta Air Lines, which last month announced plans to combine, on Thursday won final federal approval to share revenue and coordinate schedules across the Atlantic.

abstract: I need to make a quick Web site — is there any downside to using one of the free site-creation services instead of finding a Web host and getting someone to design the pages?

headline: An Interview With President Ma Ying-jeou
abstract: An edited transcript of an interview between Keith Bradsher and Edward Wong of The New York Times, Leonard M. Apcar of The International Herald Tribune, and President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan.

headline: Help for Ailing Memory Cards
abstract: I’m having trouble getting certain photos off my digital camera. Is it possible that the camera’s memory card has gone bad?

abstract: I’d like to convert text in an e-mail message from capital letters to standard uppercase and lowercase letters. Is there a way to do this, or am I stuck retyping?
