abstract: The race turns in large part on the personalities of the leading candidates, both of whom provoke high passions.

abstract: David Barstow is answering readers’ questions on his article about the Pentagon’s effort to use military analysts to generate favorable news coverage.

abstract: Outlook Express is set to save my e-mail password and now I do not remember it. Is there an easy way I can find out what it is?

abstract: India and Malaysia risked the wrath of voters by raising the price of subsidized fuel, measures that could further weaken the governments of both countries.

abstract: Farmers resumed their national strike after the government broke off talks over a controversial export tax.

headline: Chemical Maker Files Suit to Block Its $10.6 Billion Merger
abstract: Hexion Specialty Chemicals, a chemical maker owned by the buyout firm Apollo Management, sued the Huntsman Corporation to end their $10.6 billion merger.

headline: Correction
abstract: An article on April 10 about possible disruptions to air passengers because of a federal directive on aircraft inspections misspelled part of the name of the firm for which L. Nick Lacey, a former director of flight standards at the Federal Aviation Administration, now works. And a correction in this space on Wednesday rendered the firm’s name incorrectly and misidentified the nature of its business. It is Morten Beyer & Agnew  not Morton, Beyer & Agnew  and it is an airline consulting firm, not a law firm. (The name contains no comma. Morten Beyer is a senior adviser in the firm, not the surnames of two associates.)

headline: Produced in Champagne, but What Do You Call It?

headline: Russia Close to Privatizing Huge Electricity Producer
abstract: A plan to privatize the world’s largest electricity company is entering the home stretch, successfully it seems, in spite of its complexity and the hostility toward privatization in today’s Russia.

abstract: The American Bible Society said its president and chief financial officer had been placed on temporary leave following reports of payments made to a contractor with ties to online pornography.

abstract: An important aspect of sound portfolio management is to look at how to maximize certain accounts’ tax-sheltering quality relative to the type of assets you are holding.

headline: Russia: Natural Gas Partnership
abstract: Gazprom of Russia, the natural gas producer, and Eni of Italy are preparing to join forces to pipe natural gas from Libya across the Mediterranean to Southern Europe. The deal would enable Russia to increase Europe’s dependence on Gazprom, which is state controlled. Paolo Scaroni, left, chief executive of Eni, said the deal with Gazprom would involve “the swap of assets outside of Russia.” Russia already supplies more than a quarter of Western Europe’s energy needs. Some analysts said that if Gazprom succeeded in Libya and in Algeria, where it is competing for contracts, it could end up dominating the supply routes to Southern Europe.

headline: In Lean Times, Biotech Grains Are Less Taboo

abstract: The earthquake of a preliminary magnitude of 6.5 also injured dozens and damaged scores of homes.

abstract: Doah Mohammed played a trick on her mother-in law on Tuesday. She called her and told her that her son, Ms. Mohammed’s husband, had been arrested.

abstract: The black truffle is under threat from climate change, according to Jean-Charles Savignac, president of the Fédération Française des Trufficulteurs.

abstract: Canon’s iP100 Mobile Printer, available this week for $249, has a flat shape that lets it fit into a briefcase or its modern counterpart, the messenger bag.

abstract: A consortium plans to build the first of a new generation of nationwide wireless data networks in a $14.5 billion deal.

abstract: The leader of the youth league of South Africa’s governing party said the party was ready “to take up arms and kill for” the party’s president.

abstract: Thousands of people tried to evacuate the Sichuan provincial capital after a televised warning of a possible severe aftershock.

abstract: The deal comes months after Visa paid more than $2.1 billion to American Express over similar antitrust claims.

abstract: The bombings extended a pattern of attacks that are clearly intended to kill local Iraqi leaders, in particular those believed to have worked with American forces against insurgents.

She is Teri Everett, not Everette.

headline: Today in Business

abstract: Investigators say they have found blueprints for an advanced nuclear weapon on computers belonging to a Pakistani nuclear scientist’s smuggling network.

abstract: Shares of both Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines slid following the announcement of the merger and Northwest pilots vowed to kill the $2.7 billion deal.

abstract: Frontier, the latest budget carrier to seek bankruptcy protection, said it will maintain its operations.

headline: Letters: The Power of Words at the Federal Reserve
abstract: Letter related to “Two Bubbles, Two Paths” (Economic View, June 15.)

abstract: The tentative contract agreement would not create a lower wage rate scale for newly hired employees but would impose wage freezes and trim some benefits.

abstract: Two blasts ripped through a street in Diyala, and a car bomb in Baghdad killed a U.S. soldier and nine civilians.

abstract: News about airlines and airports.

abstract: India’s supply of arable land is second only to that of the U.S., but it must buy some foods on international markets, exacerbating a global food crisis.

abstract: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said that four Navy ships waiting to deliver aid would probably be withdrawn soon.

headline: South Korea to Resume Importing American Beef

abstract: Manufacturers are increasingly embedding accelerometers and other sensors into machines, which allow them to respond to movement without waiting for their humans to push a button.

abstract: What employee manuals on health insurance, taxes and retirement plans should say, but don’t.

abstract: The causes of the convergence between Iran and the United States boil down to the logic of self-interest.

headline: Doubts Greet Treasury Plan on Regulation
abstract: Lawmakers and lobbyists from industries opposed to the plan predicted that most of it would be dead on arrival.

headline: Philippines Introduces Cash Subsidies and Cheaper Rice for the Poor
abstract: The government has set in motion an unprecedented relief program and will distribute “rice passes” to the most impoverished families reeling from high food prices.

abstract: Democrats and Republicans are laying the groundwork for the coming Congressional testimony of Gen. David H. Petraeus and Ryan C. Crocker, the American ambassador in Iraq.

abstract: An ambitious experiment to save Medicare dollars is proving how difficult it can be to change the program.

abstract: IN THE LATEST setback to its recovery program, Airbus, the airplane manufacturer, said tighter credit and the weakening dollar had forced it to break off talks over the sale of European factories. NICOLA CLARK.

abstract: A former Roman Catholic bishop and self-styled champion of the poor broke a 62-year grip on the presidency by the longest-serving political party in the world.

abstract: Alcatel-Lucent shareholders, meeting in Paris, voted to make it easier for board members to dismiss and appoint the chief executive and chairman.

abstract: Prime Minister Fouad Siniora, left, was reappointed for another year despite his deep unpopularity with the Hezbollah-led opposition.

abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

abstract: A Syrian cabinet minister said Israel’s premier had indicated that Israel would be willing to withdraw from all the Golan Heights in return for peace with Syria.

abstract: Disklavier’s Mark IV is the first piano with an Internet connection and includes a variety of tricks.

headline: Another Beltway Institution Seeks New Leader

Mr. Shakur was shot five times; he was not murdered. (He died in September 1996 of multiple gunshot wounds suffered in a drive-by shooting.).

abstract: The 1970s song-and-dance television show has just been purchased, with plans to open up its archives for older viewers and to create a new version of the program for younger ones.

Ford plans to increase capacity at the Vsevolozhsk plant near St. Petersburg to 125,000 vehicles next year, a spokeswoman in Moscow, Ekaterina Kulinenko, said. The factory produces the Focus hatchback, Russia’s best-selling foreign-brand car in 2007, and will start making the midsize Mondeo this year, Ms. Kulinenko said.

abstract: Japan’s salarymen have borne the brunt of its economic decline, enduring lower wages, job insecurity and long hours of unpaid overtime. Now, a few are fighting back.

abstract: Royal Bank of Scotland became the latest lender to seek new funds to cover its soured investments, saying it would sell $23.8 billion of new shares to current investors.

headline: Wilber Hardee Dies at 89; Founded Restaurants

headline: Citigroup May Sell Its German Banking Business
abstract: Citigroup may sell Citibank Privatkunden, its consumer-banking unit in Germany, as part of a plan to replenish capital, the unit, based in Düsseldorf, said.

abstract: The royal past is being slowly rubbed away across the onetime Hindu kingdom of Nepal as the country prepares for a vote for a special assembly to rewrite the Constitution.

abstract: If a merger deal is not completed in the next three weeks, Microsoft warned, it will make its offer directly to Yahoo shareholders.

abstract: President Bush on Thursday proposed an additional $770 million in emergency food assistance for poor countries, responding to rising food prices that have brought social unrest in several nations.

abstract: E-mails attached to the Massachusetts complaint against UBS accusing it of defrauding investors support accusations in stunning black and white.

abstract: Emergency relief officials have created 50 evacuation routes and everyone in danger, they say, is within two miles of higher ground.

abstract: To the Editor:.

abstract: Critics of the government, and of Vladimir V. Putin, have been placed on a roster of individuals barred from TV news and talk shows.

abstract: War and hardship have not destroyed all of Iraq’s dreams for international competition. The country, which has been in three wars in two decades, has a robust Paralympic team.

abstract: Relief agencies said Monday that they were still having difficulty reaching hundreds of thousands of cyclone survivors who are in urgent need of assistance.

abstract: With oil at $130 a barrel, airline losses mounting, and most of the realistic revenue-raising ideas exhausted, all the airlines can do is to shrink the system and hope for the best.

abstract: To the Editor:.

headline: Amazon Gains Share of Shrinking Paid Music Market
abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

abstract: Shareholders approved a set of measures to raise capital, namely a rights offer of about $15 billion, and elected two new members to the executive board.

abstract: Arguments about global warming have become so bitter and passionate that they can divide families. Even the Rockefellers.

headline: Correction

While the grandfather was indeed hired by Ford in 1914, he did not immediately work at its Rouge plant. (The plant’s construction did not begin until 1917.).

abstract: As shares in Bell Canada declined, many investors and analysts turned their attention to alternatives for the company should its $51.8 billion privatization fail.

abstract: The actor was sentenced to a maximum of three years in federal prison for three misdemeanor convictions of failure to file his income taxes.

It is Atlanta — not Louisville, Ky., site of U.P.S.’s air hub.

headline: A Web Shift in the Way Advertisers Seek Clicks

France will take over the European Union’s six-month rotating presidency on July 1, putting the country in charge of the 27-nation bloc during the Olympic Games.

The shipments are part of a broad effort to alleviate the impact of the worst drought in the region of Catalonia in decades. Fountains and beach showers have been turned off in Barcelona, and residents have been told not to water their gardens. The government will charter ships through October if the drought does not end, a spokesman for the regional environment department said.

headline: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
abstract: The Abroad column on Tuesday, about the future of Tempelhof Airport in Berlin, misstated the percentage of Berliners who voted in a nonbinding referendum on whether to keep the airport open, and misstated a requirement for the proposal’s approval. About 36 percent of eligible voters took part, not 22 percent. Approval required a “yes” vote from at least 25 percent of eligible voters, not a turnout of 25 percent of eligible voters. (While a large majority of those taking part, as the column noted, voted to keep it open, those votes came from only about 22 percent of eligible voters, short of the requirement.).

abstract: Following is the text of a letter sent by the billionaire investor, Carl Icahn, to the chairman of Yahoo, Roy Bostock, on Thursday in which Mr. Icahn announced plans to start a proxy fight for Yahoo.

headline: France: Caesar Was Ambitious, and Perhaps Worried
abstract: An excavation near Arles has found what is thought to be the only surviving bust made of Julius Caesar during his lifetime, the newspaper Le Monde reported.

headline: A Rock Star, Finally
abstract: Mr. Haraguchi is Chief executive of Konica Minolta Business Solutions U.S.A.

headline: Urban Baby’s Lesson: Don’t Mess With Mom’s Chat
abstract: The site’s devoted fan base sent in a flurry of complaints about its new color scheme, message board system, and new default settings, but the fans are still logging on.

headline: The Road to Ikea
abstract: Pernille Lopez is the president of Ikea North America.

headline: Roadside Oddities
abstract: A writer singled out attention-grabbing roadside curiosities worth visiting, from a giant ball of twine in Kansas to a 33-foot-tall office chair in Alabama.

headline: Keep It Short, Make It Instant
abstract: A study shows that instant messaging causes less interruption than other forms of communication, such as phone calls or e-mails.

headline: Paying Off the Debts That Seem Unshakeable
abstract: The ultimate gain of getting rid of the very last of your debt, even if it means temporarily derailing a savings plan you have put in place, is not financial but peace of mind.

headline: British PM Dealt Blow in By-Election Defeat
abstract: The main opposition Conservative Party won a key by-election victory in northwest England Friday, dealing a fresh blow to beleaguered Prime Minister Gordon Brown.

headline: Mittal Said to Consider Bidding for Rio Tinto
abstract: Lakshmi Mittal is looking at entering the takeover battle for the Rio Tinto mining group, The Financial Times reported on Monday, quoting people familiar with the situation.

headline: Prince Charles Creates £1 Billion Fund
abstract: Britain’s Prince Charles has coordinated a team of property executives to run a 1 billion pound ($1.99 billion) fund to invest in sustainable developments across the nation’s urban areas, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Seattle Venture Firm Stays Active
abstract: OVP Venture Partners is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year, but the Seattle venture firm apparently isn’t slowing down as it gets on in years.

headline: A Pullback for Spacs?
abstract: Special-purpose acquisition companies, whose popularity has surged in the last few years, could be poised to take a breather in 2008, according to new research cited by Investment Dealers’ Digest.

headline: Carphone and Best Buy Strike $2.2 Billion Deal
abstract: Britain’s Carphone Warehouse will sell a 50 percent stake in its retail unit to U.S. electronics chain Best Buy for 1.1 billion pounds ($2.2 billion) and they will launch a new company to expand across Europe.

headline: Hedge Funds to Back Barclays Bid for $8.9 Billion
abstract: The $8.9 billion that Barclays plans to raise will be backed by several of London’s largest hedge funds, The Financial Times reported citing a prospectus issued by the bank on Thursday. But an analyst said that fundraising round may not be enough.

headline: Navios Maritime Seeks $220 Million in Spac I.P.O.
abstract: Navios Maritime Acquisition, a special purpose acquisition company seeking investments in transportation and logistics industries, on Tuesday filed with regulators to raise up to $220 million in an initial public offering of common stock.

headline: Fox News Regrets Obama Headline
abstract: Jim Rutenberg reports: “For the third time in less than three weeks, Fox News Channel has had to acknowledge using poor judgment through inappropriate references to Senator Barack Obama.” Read more…

headline: Upfronts: Selling The NFL Network To Advertisers
abstract: Broadcasting & Cable: “The National Football League held an upfront Thursday evening for its two flagship media properties, NFL Network and NFL.com, in which it tried to assure advertisers that the network’s distribution struggles would not keep it from growing subscribers.”

headline: Greenberg May Face Civil Charges, Report Says
abstract: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, may face civil charges for his alleged role in an effort to improperly boost the insurer’s financials, The Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday.

headline: Freddie Mac Posts Loss, Tempered by Accounting
abstract: Freddie Mac, one of the nation’s largest buyers of home loans, announced a fresh wave of bad news Wednesday, disclosing losses that were smaller than expected only because of accounting tactics that minimized the effects of bad loans.

headline: BG Goes Hostile With $13.1 Billion Bid for Australia’s Orgin
abstract: British gas producer BG Group launched a hostile $13.1 billion bid for Australia’s Origin Energy, as it seeks to boost its position in Asia-Pacific’s fast-growing gas market.

headline: Hong Kong Bank to Select Buyer Next Week
abstract: Hong Kong’s Wing Lung Bank, whose stock has gained 52 percent this year, will likely select the buyer for a majority stake next week, Bloomberg News reported citing three unnamed sources.

headline: Société Générale Inks Alliance With Rockefeller Financial
abstract: Société Générale, the French bank, and wealth management company Rockefeller Financial Services announced a global alliance on Tuesday in the private banking sector.

headline: Morgan Stanley Chairman Wins Re-election
abstract: John J. Mack, facing down an investor campaign to unseat him as the chairman of Morgan Stanley, was re-elected by an overwhelming margin on Tuesday.

headline: Buyout Lender Sees More Trouble Ahead
abstract: Intermediate Capital Group, a lender to private equity buyouts, warned on Wednesday of more credit trouble ahead but reported higher profits and said it was well placed to ride out a recession in Britain.

headline: Biotech Firms in $6.7 Billion Merger
abstract: Invitrogen, which makes chemical kits used to analyze and clone genes, said it agreed to combine with Applied Biosystems Group, a unit of Applera, in a cash and stock deal it valued at $6.7 billion. The deal price of $38 per share is 17 percent above Applied Biosystems’ closing stock price on Wednesday.

headline: A Redesign at Skype
abstract: A new version of Skype makes it easier to set up video-calls and organize records of past conversations.

headline: Leverage May Be a Double-Edged Sword for Zell
abstract: Is Samuel Zell going from leverage victor to leverage victim?

headline: France in racing focus
abstract: Just a moment to reflect on the coming week and a half: France is the place to be this time. First, this weekend there is the 24 Hours of Le Mans. Yesterday the first qualifying session gave us all what we expected – or not quite. The top six cars were the Audis and the Peugeots and the seventh car was a Pescarolo. Wait, sorry, that order is not quite right, and that’s what’s interesting: The Peugeots took the top three spots, followed by the Audis and then the Pescarolo.

headline: Next For The Osbournes: A Variety Show?
abstract: Next up for the Osbourne family: a variety show?

headline: A Budweiser Independence Plan
abstract: Quite a European party. That was my biggest impression listening to InBev‘s conference call Thursday morning. As everyone knows by now, InBev has made a proposal to acquire Anheuser-Busch at $65 a share.

headline: Big Box on ‘The Sopranos’
abstract: A a 30-disc box set with every episode of the HBO series ”The Sopranos” weighs in at nearly 10 pounds.

headline: Apollo-Backed Metals USA Files for I.P.O.
abstract: Metals USA Holdings, a metal processing company owned by Apollo Management, filed to raise as much as $200 million in an initial public offering on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Renovations at Magny-Cours
abstract: The French Grand Prix was never supposed to return to Magny-Cours. Somehow it did. Now, plans for the race to return to other parts of France – Paris, Versailles, Rouen, Disneyland – abound. So does a plan that Magny-Cours is offering to update its facilities to tempt Formula One back. While several venues, like Silverstone and Donington Park, are talking about renovations that could cost tens of millions of dollars, Magny-Cours’ latest plans also looks fairly costly, with an updating of the pit building, grandstands being fitting with awnings, etc.

headline: Bernanke Says Banks Need More Capital
abstract: Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, pushed banks on Thursday to keep raising capital in the aftermath of losses from the credit crisis to avert deeper damage to the economy.

headline: Will Amazon Lose Sales Because It Collects New York Taxes?
abstract: Even though Amazon is now collecting sales tax on shipments to New York State, at least one analyst suggests that its sales to the state will hardly fall. Online shoppers value convenience more than lower prices, some research shows.

headline: Lehman Said to Prepare 5% Staff Cut
abstract: While Morgan Stanley reportedly cut 1,500 jobs last week, Lehman Brothers will begin to cut about 5 percent of its staff on Monday, according to CNN Money.

headline: MBIA Debt Is Setting Up a Quandary
abstract: The risks associated with the vast, unregulated market for credit default swaps played a crucial role in the bailout of Bear Stearns. Now these financial instruments are taking center stage in another Wall Street drama: whether regulators will let MBIA, the big bond insurance company, renege on a promise to shore up a crucial unit with $900 million in capital.

headline: Deutsche Telekom Gains Control of OTE
abstract: Deutsche Telekom on Wednesday reached an agreement with the Greek government that will give the phone group management control of Hellenic Telecommunications Organization, or OTE.

headline: XTO to Buy Hunt Petroleum for $4.2 Billion
abstract: XTO Energy, an oil and natural gas producer, said Tuesday that it will acquire Hunt Petroleum, a company owned by descendants of oil tycoon H.L. Hunt, for about $4.2 billion in cash and stock, in what is the latest in a string of rapid-fire deals this year.

headline: Indian Media Giant Buys Virgin Radio From Scottish Firm
abstract: An Indian media conglomerate that owns The Times of India, the world’s largest-circulation English newspaper, has agreed to buy Virgin Radio Holdings for 53.2 million pounds ($105 million) in its first foreign acquisition.

headline: Carlyle to Lead Buyout of Japanese Glass Business
abstract: The Carlyle Group will lead a 58.1 billion yen ($560 million) management buyout of an LCD glass venture jointly owned by Japan’s Hoya and Nippon Sheet Glass, Hoya said on Friday.

headline: Lime Rock Raises $1.4 Billion for New Energy Fund
abstract: Lime Rock , a private equity firm that focuses on the global energy sector announced Thursday that it had closed its fifth Lime Rock Partners fund, Lime Rock Partners V, L.P., with a total $1.4 billion in investor capital commitments.

headline: Sue Naegle’s Foundation at HBO
abstract: Jacques Steinberg speaks to Sue Naegle, the new president of HBO Entertainment:

headline: Grim Clues as Bayou Founder Goes Missing
abstract: The sordid story of Bayou Group, the defunct hedge fund founded by Samuel Israel III, has taken a macabre twist.

headline: Evercore Toasts Bollinger
abstract: Evercore Capital Partners has bought a majority stake in insurance broker Bollinger in a deal valued at $250 million, The Daily Deal reported citing unnamed sources.

headline: Cablevision’s Newsday Bid Would Face Few Regulatory Hurdles
abstract: If Cablevision Systems manages to wrest the Tribune Company‘s Long Island, N.Y., newspaper Newsday away from other interested bidders, the transaction would raise the ire of consumer groups, but regulators in Washington won’t have much to say, The Deal.com reported.

headline: ‘Survivor,’ ‘Cops’ and ‘Oprah’ Will Join Sprint to High-Def
abstract: LAS VEGAS — As high-definition television matures, more and more programs are making the move.

headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

headline: Economy Hits U.S. PC Sales, but Notebook Growth Remains Strong
abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

headline: Amazon Gains Share of Shrinking Paid Music Market
abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

headline: Yahoo’s Starting Point: A Clearer Strategy
abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

headline: The Network That AT&T’s Growing Profits Will Buy
abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

headline: Clinton’s High-Tech, Smooth-Jazz Songsmith Is Back
abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

headline: The iPhone Shortage
abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: All Quiet on the Deal Front as Electronic Arts Posts Loss
abstract: The video game publisher Electronic Arts posted a wider fourth-quarter loss on one-time charges on Tuesday, but its adjusted results fueled by game sales beat Wall Street’s expectations.

headline: Spot Runner Said to Snag Another $51 Million
abstract: Spot Runner, an Internet-based advertising network that puts local business pitches on TV and radio, expects to announce Wednesday that it has landed another $51 million from investors including British media company Daily Mail and General Trust, Spanish media group Grupo Televisa, institutional investor Legg Mason Capital Management, and the luxury conglomerate Groupe Arnault/LVMH, CNet News.com reported.

headline: Takeda Pays Alnylam $100 Million for Drug Development Rights
abstract: Alnylam Pharmaceuticals, of Cambridge, Mass., and Takeda Pharmaceutical announced a complex deal Tuesday that gives Japan’s largest drugmaker the right to develop medicine based on the new field of RNA interference, or RNAi.

headline: Potential Indian Bid for Motorola Unit Meets With Skepticism
abstract: An interested buyer has emerged for Motorola‘s beleaguered cellphone unit, but it’s not one of the company’s handset competitors or a marquee consumer electronics manufacturer.

headline: Ten Million Tune to ABC’s Debate
abstract: More than 10 million viewers tuned into Wednesday’s Democratic debate on ABC, making it the most-watched debate of the primary election season.

headline: ‘Idol’ By the Numbers: 97 Million Votes, 31.7 Million Viewers
abstract: This week’s final round of “American Idol” culminated in the announcement Wednesday night on Fox that David Cook, 25, had become the seventh winner of the series. A record 97 million votes were cast, according to the network, and ratings for the singing competition improved slightly over the show’s finale a year ago.

headline: Rumor Was Wrong, or At Least Premature
abstract: The S.E.C. nailed its first credit crunch rumormonger today. He is Paul S. Berliner, a 32-year old trader from Brooklyn.

headline: Taking Stock of the Credit Comeback
abstract: Is the worst of the credit crisis behind us? Narrower yield premiums and an uptick in issuances have offered Wall Street some comfort, but Investment Dealers’ Digest says there are worrisome signs as well.

headline: Funds Sue WCI Steel Over Russian Deal
abstract: WCI Steel‘s proposed $140 million sale to Russian metals company OAO Severstal is stirring up a legal fight. Funds holdings stakes in WCI, a Warren, Ohio-based steelmaker, filed a lawsuit June 13 in Delaware Court of Chancery to try to stop the transaction.

headline: Let the Tax Collection Begin
abstract: Amazon.com and other online merchants began collecting sales tax on purchases by people in New York State last Sunday. Overstock.com, which is not collecting the tax, filed a law suit to challenge the new state policy.

headline: BHP Chief Makes His Case for Rio Deal
abstract: BHP Billiton on Thursday took its case for a takeover of rival Rio Tinto to well-heeled investors on Thursday, saying a marriage could better capture markets in fast-industrializing Asian economies.

headline: The old and the new, two racing circuits and a thought
abstract: Before yesterday, the last time I visited the Mont Tremblant racing circuit was in 1999. It was not just old and decrepit, it was a veritable ghost of a lost Formula One track. The pit building was nothing but rubble, the surface of the track had not been redone since it was first laid down in 1964. But I loved the charm of the place.

headline: Nearly Half of Wall St. Bank Profits Are Gone
abstract: Only a year ago, Wall Street reveled in an era of superlatives: record deals, record profit, record pay. But a mere 12 months later, nearly half of the profits that major banks reaped during that age of riches have vanished.

headline: Carlyle, Blackstone Miffed at Bankrupt Homebuilder
abstract: Carlyle Group and Blackstone Group‘s GSO Capital hedge fund say they’re being left out in the cold in the case of a bankrupt homebuilder that they claim fraudulently obtained a credit line designed to keep it afloat, The New York Post reported.

headline: Bezos Backs Twitter in New Round
abstract: Twitter, the popular microblogging service, announced that it has picked up some new investors: Spark Capital and Jeff Bezos, via his Bezos Expeditions fund.

headline: Merrill Raising Big Asian Property Fund
abstract: Merrill Lynch and Asian brokerage CLSA are separately raising investment funds focused on Asian property, indicating continued confidence in the region’s economies, executives from the two companies said at the weekend.

headline: ‘Funny Or Die’ In HBO Deal
abstract: Coming soon to HBO: programming from the creators of the comedy Web site Funny or Die.

headline: 2 Busches, 2 Opinions on Merger Bid
abstract: Silence still enshrouds Anheuser-Busch as it deliberates over its response to InBev‘s $46.4 billion takeover offer. But two uncles of the company’s chief executive presented two very different opinions over the tabled bid, emphasizing rifts within the Busch family that may complicate the brewer’s decisions.

headline: Big Fine Set for Wachovia to End Case
abstract: The Wachovia Corporation agreed on Friday to pay as much as $144 million to end an investigation that accuses the bank of allowing telemarketers to use its accounts to steal millions of dollars.

headline: V.C.s Put Another $12.5 Million on eMeter
abstract: eMeter has bagged $12.5 million in venture capital funding for its energy management software.

headline: Free Political Ring Tones
abstract: “RingTones08.com is a free site that lets anyone from any political persuasion post and share ring tones about the 2008 U.S. election. Join the political conversation and Ring it ON!”

headline: A.I.G.’s Raising of Capital Depresses Its Share Price
abstract: The American International Group‘s recent issue of equity and debt is expected to raise about $20 billion, far more than initially expected, its chief executive, Martin J. Sullivan, confirmed Tuesday.

headline: Inventors: Mask That Crawl
abstract: Calling all inventors: There must be a way to get rid of those distracting messages crawling across the bottom of the TV screen.

headline: Tom and Ray Become ‘Click & Clack’
abstract: The popular radio show “Car Talk” is finally being adapted for television.

headline: Circuit City Said to Explore Sale
abstract: Facing activist pressure to put itself on the block, struggling electronics retailer Circuit City Stores has hired Goldman Sachs for advice, The Deal.com reported.

headline: Nine Months Before the Digital TV Transition, 25 Million Homes Are Unready
abstract: Nearly 25 million homes have at least one television set that will stop functioning in nine months, when the nation converts to digital over-the-air television.

headline: 3i Infrastructure to Raise $230 Million for New Investments
abstract: 3i Infrastructure, the 700 million pound ($1.4 billion) fund run by private equity firm 3i Group , is raising 114.6 million pounds ($222.8 million) for new investments.

headline: United and Continental Form Alliance
abstract: Continental Airlines and United Airlines, which decided in April not to merge, said Thursday that they had reached an agreement to link their networks and operations worldwide.

headline: Northern Rock Reports Loss
abstract: Northern Rock, the British mortgage lender taken over by the government, on Monday reported a loss of 168 million pounds ($333 million) for 2007, compared with a profit of 627 million pounds in 2006, because of costs related to its funding crisis and higher losses on risky assets and home loans.

headline: GLG Portfolio Manager Considered Leaving
abstract: GLG Partners, the British hedge fund that went public last year, seems to have had an embarrassing brush with potential disaster.

headline: BrisConnections Said to Seek $1.18 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: BrisConnections, a group including Australia’s largest construction company Leighton Holdings plans to raise 1.23 billion Australian dollars ($1.18 billion) in an initial public offer, The Australian newspaper reported.

headline: Grey Wolf Rejects Canadian Offer
abstract: Grey Wolf said Thursday its board has concluded that Precision Drilling Trust‘s unsolicited bid for the U.S. contract oil driller would not be a better deal for Grey Wolf than its planned merger with Basic Energy Services.

headline: Linens ‘n Things Picks Stalking-Horse Bidders
abstract: Tiger Capital Group and SB Capital Group won a bidding war to become the joint stalking-horse bidders to lead a partial liquidation of Linens ‘n Things, paving the way for the May 29 auction of Apollo Management‘s bankrupt retailer.

headline: Planet Green’s Premiere Schedule
abstract: When the Discovery Home Channel becomes Planet Green Wednesday at 6 p.m., the new channel will offer a broad sample of its environmentally-themed schedule. Here is the premiere night programming, according to Discovery:

headline: French Deal, American Red Tape
abstract: Need some light beach reading? On Monday, Gaz de France filed its Form F-4 registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, registering the Gaz de France shares to be issued to acquire Suez.

headline: ABC Exports Two Dramas to Colombia
abstract: Clones of the ABC soap opera “Desperate Housewives” have become breakout hits in South America. Now Disney is signing deals to produce local versions of two other series, “Grey’s Anatomy” and “Brothers & Sisters,” in other countries as well.

headline: Analysts Return to Yahoo: Bad Omen for a Deal?
abstract: Since Microsoft formally pulled its bid for Yahoo over the weekend, Wall Street and Silicon Valley have been parsing every comment and reading every tea leaf in hopes of figuring out whether a deal is still possible.

headline: Colorado Proposes Tough Law on Executive Accountability
abstract: A proposed ballot measure in Colorado is seeking to create what supporters hope will be the nation’s toughest corporate fraud law.

headline: Super Aguri sale off
abstract: The Super Aguri team, which has had big financial problems, but was expected to be bought out by a company called Magma Group has just announced that this purchase will not happen. Here is the team statement:

headline: Is Continental Preparing for a Deal to Take Off?
abstract: Update: Continental and United are in merger negotiations and hope to finalize a deal by next week, The New York Times reported Friday afternoon.

headline: Before Basketball, Jimmy Kimmel
abstract: Broadcasting & Cable: “ABC is trotting out a series of ‘Jimmy Kimmel Live’ primetime specials leading into its coverage of the National Basketball Association Finals, which begin June 5.” The half-hour “Game Night” specials “will air before each basketball game at 8 p.m. in the Eastern and Central time zones and after the game in the Mountain and Pacific zones.”

headline: Convicted Hedge Fund Scammer Sues N.Y.U.
abstract: A young man convicted of running a hedge fund scam in Connecticut has filed a federal lawsuit against New York University, claiming the school owes him a diploma, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Skeptics Weigh in on Delta-Northwest Deal
abstract: During a conference call with industry analysts on Tuesday, Richard H. Anderson, chief executive of Delta Air Lines, described his just-announced merger plans with Northwest Airlines to create the world’s largest carrier as “a perfect deal.”

headline: Viewers Tired of Campaign Coverage?
abstract: AFP reports: “Americans say the media are devoting too much ink and airtime to the US presidential race, amid growing criticism that news coverage has focused on the superficial instead of important issues.” According to a weekly poll by the Pew Research Center, half of the public say news outlets are offering “too much coverage of the campaign.”

headline: What’s Behind the Stupid Face Spam Scourge?
abstract: Why spam messages that insult a person’s appearance are proliferating. (And , needless to say, don’t open them. Just read this to find out what is in it.)

headline: Lawsuit Criticizes Yahoo Retention Plan
abstract: Yahoo‘s chief executive, Jerry Yang, pushed for an expensive plan to retain employees in the event of an acquisition by Microsoftdespite reservations of some Yahoo executives and of a consulting firm that Yahoo hired to help devise the plan, according to a shareholder lawsuit.

headline: Upfronts: Let Us Entertain You
abstract: Several networks stuck to their plans, previously announced, to cut back on the hoopla and hyperbole for the 2008-09 upfront week. Others decided that the assembled advertising agency employees and journalists could use a song, a laugh or a glimpse of a celebrity or two.

headline: Bank of America Bids Good-Bye to Prime Brokerage
abstract: From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

headline: More on Wilbur Ross’s Middle Eastern Fundraising
abstract: Bloomberg News reported Wednesday that Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the billionaire financier known for buying companies cheaply, plans to approach sovereign wealth funds about investing in his project to buy stakes in a handful of regional banks and combine them with some mortgage-related companies that his investment firm, W.L. Ross & Company, has already purchased.

headline: JPMorgan’s 1st-Quarter Earnings Fall 50%
abstract: JPMorgan Chase reported first-quarter earnings of $2.4 billion on Wednesday, a nearly 50 percent slump from the same time last year, but still a show of some strength at a time when its rivals have suffered worse.

headline: Pfizer May Table Counter-Bid for India’s Ranbaxy, Report Says
abstract: Pfizer may bid for Ranbaxy Laboratories, countering a $4.6 billion offer by Japan’s Daiichi Sankyo for the Indian generic drug maker, the Business Standard newspaper said.

headline: Philbin’s ‘Password’ Wins Sunday Night
abstract: Regis Philbin made a promising return to prime-time television on Sunday as the host of a new game show, “Million Dollar Password.” The series, an updated version of the classic game show in which contestants team up with celebrity guests to win a million dollars, attracted the night’s largest audience, 10.7 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. (Watch the show here.)

headline: Bidding War Continues for Herald Resources
abstract: In what is quickly turning into a heated bidding war, a consortium of Antam and Shenzhen Zhongjin have offered up to A$524 million ($500 million) for Australian mineral exploration and development company Herald Resources, trumping an earlier offer made by Bumi Resources.

headline: The Case for a Viacom Buyout, Again
abstract: A lot has changed since the summer of 2006, when leveraged buyouts were booming and most people had never heard of subprime mortgages. But at least one thing remains the same: Richard Greenfield, the outspoken stock analyst from Pali Research, still thinks Viacom would be better off as a private company.

headline: India’s Sterlite Buys Bankrupt Miner Asarco
abstract: India’s Sterlite Industries on Saturday agreed to buy the operating assets of bankrupt copper miner Asarco for $2.6 billion, the latest in the series of overseas acquisitions by Indian firms.

headline: Noble Environment Whips Up I.P.O. Plans
abstract: Wind energy company Noble Environmental Power has filed to raise as much as $375 million in an initial public offering, according to a document with the Securities and Exchange Commission that was filed Thursday.

headline: Don’t Blame Milken for the Mortgage Crisis
abstract: As the credit markets have seized up, some on Wall Street have drawn a line from the current crisis back to Michael R. Milken, once known as the “junk bond king” of Drexel Burnham Lambert. But did the junk bond and the slicing and dicing of debt — both of which Mr. Milken clearly helped popularize — lead to the mess we are in today? Absolutely not, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column in The New York Times. Such criticism is akin to blaming the inventor of paper money, he says.

headline: For ‘Battlestar,’ A Strong Debut
abstract: Multichannel News: “‘Battlestar Galactica’s’ fourth and final season launched on a strong Nielsen note, notching its best performance against its target audience since the bow of its third season and top numbers among adults 18 to 49 in over two years.”

headline: February Sweep Becomes March Sweep In ’09
abstract: Broadcasting & Cable: “Nielsen is moving the February 2009 sweeps to March to avoid the ‘potential disruptions’ associated with the switch to digital. It will also begin testing ratings collection on digital-only stations in December 2008.”

headline: When Chiefs Follow Lieutenants Out the Door
abstract: Perhaps the ultimate test of a top Wall Street executive is simple: Stay in the game. Of course, one needs to make money, and preferably lots of it, but especially when times grow tough, the hardest task is simply to hold onto one’s seat.

headline: Newspapers Argue for First Amendment Right to Snoop on Readers
abstract: In comments to the Federal Trade Commission, the Newspaper Association of America challenged proposed rules on advertising based on where users surf online. It argued that such restrictions run afoul of the First Amendment’s protection of the freedom of the press.

abstract: PC sales in the United States are dramatically slowing, but sales in the rest of the world are staying strong. Laptops are overtaking desktops acorss the globe, says IDC, the research firm.

abstract: Amazon’s five-month-old digital download store has become the distant No. 2 in that market to Apple, according to NPD. But other data show that people are still borrowing and stealing music more and not buying it.

headline: HDTVs Shrink
abstract: Consumers are shifting to smaller HDTV as the economy weakens. No surprise there. But its surprising how well the largest sized TVs continue to sell.

abstract: Yahoo executives outlined a more sharply defined and plausible strategy for competing with Google.

abstract: For telephone users, AT&Ts latest talk with investors had mixed news: it is building a new high speed wireless network. But its profit margins are growing, as lower competition reduces pressure to keep prices low.

abstract: Gene Wang, a three-time Silicon Valley chief executive and musically inclined Hillary Clinton supporter, has penned another pro-Clinton ditty.

headline: Congress to Take Testimony on Internet Gambling Ban
abstract: At a hearing Wednesday, a House subcommittee will Stop online gambling by cutting off the flow of money to offshore casinos? A House subcommittee will talk about whether this is feasible at a hearing Wednesday.

headline: The iPhone Shortage
abstract: Apple stores are sold out of iPhones. Some analysts see signs of a new model coming. But one says Apple is simply favoring AT&T stores in order to lift its reported first-quarter sales.

headline: Second Life: Tamed for Corporate Consumption
abstract: I.B.M. and Linden Labs are developing a way for people working behind a corporate firewall to visit the virtual world, Second Life. The advantage: corporate brainstorming session or product-design simulation exercise would be attended by relatively small numbers of interested people, company employees or partners, not the wider Second Life world.

headline: Merrill to Raise $9.55 Billion in Bond-and-Share Sale
abstract: Merrill Lynch, the third-biggest U.S. securities firm, is raising $9.55 billion by selling bonds and preferred shares after writing down the value of $6.5 billion of assets.

headline: Lehman Reports $2.8 Billion Loss
abstract: Lehman Brothers on Monday reported a $2.8 billion loss for its fiscal second quarter, confirming last week’s dismal earnings update. Richard Fuld Jr., the chief executive of the embattled Wall Street firm, said in a statement that Lehman has “begun to take the necessary steps to restore the credibility of our great franchise and ensure that this quarter’s unacceptable performance is not repeated.”

headline: Merrill Lynch and TPG in Talks on Closer Ties, Report Says
abstract: Merrill Lynch is holding high-level talks with TPG that could see the private equity group take a stake in the investment bank if it needs additional capital, according to The Financial Times.

headline: Renewable Energy Appeal Is Newest Twist on Old E-Mail Scheme
abstract: Email scammers are now trying to convince victims to invest in wacky alternative energy schemes.

headline: Manitowic Raises Offer for Enodis to $2.11 Billion
abstract: Manitowic has raised its takeover offer for British catering equipment group Enodis to 1.08 billion pounds ($2.11 billion), outbidding Illinois Tool Works, MarketWatch reported.

headline: America – An Iraqi’s First Impression
abstract: Suadad al-Salhy is an Iraqi reporter who recently joined The New York Times in Iraq. In May she was one of five Iraqi journalists who visited the United States on a reporting tour organized by the State Department to learn about ‘How America’s Middle East Policy is Formulated.’

headline: Reducing the Amount of Juice Electronic Gadgets Consume
abstract: APC has taken a healthy step in the right direction with its Power-Saving SurgeArrest surge protector power strip.

headline: Illinois to Sue Countrywide
abstract: The Illinois attorney general is suing Countrywide Financial, the troubled mortgage lender, and Angelo R. Mozilo, its chief executive, contending that the company and its executives defrauded borrowers in the state by selling them costly and defective loans that quickly went into foreclosure.

headline: Post-Spitzer, a New Breed of Reformer
abstract: No one is dusting off those valiant titles once bestowed on Eliot Spitzer, honorifics like “The Enforcer” and “Sheriff of Wall Street.” But slowly, even a bit gently, Mr. Spitzer’s successor as the attorney general of New York, Andrew M. Cuomo, is shaking up the financial industry, according to The New York Times.

headline: The Highest-Paid Voices on TV?
abstract: According to The Hollywood Reporter:

headline: Semel’s IMG Plans: Wishful Thinking?
abstract: Reports surfaced Monday that Terry Semel, the former Yahoo C.E.O. has been eyeing Ted Forstmann’s talent and marketing agency IMG.

headline: Wachovia Probed in Drug Money Investigation
abstract: Wachovia is being investigated by federal prosecutors as part of an inquiry into alleged laundering of drug proceeds by Mexican and Colombian money-transfer companies, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Said to Mull Massive Rights Issue
abstract: Royal Bank of Scotland is considering a multi-billion-pounds rights issue that could spark a wave of similar moves by other banks, according to British press reports.

headline: Upfronts Preview: ABC
abstract: The fall schedule will look familiar, as ABC’s powerhouse dramas will all be back. Most of the new series will be introduced later in the season.

headline: Pa. Primary: The Perception Battle
abstract: Jim Rutenberg reports on Tuesday’s primary coverage on cable news:

headline: 2007, a Vintage Year for Mortgage Bears
abstract: In the second half of 2007, many hedge-fund wizards seemed to lose their magic — but not John Paulson. According to estimates in the latest issue in Trader Monthly, Mr. Paulson earned about $3 billion last year, thanks in large part to his firm’s bets that the subprime mortgage market would collapse.

headline: ‘ER’ Producer John Wells Turns From Docs to Cops
abstract: With veteran NBC medical drama ‘ER’ heading into its 15th and final season, series writer/producer John Wells has set up a new drama series project at the network.

headline: Study of ‘Daily Show:’ It’s A Lot Like O’Reilly
abstract: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Back-Up Your Mac, Effortlessly
abstract: David Pogue tests Apple’s Time Capsule, which backs up your computer automatically, constantly, completely and wirelessly.

headline: The Wendy’s Deal That Wasn’t
abstract: Wendy’s International and Triarc were sounding quite chummy on Thursday as they announced their proposed $2.3 billion stock-for-stock merger. But as recently as last week, the two sides were sniping at each other over several things, including two other deals proposed by Triarc that the Wendy’s board shot down.

headline: Upfronts: When the Cars Are the Stars
abstract: On Monday NBC announced a “strategic partnership” with General Motors for the 2008-9 season. Under the deal, two G.M. car brands will be incorporated into a new drama, “My Own Worst Enemy,” which will star Christian Slater at 10 p.m. Mondays.

headline: JPMorgan’s Coyle Said to Take Post at Permira
abstract: John Coyle, the global head of JPMorgan Chase‘s financial sponsor group, is leaving the company to join private equity firm Permira, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Newspaper Chain Hires Adviser as It Weighs Restructuring
abstract: In a magazine article seven years ago, the chief executive of the Journal Register Company, the publicly traded newspaper company, bragged about being such a skinflint that he checked the odometers in reporters’ vehicles to verify expense reports.

headline: Kerviel Has Not Filed Suit Against SocGen, Lawyer Says
abstract: Jérôme Kerviel, at the center of a rogue trading scandal at French bank Société Générale, has not launched any legal action against his past employer for now, a lawyer representing the former trader said.

headline: New iPhone Pricing Model Is a Step Backward for Consumers
abstract: By subsidizing the cost of the new iPhone and locking customers into a two-year contract, AT&T is returning to a more traditional U.S. pricing model for cell phones. And that’s a step backward for open networks, says one analyst.

headline: Delaware Court Considers Suit Over Bear Sale
abstract: The Delaware Chancery Court made no immediate ruling Monday on a shareholder lawsuit seeking to delay the sale of Bear Stearns to JPMorgan Chase. The judge said he plans to issue a written ruling on the matter in the next several days.

headline: Clear Channel’s Texas Suit Can Proceed, Judge Rules
abstract: A judge in Texas on Friday refused a request by several New York-based banks to dismiss a lawsuit filed by Clear Channel Communications and two buyout firms trying to acquire the radio operator.

headline: Microsoft Could Withstand 10% Increase in Yahoo Bid, Analyst Says
abstract: Microsoft could increase its bid for Yahoo by 10 percent without spooking its investors, according to one Wall Street analyst cited by CNet’s News.com.

headline: Questions About Goldman’s Bearish WaMu Call
abstract: Was the recent call by Goldman Sachs to short the stock of lender Washington Mutual a sign of the declining influence of Wall Street’s research business?

headline: Friday’s Links: Why Lawyers Leave
abstract: With large numbers of lawyers fleeing the legal profession, one ex-lawyer starts a project to try to understand why.
